abstract: on forecast of the Rebellion
snippet: on forecast of the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: -- We give place to-day to a communication, written fourteen years ago, in which our distinguished cosmopolitan correspondent, DON RUFINO M. DE ALFARERO Y. CAMPION, shows how shrewd ly he was able to forecast many of the great events which have transpired since the opening of the rebellion. Among the arguments most lucidly illustrated in our correspondent's letter, are those which show the impossibility of securing Peace by Disunion, and which make it apparent that a dissolution of the Union would be ruin of the South. There is admirable pertinence, too, in our correspondent's illustrations of the logical consequences of the South depending, for the establishment of a separate nationality, upon England.

abstract: Thirteen, The, Appeal of Rejected; Electoral Liberty and Judicial Purity in France
snippet: Thirteen, The, Appeal of Rejected; Electoral Liberty and Judicial Purity in France
lead_paragraph: The cause of popular freedom in France has experienced another disaster. The appeal of the " Thirteen" to the Court Imperial has failed, and the sentence of the inferior court has been confirmed -- that is, the accused must pay a fine of five hundred francs each or go to prison.

abstract: Precedents in International Law; English Precedents on
snippet: Precedents in International Law; English Precedents on
lead_paragraph: The letter which Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH addressed to the Boston Advertiser, and which was copied in one of our recent issues, conveyed, in the well-known nervous style of the author, a most just rebuke to a growing habit, both of our public men and our press. Whenever an irregular or unjust action is committed by our naval officers, or generals, or magistrates -- when the only rational course for any sensible American is to at once confess that the thing was out of order, and must be redressed -- there at once starts up some so-called "statesman," or industrious journalist, who amazes the public with an immense list of English precedents, with precisely the same odious, tyrannical or unjust character as the deed in question. The docile people are instructed that such actions are excusable or even right, because England has committed similar, and they leave the perusal of these clever briefs of their attorneys with the idea, that on the whole the American Republic is right if it does not do more or worse than its powerful ancestor has done. When the Trent affair occurred, there was not a popular leader, so far as we remember, who recalled to the nation its own advanced and liberal position on international questions, and the noble traditions and precedents of its past, and its duty in taking a more enlightened and generous view of these matters than had been taken by the Old World. All that we had from our professed guides were appeals to the passions of the hour, and miserable citations from what GOLDWIN SMITH so happily calls, "the criminal records" of England.

abstract: Politics in
snippet: Politics in
lead_paragraph: The King of the Greeks has taken the oath prescribed by the new Constitution, and the National Assembly has been dissolved. Before taking the oath, his Majesty addressed some admirable words to the Assembly: "Representatives," said he, "in taking the oath to observe the Constitution, I feel convinced that it is the duly both of governors and of the governed to observe with fidelity all its provisions, and to obey strictly all the laws of the State." This is a sentiment worthy the sovereign of a free people, and would be a guarantee for the stability of the Constitution if the power of the young monarch were equal to his good intentions. But this is far from being the case. GEORGE I. of Greece is bound to be swayed and controlled by his Ministers, like other constitutional Kings, and, as it is by no means certain that those functionaries will entertain their master's respect for the law, it would be rather unsafe to prognosticate the long life of the new Constitution because of the royal address.

abstract: Escape from Columbia, S C.
snippet: Escape from Columbia, S C.
lead_paragraph: Lieut.-Col. THOS J. LEIGH arrived in this city Saturday afternoon from Columbia, S.C., from which place he escaped on the 31st day of October. The Colonel's adventures on his journey through Secessia are very interesting. The following is his story, told in his own language: "I was captured on the 5th day of May, in the battle of the Wilderness, while we were charging the Stonewall Brigade. I was taken to Orange Court-house, and the next morning conveyed to Gordonsville, en route for Lynchburgh. About three miles from Charlottsville I made my escape from the train of cars, and after wandering about for two days was recaptured and taken to Lynchburgh, thence to Danville, and thence to Macon. In Macon I was placed in a stockade inclosing 2 1/2 acres, in which 1,800 Union prisoners were confined. In command of this post was Capt. TABBS, C.S.A., one of the most b[???]d cowardly officers I ever knew. He is now a prisoner in our hands. In the morning he would get us in line and use the vilest and most insulting language toward the "d__d Yankee scoundrels," as he called us. He was relieved by Col. GIBBS, TABBS being ordered to Petersburgh. On his way he was captured by SHERIDAN's cavalry. While TABBS was in command over us, one of our officers give him his watch to sell. The owner of the watch shortly after inquired for the proceeds, when TABBS took him to his quarters, and "bucked and gagged" him, and kept him there suffering torture, until some citizens interfered and procured his release. While in the stockade we finished five tunnels, and three more would have been completed in about four days, which would have secured our escape, if our plan had not been betrayed by one of our own officers.

abstract: Artists' Fund Pictures; Prices Realized; Presentation $50,000 to
snippet: Artists' Fund Pictures; Prices Realized; Presentation $50,000 to
lead_paragraph: The patriotism, the gratitude and the good sense of the citizens of New-York, was displayed in a becoming manner yesterday, in the presentation of a substantial testimonial to the great naval hero of the age, Vice-Admiral FARRAGUT. It was resolved about two weeks ago, to present him with some token of the regard and high estimation in which he was held by the community; and, in accordance with a suggestion from the TIMES, the committee having the matter in charge, determined to make the gift a useful and practicably valuable testimonial, which the recipient could enjoy in his lifetime, and hand down to his descendents in perpetuity. In pursuance of this plan, the munificent sum of $50,000 was collected by voluntary contribution in the short space of ten days; the last dollar being subscribed on Thursday. The money was then invested in United States Seven-thirty bonds, and the Admiral was invited to meet the committee yesterday morning at the Custom-house.

abstract: Spain, Fall of
snippet: Spain, Fall of
lead_paragraph: Another governmental crisis has occurred in Spain. After a three-months' existence, the Narvaez Ministry has fallen -- fallen, not because of their perfidious treatment of the press, not because of administrative delinquencies, during their brief term of office, not because a popular tempest had burst forth, but simply because Queen ISABELLA and their chief had differed on matters of foreign policy.

abstract: The Winter, although mild, may, as far as navigation is concerned, to considered fairly "set in." With the exception of a few miles above the harbor the North River is closed, and for several days but few vessels have had the temerity to venture below Hudson.
lead_paragraph: The Winter, although mild, may, as far as navigation is concerned, to considered fairly "set in." With the exception of a few miles above the harbor the North River is closed, and for several days but few vessels have had the temerity to venture below Hudson. The damage done to the docks by floating ice last Winter hue proved a sufficient warning to our shipowners to induce them to properly guard their piers. Most of the spiles have been double planked, and but little injury to shipping from ice this Winter need be anticipated. An effort is being made by merchants doing business in the vicinity of the Battery, to race a subscription to build a new dock for the landing of small bouts. It is a disgrace to the city that an enterprise of this character was not thought of before. It is a singular fact, so say travelers, that there is not a harbor in the world where there are such poor accommodations for reaching t[???]r[???] firma as at the City of New-York. Except at Pier No. 1 North River, there is no place where a small boat can land with safely. The tide at Castle Garden is stronger than at any other point in the harbor, and, when the fact is remembered that the steamer George Leory, on her trial trip, nearly cut the Battery dock in two, in consequence of the strong current, while trying to "found the Point," it will readily be seen that small craft are not safe without strong dock protection. Guests of the city, arriving from foreign ports, have on several occasions been comp[???]led to remain on shipboard for hours -- if being impossible to land in safety. In Jersey City the dock improvements are extensive, showing in enterprise on the part of shipowners on that side of the river worthy of emulation in New-York. The new steamship docks of the Bremen and Hamburg line of steamers are completed, and will compare favorably with the best piers in this city. A new company have recently been docking out from the lower part of Jersey City toward B[???]loe's Island, nearly a mile, making a secure landing for vessels of all classes. The arrival of foreign vessels during the present month is greater than during the same period last year, and the weekly report of the arrival of coast streamers is larger than at any time since the war. Thursday, as the sailors say, "the moon fulled," and as the wind was southwest, the indications are that it will [???]ow from [???]t [???]arfer for the next fourteen days. Hence any vessels driven off the coast by stress of weather will soon reach the harbor. In connection with harbor matters, it is well to give our skippers a hint concerning the observance of Sundays and holidays. In almost every civilized country shipping in harbor display bunting on the Sabbath, but in New-York the reverential custom has been almost entirely ignored. On Christmas, not one but of ta[???] [???]an vessels in port displayed signals, and the [???] to honor this day was generally noticed. The fog which for several days hung over the rivers has risen, and the ferry-boats were able to run their regular trips, much to the accommodation of the traveling public. During the prevalence of the fog there were a few accidents; a[???] the number the sinking of the steamer Com[???]d[???]r which struck on a rock while going through Hell Gate, and was run on the flats at Hunter's Pol[???]t, where the is now lying in about three feet of water. The steamer Kalahain ran on a reef near the Bellevue Gardens, opposite Blackwell's Island, but was soon floated off. The pro[???] Potomac, of the Portland line, also touched on the [???] near the Lunatic Asylum on Blackwell's Island, and after b[???]ea[???]ingone anchor proceeded down the river without [???]e[???] damage. There were several collisions of vessels, but no considerable damage was done. Old river Captains say our harbor has not been visited by such a dense fog for many years.

abstract: Philadelphia Union League on Local Bounties; Union League of Philadelphia; on; Bounties to Volunteers
snippet: Philadelphia Union League on Local Bounties; Union League of Philadelphia; on; Bounties to Volunteers
lead_paragraph: Certain responsible citizens connected with the Union League of Philadelphia have memorialized Congress on the subject of local bounties. They disapprove of local bounties altogether. They have had experience in the matter, and they tell us that, while the system was well enough as a stimulus to volunteering in the early stages of the war, its effect is to make the liability to military service an affair of bargain and sale, to lower the morale of the army, to deaden "all living interest in the war," to destroy all sense of personal responsibility, to make "dollars take the place of patriotism, and substitute paper credits for men." Much more in the same rhetorical vein occurs in the memorial. And then follow sundry recommendations. Among these are, that the President should be empowered to draft for one, two or three years during the war; to discourage offering local bounties; to have the Government bounty restricted to those who receive no local bounty, and generally to discourage volunteering by relying on an unconditional draft for the recruitment of the army.
headline: {'main': 'Bounties for Volunteers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Bounties for Volunteers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The laborers employed in cleaning the streets were made glad yesterday by the recession of Mayor GUNTHER from the ground he assumed respecting his refusal to sign the note upon the Broadway Bank, for the payment of their wages for the last nine weeks. The Mayor put his signature to the requisition by the advice of the Corporation Counsel. The strike of the street-cleaners is, therefore, at an end, and the danger that the city would be buried in ashes is, for the present at least, avoided. The Mayor's action was made known to the strikers in line for most of them to borrow money by "shaving" their claims, wherewith to keep the New-Year holiday.

abstract: Florida Case, Correspondence between Mr Seward and Brazil
snippet: Florida Case, Correspondence between Mr Seward and Brazil
lead_paragraph: It appears from official correspondence that on the 11th of November, Secretary SEWARD wrote to Minister WEBB that this Government had just heard of the capture of the Florida by the Wachusett at Bahia, and of the consequent hostilities adopted by the Brazilian forces in that port, and that in this stage of the matter, the President thought it proper that Mr. WEBB should inform the Minister for Foreign Affairs, that "we are not indisposed to examine the subject up to its merits carefully, and to consider whatever questions may arise out of it in a friendly and becoming spirit, if that spirit should be adopted by His Imperial Majesty's Government. On the 17th of December, Mr. BARBOSA, Charge d'Affaires ad interim, addressed Secretary SEWARD a letter in reference to the seizure of the Florida, calling it an act of the most transcendent gravity, which involved a manifest violation of the territorial jurisdiction of the Empire, and an offence to its honor and sovereignty. He enters into the particulars of the seizure. He concludes by saying:

abstract: The; Retrospect and Prospect
snippet: The; Retrospect and Prospect
lead_paragraph: We begin the year with great strength and with most excellent prospects. Our veteran and triumphant army, our powerful and gallant navy, have operated on the great rebellion during the year with an effect which would assuredly prove mortal to it, even if they were henceforth to stand still in their career of conquest. GRANT holds and commands Virginia more even than LEE; SHERMAN is master of Georgia and the Carolinas; we control the Mississippi; we are masters of Tennessee; the key positions of the great central mountain range are in our hands; the seaboard is under our power. Our armies are able to march anywhere through the Confederacy, and demolish its resources at their leisure. Within the last few weeks we have had bodies, consisting merely of cavalry, operating at their convenience over the State of Mississippi. The body which started from Baton Rouge have scoured across the Southern part of the State; the body which started from Vicksburgh rode across the central part; and we operate at pleasure in the whole Northern section. We mention this, merely to show from it, as well as from SHERMAN's march, the real weakness and hollowness of the Southern Confederacy. When SHERMAN started out from Atlanta in November, Lieut.-Gen. GRANT was in this city, and to a gentleman he made the remark: "The South is a mere shell; Gen. SHERMAN will soon prove it to you." Since then, SHERMAN has proved it, as he marched leisurely through Georgia, demolishing the railroads and supplies, capturing the State capital and its chief city, and doing, unmolestedly, whatever seemed to him wise and proper. South Carolina now lies open before him; and we do not suppose his experience there will differ greatly from what it was in Georgia.
headline: {'main': 'The New Year Retrospect and Prospect.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Year Retrospect and Prospect.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Washington Intelligencer About to Change Hands
snippet: Washington Intelligencer About to Change Hands
lead_paragraph: -Report says that the venerable Intelligencer is to change proprietorship, Col. SEATON withdrawing on an annuity, and the paper going into the hands of Mr. JOHN F. COLE, (being connected with its business management). Mr. A.G. ALLEN, well-known as an experienced journalist, and Col. WM.R. SNOW, a gentleman of energy and business capacity. It is to maintain the same political tone as heretofore, but is to be more newsy, and is to have a Sunday edition, and other startling innovations upon the old routine of that establishment. -- Washington Star, Dec. 27.

abstract: U S District Attorney's Office, Business for 1864; Dayton, W L; Funeral of
snippet: U S District Attorney's Office, Business for 1864; Dayton, W L; Funeral of
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning our citizens visited the City Hall in large numbers, in spite of the snow-storm, to silently honor the memory of the late Hon. WILLIAM L. DAYTON, Minister Plenipotentiary from the United States to the Court of France, by passing in mournful procession around the massive oak box in the Governor's Room, which contained the earthly remains of the distinguished dead. It is an unpleasant reflection, but it is nevertheless a fact, that the exceeding parsimony of the city admitted only or a flag to cover the coffin, not much larger than a boy's toy banner, and a hearse that might be classed among the shabby-genteel.

abstract: The recent announcement of the transfer of the North American Review to the house of Messrs. TICKNOR  FIELDS, of Boston, is hailed with pleasure by all who take an interest in American literature and in the prosperous condition of its oldest and most respected periodical organ.
lead_paragraph: -- The recent announcement of the transfer of the North American Review to the house of Messrs. TICKNOR & FIELDS, of Boston, is hailed with pleasure by all who take an interest in American literature and in the prosperous condition of its oldest and most respected periodical organ. In the tact, enterprise and extensive connexions of the firm who have become owners of the Review, a guarantee exists for the energetic prosecution of its business interests. No change is contemplated in the editorial management, the new life infused into the time-honored work since the accession of Messrs. LOWELL and NORTON to the chair, proving emphatically that its leadership is in good hands. Messrs. TICKNOR & FIELDS also give notice of a new literary enterprise of a serial character, an illustrated Child's Magazine, adapted for juvenile readers of all ages, and numbering among its contributors an array of names sufficient of itself to secure the success of any such undertaking, as AGASSIZ, Capt. MAYNE REID, Mrs. H.B. STOWE, the author of Ten Acres Enough, and many others.

abstract: Improper Publication of by Provost-Marshals; Improper Exposures; Conscription Exposures of Physical Disability
snippet: Improper Publication of by Provost-Marshals; Improper Exposures; Conscription Exposures of Physical Disability
lead_paragraph: We said a few words a day or two ago about the necessity for greater secresy on the part of assessors of the income tax. Most of our remarks will apply, mutatis mutandis, to the Provost-Marshals. The newspapers are filled every day with appeals to the public to assist in correcting the enrollment lists. Persons who are far any reason exempt from serving, are earnestly entreated to come in and prove their claims, so as to have their names removed from the books, and it is a constant subject of lamentation with the officials that so few respond to these appeals. Of course a large number refrain from doing so through sheer carelessness or unwillingness to give the necessary time to it. But of that very great class of persons, those who are disqualified by reason of physical disability, a large number are deterred from putting in their claims to exemption by the strong and most natural dislike to have their bodily ailments set down in black and white, in a book, which if not absolutely open to public inspection, nobody is under any obligation to keep private. There is, we believe, no restraint of any kind imposed on anybody connected with the conscription and recruiting service to keep anything he hears, sees or writes, secret or concealed. He may permit anybody he pleases to look over his list of exemptions, and ascertain the precise nature of the bodily infirmity which keeps any of his neighbors or friends from rushing to arms; or the Provost-Marshal may communicate it to him by word of mouth, or talk of it to his own acquaintances, not only without incurring any penalty, but without laying himself open to any imputation.

abstract: and Brazil, How to be Disposed of; The, in Florida Case
snippet: and Brazil, How to be Disposed of; The, in Florida Case
lead_paragraph: -- There is nothing new developed in the Florida case by the additional items of official correspondence which have found their way into print. Mr. SEWARD has taken simply the ground with Brazil, that he has taken with England. He refuses to recede from his former stand-point, that the Government of the United States must continue to regard these English-built war-vessels as pirates; and that, if the Government finds it necessary for the time to accept the character assigned to them by the so called neutral Powers, it does so under the strongest possible protest. As the pirates of the Florida were brought to the United States unlawfully, or rather by agents entirely unauthorized to make the capture, the prisoners will be given up to Brazil. The United States Consul is to be relieved from his post, and Capt. COLLINS will be tried by court-martial -- both for overstepping the line of their duty, and the flag of Brazil will be saluted with the customary honors due to an independent Power.

abstract: Public Feeling in
snippet: Public Feeling in
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most remarkable and significant revelation made by SHERMAN'S march through Georgia, is not the internal weakness of the Confederacy, the want of military strength inside tile "shell," but the entire absence of desperation on the part of that portion of the population which still remains at home. If the war were felt by them to be a national war, in the sense in which this phrase is ordinarily understood, a war in which everything that men hold dear was at stake, and in which death was preferable to submission, it is impossible to believe that their resistance to SHERMAN's progress would have been so feeble. The proclamations of the leaders, of the Governor and Generals, of the Senators and Congressmen, and the articles in the newspapers, were couched in terms worthy of the occasion. They were just such as ought to have been issued by revolutionary chiefs to followers who were really and terribly in earnest. They called on the Georgians to "come in squads or come singly," to "bring such weapons as they could find," to "rise to a man in the in vaders' path," "to bushwhack him without mercy." The planters were to shoot at him from behind fences; the negroes to be employed in cutting down trees across the road and breaking down bridges; and, last and greatest sacrifice of all, they were to lay waste everything before him, to drive off the cattle and horses, and burn and destroy what they could not convey away.

abstract: U.S. steam transport United States. Share. Baltimore 24 hours to U.S. Assistant Quartermaster. Dec. 31, off the Delaware lightship saw two sunken vessels. Observing something at the maintopmast of one of them, fore sown to her, and discovered it to be a man, dead, and issued to the topmast. Found on his person a gold watch, a pocketbook, containing a silver dollar, a three-dollar bank note and some copper coin; also the vessels papers, showing her to be the schr. Water Witch, Capt. Thos. Hull, iron Province, with a cargo of iron bars, oats and [???]ay, bound to Baltimore. The body was brought to this port and is supposed to be that of the Captain of the schooner.

abstract: The North not; Policy; The True; Relinquishment by Grant; Boasts about Texas,>amp;c.
snippet: The North not; Policy; The True; Relinquishment by Grant; Boasts about Texas,>amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The secessionist partisans in Europe have begun to draw comfort from the sophistical attempt made by DAVIS in his last message to make it appear that the withdrawal of Union troops from any place which they had once occupied, was a proof that the North was not only making no progress, but positively retrograding. DAVIS sets forth the fact that there are now no Federal troops in Texas, and fewer than formerly in Louisiana, and Arkansas and Mississippi, as indicative of Federal exhaustion, and consequently giving ground for rebel hope and jubilation; and the London press echoes his boasts, with undisguised satisfaction.

abstract: Messrs. JACOB A. WESTERVELT & SON, of this city, are building for the Pacific Steam Navigation Company, of Liverpool, England, a beautiful side-wheel steamer, to be called the Favorita, and from present appearances, she will probably be one of the fastest steamers of her length ever built in this city. The Favorita is intended for the route of the company on the west coast of South America. Capt. JAS. HALL, one of the company's officers, is here superintending the construction of the vessel. The Favorita is 200 feet long, 30 feet beam, and 9 feet depth of hold. She is being built of the best of material, and will be in every respect a first-class passenger and light-freight steamer. The All[???] Works are building the engines, which have a 56-inch cylinder and 11 feet stroke, and the power that can be developed will certainly tend, with her fine model, to make her a very fast vessel. No pains or expense will be spared to make her as attractive and comfortable as possible for a vessel of her small dimensions to be. The bull is thoroughly iron-strapped on the outside of the frame, the bolts or fastenings all clinched on the inside aide of the timbers. She will have EMERSON's improved patent windlass and some other modern improvements. Capt. HALL, was called to England by the directors of the company for the purposes of having the vessel bunt there. But the builders of all the company's steamers, Messrs. RANDOLPH, ELDER & CO., of Glasgow, having at the time three large steamers of ever 2,000 tons each for the company, beside seven others for other parties, could not undertake to build the Favorita within the time named by the directors, and as the steamer was urgently wanted on her route, the directors decided to have her bunt in this country. The Pacific Steam Navigation Company have, within the fast two years, sent into the Pacific four first-class steamships, all fitted up in the most expensive and comfortable manner, and fitted expressly for the coast trade, and to meet all the requirements of the passenger trafic. These shi[???]s are of the following sizes: Peru, 1,400 tons; Chile, 1,750 tons; Quito, 1,350 tons; Payta, 1,860 tons. The passages made by the above steamers from Liverpool to Valparaiso, were: Peru 35 days; Chile, 33 days; Quito, 36 days; Payta, 31 days. The three large steamers now building on the Clyde for the company will be the finest steamers yet sent into the Pacific. They will have every improvement that can add to comfort or safety, and are guaranteed a speed of 14 knots per hour. These steamers will leave Liverpool in September next. The Favorita will leave this city about first of March, making four more steamers sent out to the coast in less than one year.

abstract: Nearly all the steamers composing that portion of the expedition against Wilmington which was under command of Gen. BUTLER have returned to Fortress Monroe. The Santiago de Cuba and Fort Jackson are the only vessels under the immediate command of Admiral PORTER which have returned from off Wilmington, and the latest advices received from the Admiral represent him as subjecting Fort Fisher to a very severe bombardment.

abstract: Our National flag, alter a lapse of nearly four years, floats over the city of Savannah. It was entered by the advance of Gen. SHERMAN'S army at 4 o'clock A.M. on the 21st instant. GEARY.

abstract: We are not, it seems, to be wholly deprived of music during Mr. MARET[???]K's sojourn in Boston. A new enterprise will at once be inaugurated at Niblo's Saloon. This is nothing else than an opera Buffa. The opening work is "L'Elisir d'Amore." and the Initial effort will be made on Wednesday evening. The establishment is rather small for musical purposes, but it possesses the merit of complete elegance. The various roles will be sustained by Miss LAURA HARRIS, Signor MONGIARDINI, Signor ARDAVANI and Signor FELLINI, whilst the orchestra will be conducted by Signor ROSA.

abstract: French Canadians on St Albans Raiders
snippet: French Canadians on St Albans Raiders
lead_paragraph: -- It is a noteworthy fact that there is all but entire unanimity among the French of opposite parties in Lower Canada as to the right of the St. Albans robbers to a safe asylum in the Province. We publish to-day an article from the leading French newspaper of Montreal, which illustrates this perversion of sentiment in a very direct way. It is to the same partiality for the rebels that their discharge by COURSOL (himself a French Canadian) is attributed, and it is this likewise, we are assured, that has protected the Montreal Chief of Police from a criminal prosecution by his employers for fraud and conspiracy.

abstract: The patriotism, the gratitude and the good sense of the citizens of New-York, was displayed in a becoming manner on Saturday, in the presentation of a substantial testimonial to the great naval hero of the age, Vice-Admiral FARRAGUT. It was resolved about two weeks ago, to present him with some token of the regard and high estimation in which he was held by the community; and, in accordance with a suggestion from the TIMES, the committee having the matter in charge, determined to make the gift a useful and practicably valuable testimonial, which the recipient could enjoy in his lifetime, and hand down to his descendants in perpetuity. In pursuance of this plan, the munificent sum of $50,000 was collected by voluntary contribution in the short space of ten days; the last dollar being subscribed on Thursday. The money was then invested in United States Seven-thirty bonds, and the Admiral was invited to meet the committee yesterday morning at the Custom-house.
lead_paragraph: The patriotism, the gratitude and the good sense of the citizens of New-York, was displayed in a becoming manner on Saturday, in the presentation of a substantial testimonial to the great naval hero of the age, Vice-Admiral FARRAGUT. abstract: North and South; Men of the North and of the South
snippet: North and South; Men of the North and of the South
lead_paragraph: The difference between democracy and aristocracy in their influence on the character and resources of the communities which live under them respectively, has been remarkably illustrated by the progress of the war. When hostilities began, the South was ready at all points. A leader of great ability and audacity was at once found in JEFFERSON DAVIS, and unanimously elected to head the revolution. Half a dozen Generals of very high reputation also came to the front -- LEE, JACKSON, BEAUREGARD, the two JOHNSTONS, BRAGG, as well as others. Large armies were brought rapidly into the field in every direction, and confronted the National troops on every field. There was an abundant supply, too, of very good regimental officers, accustomed to command, and with a sense of self-respect and of social superiority, which were extremely useful in establishing and enforcing discipline. Europe was flooded with Southern diplomatists, official and unofficial, familiar with foreign languages and with foreign usages, with winning manners, great tact and adaptability.
headline: {'main': 'The Men of the South and the Men of the North.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Men of the South and the Men of the North.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SHOOTING IN A LAGER-BIER SALOON. -- At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning CASPER H. HINES, who is otherwise known as "HICKS, the Pirate," quarreled with CHARLES OPPERMANN, keeper of a lager-bier saloon in Tenth-avenue, near Forty-third-street, and at length HICKS fired upon the landlord, but missed aim. He then fled to the street, but again fired from the sidewalk, and CHRISTIAN SCHLEMMER, one of the bystanders, received in his breast a bullet, which entered beyond the reach of a probe. HICKS was taken into custody by Officers ROBERTS and COTRELL, and taken to the Yorkville Police Court, where he was committed by Justice DODGE. SCHLEMMER's wound was dressed by Dr. GRAHAM, and he was subsequently taken home, where he lay, yesterday, in a critical condition.

abstract: -- The Richmond Examiner, of Friday last, seeks to take comfort from the condition of the roads, in forming its estimate of the dangers which threaten the rebel capital. It places its rellance mainly upon Eastern Virginia mud, and predicts a suspension of hostilities in that quarter till May. This augury is hopeful enough for a journalist writing from the heart of a beleagured city. But we take it that it leaves out of account the great risk of the mud drying up at sundry joints where the communications and supplies of Richmond are likely to be cut off long before May day. The prediction of the Richmond journal, in short, looks exceedingly like on attempt to withdraw attention from some projected movement of LEE's, having in view precisely this question of keeping his communications open.

abstract: CORONERS' INQUESTS.--On Saturday afternoon Capt. SMITH, of the sloop Intrepid, found in the dock at the foot of West Thirty-ninth street a body which is supposed to be that of Mr. C.C. BOWLES, late a boarder at the Hoffman House. Under a permit from
lead_paragraph: CORONERS' INQUESTS. -- On Saturday afternoon Capt. SMITH, of the sloop Intrepid, found in the dock at the foot of West Thirty-ninth street a body which is supposed to be that of Mr. C.C. BOWLES, late a boarder at the Hoffman House. Under a permit from one of the Coroners, the Twentieth Precinct Police took the corpse to Bellevue Hospital, and there an inquest was held yesterday. Relatives may find at the Tweniieth Precinct Police Station articles which were taken from the body .... LEWIS STEHLY, a youth of 10 years, who was employed in SMITH's confectionery, at No. 154 Greenwich-street, accidenta lly fell through an open batch on the fourth floor, and when taken from the basement was found to have sustained mortal injuries. He died on Saturday evening, at his parents' abode, No. 98 Ridge-street. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest.... On Saturday evening, Mr. A.W. SATERLEE, of No. 122 Bergen-street, Brooklyn, slipped and fell while descending a staircase leading to a Broadway concert-saloon. He was unconscious when taken up, and while officers were taking him to the New-York Hospital he died. An inquest was held by Coroner GAMBLE.

abstract: Imports Foreign Merchandise, 1864; California Gold Received in New-York, 1864; Progress of Country During Civil War; From California, 1864
snippet: Imports Foreign Merchandise, 1864; California Gold Received in New-York, 1864; Progress of Country During Civil War; From California, 1864
lead_paragraph: One of the most striking and gratifying facts in connection with the civil war which prevails, has been, during its process, the progress of the Northern States in population, in wealth, in commerce and manufactures, and in that peculiar development which is alone characteristic of the American people. And all this progress has been made with one-half of the country, with all its resources and trade suddenly cut off from the other, and while the North has constantly maintained a million of men in the field, has created a vast navy, has put in a complete state of defence a frontier line of many thousand miles, and has made steady and rapid advance in restoring the authority of the central Government over the whole of our wide domain.

abstract: Beauregard not Directing Hood's Movements
snippet: Beauregard not Directing Hood's Movements
lead_paragraph: -- It has hitherto been supposed that the strategy and movements of HOOD were in part subject to the control of BEAUREGARD. The conclusion, however, was not drawn inferentially from the results achieved by the rebel Commander in Tennessee. Most people, indeed, were agreed that such results could only be due to one military genius, and that genius, HOOD. But during the early part of December, it was sedulously given out by most of the southwestern as well as the Richmond rebel journals, that BEAUREGARD was moving mysteriously by HOOD's side, of slightly in his rear; that the inspiration of the great rebel Engineer was continually available for the purposes of the invasion, and that the campaign would be made an assured success by the general superintendence of a military master spirit. One Georgia sheet, we believe, did admit that BEAUREGARD was at Macon on the 30th of November. But that left it open to be inferred, that he might be hovering around there to dash upon SHERMAN's rear, and strike out toward Atlanta and Chattanooga in cooperating with HOOD.

abstract: London Times, >amp;c, on President Lincoln's Message; Message; English Press on
snippet: London Times, >amp;c, on President Lincoln's Message; Message; English Press on
lead_paragraph: American affairs -- more especially the President's message -- receive great attention at the hands of the English press. The fact that Mr. LINCOLN repudiates the idea of negotiation and urges continued war had the effect of animating the Liverpool Cotton market, and causing an advance in prices. It also imported more buoyancy to the Manchester market -- while in the London Stock Exchange the financial statement was regarded as unfavorable, and caused a slight general decline in American Securities.

abstract: Annual Renting Pews
snippet: Annual Renting Pews
lead_paragraph: Plymouth Church was well filled last evening with an audience who had assembled to attend the auction sales of the various pews and aisle seats of the church for the coming year. At about 7:30 o'clock Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, Pastor of the church, briefly addressed the audience. He said he wished to congratulate and offer the compliments of the season to all present, and particularly to congratulate those who should be so fortunate as to secure the seats they wished, and to sympathize and condole with those who failed in so doing. Some dissatisfaction had been expressed by a few at this manner of disposing of the seats, but he thought it the only fair way thus to dispose of them in public, before all who cared to attend, and by so doing giving an equal chance to all to secure their favorite seats. It was the intention of the Board of Trustees that one third of the best seats of the house, should pay at least two-thirds of the expenses of the house, so that the poorer members of the congregation might secure seats at the other end of the list, at prices within their reach. For years past through the generosity of the congregation this desirable result had been accomplished, and he hoped the same generosity would be again extended. He then introduced the Auctioneer, Mr. PITTSBURY, who immediately commenced the sale of the pews.

abstract: The Senate was organized yesterday, Lieut.-Gov. THOS. G. ALVORD taking the Chair, and making a brief and pertinent address to the Senators. The Senate at once proceeded to business. Among the bills introduced were the following: To incorporate the Union League Club of New-York; to fix the compensation of members of the New-York Common Council; to forbid the payment of local bounties; to amend the Soldiers' Voting Law; to authorize the construction of a ship canal from Cayuga Lake to Lake Ontario; to provide for the appointment of Inspectors and Canvassers in the city of New-York. A resolution of thanks to our leading army and naval officers was laid over. The Governor's Message was read and 4,000 copies ordered printed. A report was read by Mr. FOLGER, giving the contested seat in the Ninth District to A.S. Low.

abstract: The steamship New-York, From Southampton Dec. 31, and the Etna, from Liverpool Dec. 21 and Queenstown Dec. 22, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing four days later news. The President's Message had been received and printed, and variously commented on by the English press. Parliament would meet early in February. The coiling of the new Atlantic cable on board the ship Amethyst was proceeding. CHARLES COUTI, the Corsican, had been appointed private secretary to the French Emperor. The Ministerial crisis in Spain has come to an end. All efforts to form another ministry have failed. The Pope had issued a bull condemning all modern religious and political errors having a tendency hostile to the Catholic Church, and exhorting the Bishops to confute them. The bull was signed on the 8th of October last.

abstract: Message
snippet: Message
lead_paragraph: Gov. FENTON's Message to the Legislature of New-York is exceedingly comprehensive. And the space it covers -- although large -- will scarcely be considered inordinate, when the importance of the questions which the Governor takes under review are carefully noted. The great social problems involved in our public charitable institutions necessarily occupy a considerable portion of the Message. And the Governor's statements, especially in regard to the large body of our insane population, now in a great measure uncared for, cannot fail to excite a deep feeling which ought to find practical expression by an immediate legislative provision. We are apt to forget, in comparing the liberality of the annual appropriations for charitable institutes in this country, with similar appropriations in other countries, that a large proportion of the benefactions which go to maintain the aged, the imbecile and the disabled in older communities, are the result of private and special bequests. Many years must elapse before the same class of charitable foundations -- many of them laid centuries ago -- can come into account here as great auxilliaries of the State. We must, therefore, be prepared to hear the painful statement that, outside of this city and its great suburb on the East River, there are between thirteen and fourteen hundred lunatics, growing more helpless in their misery each day, by reason of the inadequate provision made for their sustenance and relief. Attentive regard must also be paid to Gov. FENTON's report of the increased demand made upon the charitable appropriations of the State, by the daily increasing population of military invalids which the war has thrown back upon our benevolence. The State has given its sons by the hundred thousand to the national service, and whatever may be the national provision made for the invalided, New-York cannot afford to see their wants unsupplied, where the pension fund may require to be supplemented.

abstract: The and Our Brazilian Relations; Florida Case
snippet: The and Our Brazilian Relations; Florida Case
lead_paragraph: The handsome apology made by Secretary SEWARD to Brazil, for the capture of the Florida in its waters, the ordering of Capt. COLLINS to a court-martial, the dismissal of the Consul at Bahia from his post, are acts which ought to make every American prouder of his Government. They attest to the world that the United States, in spite of all its hard trials and sore provocations, yet holds firm to its old character, as the nation preeminently respecting international law.

abstract: N Y; Gov Fenton's Proclamation to Fill Quota; Appeals to People on Quota; Gov Fenton's Proc on Draft; New-York, Proclamation on Raising Quota
snippet: N Y; Gov Fenton's Proclamation to Fill Quota; Appeals to People on Quota; Gov Fenton's Proc on Draft; New-York, Proclamation on Raising Quota
lead_paragraph: The President of the United States has issued his proclamation dated the 20th day of December, 1864, calling on the people of the respective States for three hundred thousand recruits. These men are needed to strengthen the gallant armies now administering such effective blows to the rebellion, to assist those who are so fearlessly risking their lives for the life of the nation, to aid GRANT and SHERMAN, SHERIDAN and THOMAS, FARRAGUT and PORTER, in securing the fruits of the victories they have so bravely won. We cannot allow the enemies of the republic to triumph now, when they are so nearly vanquished, -- when each successive assault is resulting so auspiciously to the cause of the Union and so disastrously to that of its adversaries. The war for its preservation must continue until the last enemy of the national supremacy shall be subdued. In the great contest in which the nation is unhappily involved, New-York has not been behind her sister States in earnest efforts and sacrifices; she will not be now. I do earnestly invite the people of this State to exercise the utmost diligence in filling the quota, which may be assigned them under the call of the President. Believing ourselves to be inspired by the same lofty sentiments of patriotism which animated our fathers, in founding our free institutions, let us continue to imitate their bright example of courage, endurance and faithfulness to principles in maintaining them. Let us be patient and persevere! Let there be a rally of the people in every city, village and town! Let all true patriots vie with each other in efforts to make up the numbers which may be required, so that when the 15th day of February arrives, our quota shall be completely filled, and by men who will be anxious, not to avoid the discharge of a solemn duty, but to participate in the closing of the great struggle, which is to result in settling the destinies of this Government upon a foundation firm as truth and righteousness.

abstract: Militia Draft resisted in Montmorenci; French Canadian Sympathy with; Resistance to Militia Draft in; French Canadian Sympathizers Resisting Draft
snippet: Militia Draft resisted in Montmorenci; French Canadian Sympathy with; Resistance to Militia Draft in; French Canadian Sympathizers Resisting Draft
lead_paragraph: -- Our Quebec advices of last evening are of lively interest. The French Canadians in the old District of Montmorenci are in arms against the local Government, in resistance to the militia draft for the maintenance of order on the frontier. It appears that nearly the whole French Canadian population sympathize with the raiders; that they are determined that the St. Albans gang shall escape justice, and that they will resist all attempts to coerce the habitans into service for the assertion of the Provincial municipal laws as against those who call themselves Confederates, whatever their character otherwise may be.

abstract: State Quota; Governor's Appeal to People
snippet: State Quota; Governor's Appeal to People
lead_paragraph: It is refreshing to read the appeals of Gov. FENTON to the patriotism of the Empire State. For two dreary years we have heard no such language. Nothing has been heard from the Executive Chamber at Albany in support of the war but cold, measured, perfunctory words. The only earnestness has been reserved for efforts to destroy the confidence of the people in the administration of the Government. All the influence which has emanated from that high position has gone to depress the popular spirit and unnerve the public arm. But now we hear a voice that stirs the blood like a trumpet -- a voice that not only summons every man in the State to his duty, but animates him with a spirit to go straight on in its performance. The glad sense is brought home to all the true patriots of the State that they now have a leader worthy of the cause.

abstract: Privateers ordered by Juarez

lead_paragraph: The steamship Asia, from Liverpool, via Queenstown, Dec. 25, arrived at Halifax yesterday morning, bringing three days later news from Europe. The Shipping Gazette says that advices from Nantes confirm the report that JUAREZ had issued letters-of-marque to Americans against French ships. The Army and Navy Gazette takes a very appreciative view of Gen. SHERMAN's march. The Pope has replied to the rebel manifesto, and expressed himself in favor of peace. VICTOR EMANUEL has decreed the occupation of convents in Florence for the service of the State. The Queen of Spain, in her speech to the Cortes, admits that the general condition of the monarchy is not satisfactory. The majority of the Polish prisoners on trial at Berlin have been acquitted.

abstract: The steamship Fulton, from Port Royal Jan. 1, arrived at this port yesterday morning, bringing news from Savannah to Dec. 31. The city was perfectly quiet and the best feeling prevailed. Gen. SAFRMAN had reviewed his entire army by corps, and was vigorously preparing for another offensive movement.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Fulton, from Port Royal Jan. 1, arrived at this port yesterday morning, bringing news from Savannah to Dec. 31. The city was perfectly quiet and the best feeling prevailed. Gen. SAFRMAN had reviewed his entire army by corps, and was vigorously preparing for another offensive movement. He had issued a very judicious order with reference to the government of the city, which authorized the Fire Department, the water and gas companies, to continue their operations as usual, guards being furnished for their protection when necessary. Trade was reviving, and the docks once more presented a busy appearance. The obstructions in Savannah River were being rapidly removed by the navy. An important meeting of the citizens of Savannah was held on Dec. 28, presided over by the Major, at which resolutions were passed expressing a desire to accept the terms of the amnesty proclamation of the President, and promising a faithful return to their allegiance. The call for the meeting was signed by many of the prominent citizens of Savannah. Measures are being taken to procure a supply of food from the North for the destitute families of Savannah.

abstract: NIBLO'S SALOON. A company, styling itself the Italian Opera Buffa, commenced a "season" here last evening.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's SALOON. -- A company, styling itself the Italian Opera Buffa, commenced a "season" here last evening. There is no reason why such an enterprise should not succeed. Light opera is pleasant at any establishment except the Academy of Music, where the conditions of its performance render pleasure almost impossible. It is, perhaps, going to the other extreme to anticipate it at Niblo's Saloon. In that not over-large apartment, mimic life is colossal. An ordinary individual becomes a giant and a chorus a crowd. This, however, has, in a measure, been overcome by M. JUIGNET's French artists. Their natural tact and knowledge have enabled them to accommodate themselves to a limited sphere of operations. We cannot say the same for the members of the Italian Opera Buffa. Although this description of work requires the best of acting, it was obvious, last evening, that most of the artists were at least inexperienced, and better disposed to look at the audience than to consult the interchanges and necessities of the scene. We do not propose to criticise the performance in a musical point of view. The artists were evidently laboring under indisposition, and it would be unjust to suppose that they did their best. There was a small but good orchestra, which accomplished its object satisfactorily. The chorus was as large as the stage could accommodate, but it did not by any means accommodate itself to the stage. For its numbers, it was as bad as could be expected. We hope, on some future occasion, to say more of a speculation which, if successfully conducted, would add to the enjoyments of city life. The cast of the of the opera last evening was as follows: Adnia, Mme. CAVIOLI; Nemorino, Signor MONGIARDINI; Dulcamara, Signor ARDAVNI; Belcore, Signor FELLINI; Gianella, Mme. PICKANESER. It will be repeated on Friday.

abstract: Lazarus Murder; Inquest
snippet: Lazarus Murder; Inquest
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, afternoon, Officer DWYER, of the Twenty-third Precinet, assisted by Officers PORCHER and MOLD, of the Twelfth, found, in a lager-bier saloon, in Third-avenue, near One Hundred and Seventeenth-street, BARNEY FRIERY, the murderer of HENRY LAZARUS, and JAMES McDONALD and JAMES CLARK, the persons who were with him at the time of the murder. The officers held their prisoners until nightfall, and, under instructions from the Coroner, lodged them in cells at Police Headquarters, in Mulberry-street, to await further developments.

abstract: Both branches of the Legislature have proceeded promptly to business. In the Senate, yesterday, notice was given of bills to incorporate a paid Fire Department in New-York; to improve and build the wall for the protection of the Battery in New-York; to facilitate the construction of the West Shore Railroad in County; to provide for submitting to the people the constitutional amendment for the appointment of Commissioners of Appeals; to amend the laws designating legal holidays. Among the bills introduced was one to provide for filling the quota of the State by paying a State bounty of $600, $400 and $200 for three, two and one year's men. The paying of local bounties is prohibited. To incorporate the Union League Club of New-York. Mr. LAIMBEER introduced a resolution appointing Senators MUNGER, WHITE and HUMPHREY a committee to examine and investigate the affairs and management of the several city department of the Government of New-York City, which was tabled. Adjourned.

abstract: Weitzel's Gen. Judgment as to Strength of Fort Fisher; The Failure to Capture; Attacks Compared; Naval Reporter, Arrest of for Contraband Publication
snippet: Weitzel's Gen. Judgment as to Strength of Fort Fisher; The Failure to Capture; Attacks Compared; Naval Reporter, Arrest of for Contraband Publication
lead_paragraph: The attempt upon Wilmington has failed and everybody is disappointed. Disappointed, because, like ripe fruit, the works were expected to fall into our hands with the first shake of the tree. Disappointed, because no such naval force was ever before sent from a Northern port. Disappointed, in fact, because everything was hoped for -- nothing apprehended or anticipated that could stay the fast-running current of our late good fortunes. But we have learned to accept these disappointments with equanimity and patience -convinced that the fruit will duly ripen as the days pass by, until it may even fall to the ground without a shake.

abstract: There may be some reason to question the truth of the report, which we publish this morning, respecting the issue of letters-of-marque by JUAREZ, the President of Mexico. The news comes from Europe by the Asia, through the London Shipping Gazette. The story was told in a less circumstantial form, several weeks ago. But now, we have it positively asserted that President JUAREZ "has issued letters-of-marque to Americans against French ships, and especially against the steamers of the French Transatlantic Company." To this is added the statement that one of these steamers was convoyed from Vera Cruz by a French man-of-war, as a protection against the expected Mexican cruisers.
lead_paragraph: There may be some reason to question the truth of the report, which we publish this morning, respecting the issue of letters-of-marque by JUAREZ, the President of Mexico. But now, we have it positively asserted that President JUAREZ "has issued letters-of-marque to Americans against French ships, and especially against the steamers of the French Transatlantic Company." To this is added the statement that one of these steamers was convoyed from Vera Cruz by a French man-of-war, as a protection against the expected Mexican cruisers.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. in addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Rebel Pictures of and the Facts; Libels on North vs Aid to Savannah
snippet: Rebel Pictures of and the Facts; Libels on North vs Aid to Savannah
lead_paragraph: The movement to relieve the suffering people of Savannah deserves the support of every patriotic and every humane man. The simple statement of Gen. SHERMAN is proof enough that great need exists. The military authorities are doing what they well can to to abate it, but their available means are very limited. Something will be realized from the shipments of rice made by the municipal authorities of Savannah to be exchanged for other articles of food. But much will yet remain to be supplied from other sources. It is an opportunity which not only appeals to every Christian feeling, but which can be turned to most excellent advantage.

abstract: At the beginning of the war the patriotic devotion of our young men carried many a one into the army whom prudential considerations might with great propriety have restrained. Thousands, too, left lucrative employments to volunteer, and were cheered and applauded by the w[???] country. It was not supposed, however, that every position could remain open or the business interests of the country stand still until they should return. Where a good clerk or mechanic enlisted the merchant or manufacturer filled his place with a poorer one and went on as before. Now when the volunteer returns a veteran he finds his old place occupied. He has not been improving his condition pe[???]y, and, perhaps, he has left on some bloody [???] an eye, or hand, or foot; vet at home every one has been pushing ahead and growing itch. His army experience, perhaps, has made a better man of him. The hardships of the march have made old discomforts appear light. The early [???] and regular exercises of the camp have to [???] and disciplined his character. He has learned to obey orders, and perform disagreeable tasks with [???]rity. Yet this very training has unfitted him to push his own way; he is disposed to wait for orders, and not to march till the command be given. Perhaps, [???]o, he is one of the unfortunate maimed and disabled, and thus a sensitiveness -- a feeling of helplessness -- oppresses and unmans. He finds his old [???]ion gone; he has to begin again. He is loaded with all the disadvantages of youth, with none of its hope and buoyancy.

Thousands, too, left lucrative employments to volunteer, and were cheered and applauded by the w[???] country. It was not supposed, however, that every position could remain open or the business interests of the country stand still until they should return. Where a good clerk or mechanic enlisted the merchant or manufacturer filled his place with a poorer one and went on as before. Now when the volunteer returns a veteran he finds his old place occupied. He has not been improving his condition pe[???]y, and, perhaps, he has left on some bloody [???] an eye, or hand, or foot; vet at home every one has been pushing ahead and growing itch. His army experience, perhaps, has made a better man of him. The hardships of the march have made old discomforts appear light. The early [???] and regular exercises of the camp have to [???] and disciplined his character. He has learned to obey orders, and perform disagreeable tasks with [???]rity. Yet this very training has unfitted him to push his own way; he is disposed to wait for orders, and not to march till the command be given. Perhaps, [???]o, he is one of the unfortunate maimed and disabled, and thus a sensitiveness -- a feeling of helplessness -- oppresses and unmans. abstract: In the Senate yesterday petitions were offered from citizens of Ohio, asking for the passage of Mr. CHANDLER'S resolution to orangize a corps for the protection of the northern frontier, and from officers of the army and navy, asking for increased compensation.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday petitions were offered from citizens of Ohio, asking for the passage of Mr. CHANDLER'S resolution to orangize a corps for the protection of the northern frontier, and from officers of the army and navy, asking for increased compensation. A resolution was offered and adopted asking for information from the Secretary of War in regard to naval credits. A resolution was adopted to inquire into the expediency of appropriating the proceeds of the sale of cotton capcaptured at Savannah to the benefit of Gen. SHERMAN's army. Mr. WILSON's resolution, to free the families of neGro soldiers, was debated but not acted on. The bill to permit aliens who have served one year in the army to become citizens of the United States was called up and an amendment offered by Mr. SHERMAN, pending the consideration of which the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Infringements of; Respect for Courts of Law
snippet: Infringements of; Respect for Courts of Law
lead_paragraph: -- We published, a few mornings since, a report of the Punishment of several persons by the United States Circuit Court in this city, for violation of the injunction of the court against infringements upon the sewing-machine patents. The punishments in those cases were not very severe, but in a similar case which we published on Tuesday, the court felt itself called upon to inflict a much more serious penalty. The infringer was sent to prison for thirty days, and, besides, ordered to pay a fine of $1,000, and be imprisoned until he paid it, or till the court should otherwise order.

abstract: American Confederation Scheme Approved by British Government; Mr Cardwell's dispatch to Lord Monck
snippet: American Confederation Scheme Approved by British Government; Mr Cardwell's dispatch to Lord Monck
lead_paragraph: -- We publish, to-day, Mr. CARDWELL's dispatch announcing the approval, by the Imperial Government, of the British-American Union scheme in its general features. Mr. CARDWELL, taking his cue from the comments of the New-York TIMES, points out to the Governor-General of the Colonies that their proposal to constitute a second Legislative Chamber by nomination of the Crown, limited as to the number of members, will not work harmoniously with the elective Chamber. Otherwise, the scheme is commended. The Colonial Secretary pledges the whole influence of the Government to secure the passage of the necessary measures to give the new Colonial Constitution effect.

abstract: George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. There was a large attendance in court yesterday, to hear the argument of counsel. Judge Pierrepont, on opening his remarks, paid a tribute to the court and jury.
lead_paragraph: George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. -- There was a large attendance in court yesterday, to hear the argument of counsel. Judge Pierrepont, on opening his remarks, paid a tribute to the court and jury. It is with sorrow that any right-minded man feels himself compelled to prosecute his fellow-man for crime of any kind. But there comes a time in the life of every man when he must choose between being a coward for his ease, or a brave man for the right. This controversy is the culmination of a feud of somewhat ancient date. As you have seen from the evidence quoted from the libels themselves, as well as from other evidence in the case, Mr. Weed was the party upon whom the attack first was made. He was assailed as "the father of the lobby," the "corrupter of public morals," the "contriver of various corrupt schemes," a "coarse fellow," as engaged in the fraudulent charter of the steamer Cataline, all which, and much more, was reiterated in the public newspapers, barking and snapping continually, until Old Thurlow turns, and with one snap of his whip sends his assailant whining to a court of justice, in search of a greenback plaster to cover his smarting wounds. Is that a manly way in which to act, when worsted in a political feud? But this cause involves a higher question; a question of public morality; a question of political responsibility. Whether the corruptions of men in office can be exposed; the freedom of the press, the greatest question that ever came before the world -- whether our free institutions shall continue, or corruption shall destroy them, and liberty perish from off the of the earth. This, gentlemen, is a time of civil war, and do you suppose there can be a great civil war which will not shake the great foundations of the nation? The war on battle-fields, will, in a few months, be over; but the war of ideas has just begun; and when the bells shall ring in the joyful news of peace, beware lest they ring in a peace without liberty. The charge which the court shall give you will be of more moment than the order any Major-General has issued; and your verdict will be vaster in its consequences than the issue of any battle. The instinct of the people tells them so; and even the march of Sherman and the stack on Wilmington were not able to direct the attention of the people from this issue. It has even excited the attention of the religious community, so much so that it has been spoken of in the churches. [The counsel was about to read a report of some pulpit remarks, when Mr. Field interposed, and it was ruled out as irregular.] Gentlemen, the counsel for the plaintiff has stated in your presence that the World newspaper was sued for the same libel, and the damages are laid at $50,-000, the same sum that Mr. Weed is sued for; so that, it successful, Mr. Opdyke will make money by these suits almost as fast as out of his secret contract with the Government, or out of Mariposa stock, or out of his fraudulent gun claim on the city. In Mariposa it is shown he did not invest a dollar, and he has made $800,000 or $900,000. Now sane men do not act without motive. Perhaps personal feeling had something to do with it; but the great motive for this suit was the love of money. If not for the sake of money, why drag Mr. Weed into a civil court, instead of having him punished in a criminal court? Let these suits prevail, and tell me how much of civil liberty the people have left? Counsel went into a consideration of the wrongs often unavoidably committed on the liberty of individuals in a time of civil war. The tree of liberty is not growing very vigorously just now. Give a verdict which will muzzle the press, and you will find next year it is dead. You may water it with your tears, but it will not survive. This is a public question. Is it not right to expose the frauds of men in public places? If it is right to expose them, then it is wrong that Mr. Weed should be punished for ex posing them. He ought to have a monument, rather. The only tribunal before whom such offenders can be brought, is that of public opinion; and the only instrument we can use is the public press. Will you destroy that? The question has been asked a thousand times: "How dare Mr. Opdyke bring this suit?" Why, the evidence was all his own, in his own possession; the witnesses we had to call were in his interest; Mr. Blunt was his friend; he did not believe the thing could be proved; and it is a miracle that they have been proved, and more than proved. He did not think he ran any risk. But when a man is engaged in a fraud, he always runs a risk, and sooner or later it will be revealed. Now, I call your attention to the first part of the article complained of as libelous. "Mr, Opdyke may enlarge the field of inquiry and look into this alleged sale of the Surveyorship of the port of New-York." Suppose there was no truth in this statement, taken in connection with what precedes, ought there to have been a suit about it? But it is true, in substance and in fact; and if one of the parties did cheat a little, by keeping back part of the price, it does not alter the fact of the sale. When this suit was brought, gentlemen, the plaintiff must have had in mind the old saying: "The greater the truth the greater the libel." But his friend Orison Blunt, who is a lawyer, should have informed him better -- that there has been no change in the law -- that the old adage does not prevail -- and that when a man has proved the truth of the libel, he is protected. Counsel went into a review of the testimony on this point. Could it be believed that McNeil, who had been a member of the Legislature, had been engaged in political life, and a friend of Mr. Opdyke, had concocted all the story which he related. As a counterfeit bill was detected by its appearance, so could the jury tell by the manner of a witness on the stand, whether he was telling the truth. McNeill was the friend of Mr. Opdyke, and desired his election as Mayor. Mr. Andrews was also his friend, and himself was looking for the Surveyorship. What more natural than that he should go to McNeil and tell him he wanted Opdyke's influence -- that he wanted him to drop Stanton and support him? McNeil says. "How will it be to Mr. Opdyke's interest?" Andrews replies, "I will have $10,000 collected in the Custom-house to help his election as Mayor." McNeil reports this to Opdyke next day. Opdyke seems contented with it, but says, "Will he not cheat you?" "I think not," says McNeil, "but pick your man and we will go and meet him, and have the thing fixed." Says Opdyke, "Suppose you take Amos J. Williamson?" Agreed. Next day they see Andrews; make an appointment in an eating-house on 5th July, in a private room, where Andrews says there was a "spread." How happened there to be a "spread?" The bargain is there made. Both McNeill and Williamson tell you the same thing; that when they sat down McNeil says, "Well, Andrews, let us go to business." That Andrews entered into the arrangement; when leaving McNeil says to Williamson "Are you satisfied?" he being Opdyke's picked man. He says he is satisfied. That they went to Opdyke, who expressed himself satisfied. Do you think they have both contrived this story? Andrews, after he gets the office, thanks McNeil and Williamson both for aiding him. Had Williamson and McNeil any motive to be false in this narration? You cannot conceive of any. Go to the Custom-house and see what they do to carry out that bargain. Mr. Barney says he never heard of any money being raised in the Custom-house on a Mayoralty election before this. No one ever did. Federal officers do not hold under the Mayor. Why was this assessment made? It was made to carry out the arrangement between Andrews and Opdyke. Barney tells you he was opposed to the whole thing. He had no knowledge of this secret contract between Andrews and Opdyke, to assess the Custom-house for $10,000. And what kind of a thing was that for George Opdyke, a man of great wealth, to enter into? to get $10,000 out of the poor laboring clerks of the Custom-house; to do what? to make him Mayor of the City of New-York. In Heaven's name, if he wanted to be Mayor of the city, why not pay the expenses oat of his own money -- money got out of the Government and his vast trade. You are told it was all "voluntary." Of course it was very voluntary. A circular issued by the head of the department. Ah! if any of you were a clerk in the Custom-house, you would find out what a "voluntary" subscription means. If it is not responded to, it will not be long before you receive a "voluntary" note, stating "voluntarily" that your services will be no longer required. Yes, Mr. Opdyke "may enlarge the field of inquiry, so as to embrace the alleged sale of the office of Surveyor of the port of New-York." We have made a brief examination of it, and find it pretty satisfactory. Counsel reviewed the testimony of Mr. Andrews himself, as, on close inspection, tending to show the truth of the matter he sought to deny. The next libel was in relation to the Mariposa estate; that Opdyke, Ketchum and Hoy obtained $2,400,000. The fact proved was, that they received $2,500,000. No one of them but Mr. Opdyke had sued for libel, when Mr. Fremont was asked whether any advantage was taken of him, his answer was: "Any unfair advantage? I (hesitating) think not." The business was urgent, the pressure was great, and he wisely took his hand out of the lion's mouth. Gen. Fremont was willing to give two and a half millions to adjust difficulties, and Opdyke and the other gentlemen got each $800,000 or $900,000 for nothing. Mr. Fremont was required to give, in addtion to his first agreement, $700,000, out of which Mr. Field got his counsel fees, and then to give a proxy for a large amount of his own stocks, and at last to sell 5,000 shares at $25 a share, when it was worth about double in the market. Then Fremont commenced an action about $180,000 of bonds, which he afterward adjusted. The next libel was in regard to secret partnerships. It was proved that he made $172,000 out of one batch in a very few months. William Churchill sold to Opkyke three distinct contracts with the Government for clothing, for which Opdyke paid him 12 1/2 cents per coat. Churchill could not get the goods except of Opdyke. Mr. Spaulding sold Opdyke a quantity of cloth which was so bad, as the plaintiff claimed, that it would not take an indigo blue dye, but somehow or other they did "work it in." Then there was the contract with the State for military clothing. Mr. Carhart produced a list of contracts in his own name, amounting to $4,600,000, in which Opdyke was interested and at the same time surety, making as his share $172,000. In September, 1863, Opdyke says it was true that he had no contracts in the present tense. But when a man states "equally ungrounded is the charge that I have any interest in Government contracts; I have none direct or indirect, and they exist only in Mr. Weed's imagination," do you not understand that he means I have had no contracts? In regard to the guns, if there was a [???]aud in presenting the claim. It was to be laid to the charge of the Mayor of the city in 1863. It was hoped that a wealthy Mayor would be proof against corruption. But we find him secretely interested in contracts. Instead of guarding the City Treasury he took money illegally from the city and pocketed it. Opdyke went into a contract for making guns, a hazardous business, with which he was entirely unacquainted. Marston, who is making them, requires more and more money, until Opdyke advances $65,000. Then Opdyke buys out the establishment in the name of Farley. He was then willing to get out of the business at a loss of $10,000 or $20,000. At length his advances amounted to $185,000, when he said he would be willing to sell out at a loss of $25,000 or $30,000. Then came the destruction of the armory. A great effort had been made to show that Opdyke did not connive at the destruction of his establishment. No such charge had been made in the opening. The only thing that he (Mr. Pierrepont) said, was that when it was found that the factory was going to be destroyed, the plaintiff felt very quiet about it, knowing that the city would have to pay for it, and that his ruinously losing and bankrupt concern would be better paid for by the city. Now all an insurance company would have to pay would be the actual value of the property destroyed, not any prospective profit. While Opdyke was thinking how to make up his claim, Lorein Jones came in and suggested to charge the contract price, less the cost of furnishing the goods, that would protect the patentees and all, Opdyke had been thinking that he might claim what he had paid out; but he says, "he thought that would be highly illegal," so he adopted the suggestion of Jones, by which he gets all he put in, with all the prospective profits beside. That would not be illegal. Now Jones swears that he could duplicate all the machinery and tools for $40,000, thus showing an overcharge of $63,000. The cash-book showed that Jones had told the truth in regard to the matter. Only $15,000 had been received from the Government until the 11th of September, so that the balance of the $28,000 was kept out. The $15,000 balances itself in the books. In making up the account they had to estimate the value of the materials for unfinished guns. The value of the different parts of the guns was proved accurately on this trial. Now if they had put in an exact account of the materials destroyed, it would have reduced the claim $63,000. Supervisor Blunt, who had dismissed, riot claims with a five minutes, hearing, takes up the claim of Opdyke into his own choice keeping, and in a few days he is nominated for Mayor in Opdyke's place. Mr. Fields, on behalf of the Corporation, was not allowed to cross-examine witnesses, or hear the testimony. Supervisor Purdy resigned the very day the claim was passed. Counsel reviewed the testimony of Mr. Farley before the Supervisors, in which he stated that the articles were charged at the prices they cost to make them, and points out several discrepancies in the items as compared with the inventory, among others, $3,000 for the model gun, which cost only $500. The great question for the jury to decide was, whether a man who, in office, had been undertaking to get, by indirection, and by means which the law regards as fraudulent, money out of the city, when he himself was its trustee and guardian, If the jury should say that that was right, then corruption had overridden justice, fraud triumphed over honesty, the day of our destruction was near. Gentlemen, the responsibility that rests upon you is the gravest that has been cast upon you in a lifetime. All I ask is, that you shall do your duty in a way that, when you go out from here, you may feel that you have done right, and may be able to tell your fellow-citizens why it is right.
