abstract: Shenandoah, Description, History and Exploits; Shenandoah and Sea King Identical
snippet: Shenandoah, Description, History and Exploits; Shenandoah and Sea King Identical
lead_paragraph: Capt. S.J. GILMAN, of the Schooner Charter Oak, of and bound to San Francisco, from Boston, called at our office yesterday, and gives us information respecting the capture of his vessel by the rebel pirate Shenandoah, in lat. 7 north, lon. 27 30 west. The Charter Oak had a cargo of coals and hardware, furniture and preserved fruits. On the 5th of November, about 5 A.M., when the wind was very light from the southwest, saw a large ship (looking for all the world like a clipper) astern, which ship the Captain, a half-hour later, discovered was getting up steam and making for the schooner. At 6 A.M. the stranger ran up alongside to the windward, flying the English flag, having fired a gun for him to heave to, which the Charter Oak did, when the steamer ran up the Confederate flag. A small boat with an officer and several men, all armed, then came up alongside, and told Capt. GILMAN that the schooner was a prize to the Confederate States steamer Shenandoah. The Captain and crew were then ordered on board the small boat, and taken to the steamer, the former being allowed to gather up and carry with him his papers, &c. He was conducted to the cabin of the steamer, and introduced to the Captain, WADDELL, who after duly examining his schooner's papers, gravely informed him that nothing could save the schooner, and that after taking what he wanted from her, he should burn her. After removing a few things from the schooner she was set on fire, the pirate remaining in sight until she was dismantled and nearly burned to the water's edge. Capt. GILMAN and his crew remained on the Shenandoah seven days, during which time she burned the bark D. Godfrey, of Boston, Capt. HALLETT, bound to Valparaiso, and sunk the brig Susan, of New-York, bound to Rio Grande, S.A. The course of the Shenandoah was, of course, very erratic; but her principal cruising-ground seems to have been from 26 to 32 W. lon.; it is probable, however, that by this time she has crossed the line, following the Brazil coast, and cutting across to the Cape of Good Hope. (Capt. GILMAN comes to this conclusion from the fact that the pirate-chief took his chart, which was the first and only one he ever had, giving this course, and seemed to be highly delighted at obtaining it.) On the seventh day Capt. GILMAN and his crew were but on board the ship Kate Prince, of Portsmouth, N.H., Capt. H. LIBBY, bound to Bahia or St. Salvador, Brazil, where they arrived on the 23d of November. The Kate Prince was bonded for $40,000, which would seem rather strange were the fact not known that her cargoes (consisting chiefly of coal) was English. Capt. HALLETT, of the bark D. Godfrey, of Boston, and Capt. STAPLES, of the bark Helena, (captured eight days before the Charter Oak,) were put on board a Danish brig and sent to Rio Janeiro. Capt. GILMAN and his crew reached this city on Sunday last, in the bark Grace. His crew was as follows: Zairil Burges, mate; Charles E. Burse, second mate; Jno. M. Sampson, Manuel Tratus, John Eamis and Frank Rogers.

abstract: The skating at the Fifth -- avenue Pond was in a delightful condition yesterday -- affording full enjoyment to the many thousand patrons who visit that pond. A fine band of music was in attendance in the afternoon and evening. Many of the older ones, who were not favored with the privileges of skating in former days, visited the pond in their carriages, and enjoyed the invigorating and healthful Winter sport fully as much as the participators. If the weather continues as favorably as during the present week, the proprietors of the fashionable Winter resort -- Messrs. OATMAN & VAN BARN -- will announce their regular skating carnival for the season.

abstract: Dictatorship Advised by Richmond Examiner
snippet: Dictatorship Advised by Richmond Examiner
lead_paragraph: Several persons have employed themselves lately in preparing statistical tables of the wealth, food, and fighting men, remaining in the Confederacy subject to the command of the Government. They prove conclusively that the amount of all these things is still very great -- enormous -- sufficient to support far greater efforts than the Confederacy has yet made. To question the accuracy of their facts is far from our purpose; indeed their truth has been so long and so well known to all who have examined the subject, that the proof and tabular exposition seem to them quite superfluous, and even uninteresting.

lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Decatur, Ala., dated Jan. 4, says that Gen. STEEDMAN'S cavalry has overtaken HOOD'S pontoon train south of the Tennessee, at Russellville, and had captured it, together with 600 mules, 100 horses and 200 hogs. abstract: NEW-YORK LEADER. -- This popular Democratic weekly enters on Saturday next upon a new volume, under the editorial charge of Mr. S.R. FISK. Mr. CLAPP, who has had charge of the paper since the death of its late p[???]or, has withdrawn for reasons which appear to be sufficiently stated in the following paragraph from the New-York Courier, of Saturday: "We learn that at a meeting of the New-York Leader Association, Mr. S.R. FISK, one of the editors of the New-York Herald, was elected to the responsible post of controlling editor of the former paper. Thereupon, it is said that Mr. HENRY CLAPP, Jr., who has managed that paper admirably since the death of Mr. CLANCY, has resigned his connection with the establishment."

abstract: Walton, J Francis, of New-York
snippet: Walton, J Francis, of New-York
lead_paragraph: -We publish to-day, under the usual head, the death notice of J. FRANCIS WALTON, senior partner of the law firm of Messrs. WALTON, SHERMAN & REDFIELD. The deceased was well known in this city as among our most promising young lawyers. He graduated a few years since at Columbia College with the highest honors, and immediately applied himself to the study of his profession. Steady of purpose, courteous in manner, a thorough scholar, and with a strong ambition to excel in his profession, he has been cut down at the early age of 29 years by consumption. His many friends will read of his death, for it is but a short time since he was among them with the best prospects for a healthy and long future. His remains will be placed in Greenwood from No. 291 Atlantic-street, Brooklyn, on Sunday, at 2 o'clock P.M.

lead_paragraph: Our special correspondent, writing from Huntsville on the 2d inst., says HOOD made his final escape across the Tennessee, at Bainbridge, on the 24th ult. He also gives a very clear resume of the inception, location and result of the late campaign, from which it is clear that Gen. THOMAS is now complete master of the situation. It is believed HOOD will retire upon Meridian, Miss., to reorganize his army. In the meantime, THOMAS is on the alert, and already in motion for a resumption of the campaign from a new point, the direction of which will shortly appear.

abstract: Meteor; New Man-of-War; Trial Trip
snippet: Meteor; New Man-of-War; Trial Trip
lead_paragraph: On Thursday the officers of the navy subjected to trial a splendid man-of-war steamer, built in Boston by R.B. FORBES, Esq., called the Meteor, and the results were highly satisfactory. The ship is of the same size as the larger sloops-of-war of the [???]nderoga class, measuring about 1,400 tons, having a midship cross-section immersed of about 485 square feet. Her boilers are of the horizontal tubular variety, having 204 square feet of grate surface only, without blowers, and the cylinders are 62 1/2 inches in diameter and three feet stroke, with an independent cut-off, cutting off at about one third of the stroke. The safety valves were set so as to blow off at 22 pounds' pressure, and although the boilers were tested up to 53 pounds, the valves could not be loaded heavier on the trial, on account of their location, so that the test had to be made with much less steam than the machine is entitled to carry. The trial was made under the direction of Capt. BOGGS and Chief-Engineer W.W. WOOD, with the assistants, and the ship was run four times over the two measured knots now used as a race course in the lower bay. The result was that a uniform speed of sixty-three revolutions a minute could be maintained on a twenty-three pitch, now driving the ship twelve knots, or fourteen miles an honor; while at the same time the tubes were furnishing more steam at the limited pressure than could be used by the engine. It the pressure had been increased to 35 lbs., as it could have been with a heavier load on the safety valves, the speed would have gone up to about thirteen and a half knots, as the engineer said. Capt. COMSTOCK, who was one of the company, said that it was the fastest time he had ever known made by any propellor on a trial on measured distance, and to all others said: "This is the sort of ship to send after the Shenandoah."
headline: {'main': "Trial Trip of Mr. R.B. Forbes' New Steamship Meteor A Great Success.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Trial Trip of Mr. R.B. Forbes' New Steamship Meteor A Great Success.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: District-Attorney's Office; Loose Action of; Juvenile, Sentenced; Crime and Criminals in New-York
snippet: District-Attorney's Office; Loose Action of; Juvenile, Sentenced; Crime and Criminals in New-York
lead_paragraph: The statistics of crime in this city, as exhibited in the annual report of the Police Commissioners, are well worthy of general consideration; while the vast discrepancy between the number of arrests for high crimes, and the number of convictions for such offences in the courts, is truly alarming. After enumerating seven hundred and forty-two cases of arrest, during the year 1864, for violence against the person, including forty-eight for murder and ten for manslaughter, the Commissioners say: "A small portion of this mass of high crimes has received the punishment provided by the laws. The fault, if any exist, is somewhere beyond the power of the police."

abstract: their Annual Record; Ohio and Massachusetts Annual State Record
snippet: their Annual Record; Ohio and Massachusetts Annual State Record
lead_paragraph: -- THEIR ANNUAL STATE RECORD. -- With the exception of New-York, there are, probably, no States in the Union that have shown a more patriotic record than Ohio and Massachusetts, since the opening of the rebellion -- whether we regard the number of soldiers they have contributed to the national armies, the class of men which represent them in these armies, the readiness with which responses have been made to the calls of the General Government, or the nobility of the efforts made to afford relief to the sick and the wounded through special State agencies. Yet, in spite of these self-imposed taxes upon the industry of both these Commonwealths, it is a fact, which may be pointed to at once with pride and gratitude, that at no period of its previous history, was either State more prosperous in its financial resources, or better able to meet the future demands upon its liberality for local or general expenditures.
headline: {'main': 'OHIO AND MASSACHUSETTS?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OHIO AND MASSACHUSETTS?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Confederate Commissioners and the Pope's Reply; The, and the Confederacy
snippet: Confederate Commissioners and the Pope's Reply; The, and the Confederacy
lead_paragraph: -- The full text of His Holiness the Pope's response to the manifesto of the "Confederate Commissioners," is a most inadequate fulfillment of the promise given of its significance in the telegraphic abstract. Cardinal ANTONELLI, so far from indulging in political disquisition, confines himself to a sober, sarcerdotal invocation of peace. He tells the "Commissioners," in very appropriate and pointed phrase, that the Pope is a priest, that his mission is to see "wrath appeased and peace restored," everywhere. And for the attainment of this great object, he urges the clergy everywhere to offer up prayer and supplication. There can be nothing more proper than this. It is precisely the object sought for by the United States Government, and it will be attained just as soon as the employes of this "Confederate Commission" choose to lay down their arms of rebellion. They began the strife, and persist in it. If they were wise, they would take the Pope's advice, and become peaceable citizens.
headline: {'main': 'THE POPE AND THE CONFEDERACY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE POPE AND THE CONFEDERACY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: NIBLO'S GARDEN. A new Irish drama called the "Shamrock," is the present attraction at this establishment and the latest novelty offered to the public by the popular favorites, Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS. The work has been in preparation for some time, and has been produced with all the scenic splendor and liberal stage appointments that characterize Mr. WHEATLEY'S management.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- new Irish drama called the "Shamrock," is the present attraction at this establishment and the latest novelty offered to the public by the popular favorites, Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS. The work has been in preparation for some time, and has been produced with all the scenic splendor and liberal stage appointments that characterize Mr. WHEATLEY'S management. Mr. J.B. HOWE is the author, and we freely confess that his inventive powers somewhat overtax our powers of analysis. He has succeeded, however, in presenting a glory which is not only interesting but exciting. The difficulty of accomplishing this in any new form need not be dwelt upon, for Mr. HOWE has not attempted a new form. He has illustrated once more the old story of a virtuous peasantry and a vicious landlordism. The materials have been used a hundred times, but the phases of common life permit frequent repetition. Some of the situations are remarkably, striking, and keep the audience in breathless suspense. The piece is acted with spirit by the company, and with special ability by Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS. It will be repeated every night until further notice.

abstract: George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. At the opening of the court, Mr. Emott resumed his argument in relation to the alleged fraud in the omission of the $28,000 received from the Government.
lead_paragraph: George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. -- At the opening of the court, Mr. Emott resumed his argument in relation to the alleged fraud in the omission of the $28,000 received from the Government. There was not the slightest evidence to support the allegation. Mr. Farley did not exhibit to the Board of Supervisors the statement of profit or loss which he had given in evidence on this trial, but he was examined on the subject by Mr. Blunt, and stated the result to which that calculation led him, and in that calculation he was compelled to take into account the $28,000. The item of $15,000 that appeared in the cash-book was balanced and it had nothing to do with the claim, which was for machinery, tools and material. In regard to damages, counsel insisted that a small verdict at the end of such a trial and against such a libel would be a repetition of the slander.

abstract: Reunion
snippet: Reunion
lead_paragraph: Under the auspices of the New-York Sigma Phi Club, the Fraternity held their annual reunion Thursday evening. It was the fortieth anniversary of the society, which is one of the ablest and most prosperous among the college societies in this country, and numbers in the list of its members many of the most eminent men of the nation. The brethren assembled at the rooms of the New-York Club, St. Germain Hotel, and adjourned to dinner at the Maison Doree. A most sumptuous entertainment, elegant in all its appointments, awaited the guests, who filled nearly all the seats at the table. G.M. SPEIR, Esq., President of the New-York Sigma Phi Club, presided, assisted by Dr. LEWIS A. SAYEE. After the cloth was removed, and the brethren had listened to an eloquent address from the President, the regular toasts were announced and responded to with much eloquence and good taste. We can give but two:

abstract: Consumers' Benefit Coal Co.
snippet: Consumers' Benefit Coal Co.
lead_paragraph: Every consumer of coal would do well to investigate the inducements held out by the "Consumer's Benefit Coal Company," for furnishing this indispensable article at low rates. The organization claims to operate upon a cash capital of $600,000, limiting the shares to $60,000 at a par value of $10 each. Each share entiles the holder to one ton of coal at the actual cost, and dividends from surplus sales are to be made semi-annually in cash. The directors have procured a perpetual lease of the Andarned Improvement Coal Company, at Wilkesbarre, Penn. An advertisement elsewhere gives the details of the organization....Divine service will be held at the rooms of the New-England Relief Society, No. 194 Broadway, to-morrow, at 3 1/2 P.M., by Rev. A.R. THOMPSON, when a sermon commemorative of MATTHEW AGER, late of the Eighth New-Hampshire Volunteers, will be preached....A discourse will be delivered to-morrow evening, at the request of the Young Men's Christian Association, by Rev. T. RALSTON SMITH, in the Seventh Presbyterian Church, Broome-street, corner of Ridge.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, several petitions were presented from army officers, asking for an increase of pay. The petition of the Sisters of Charity, asking for the remission of the duties paid on the material used in the manufacture of their uniforms, was reported back from the Committee on Finance, who were discharged from further consideration of the subject.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, several petitions were presented from army officers, asking for an increase of pay. The petition of the Sisters of Charity, asking for the remission of the duties paid on the material used in the manufacture of their uniforms, was reported back from the Committee on Finance, who were discharged from further consideration of the subject. A resolution was passed calling for information in regard to the number of pension agents employed by the Government. The bill to regulate proceedings in criminal cases, relating especially to the crime of treason, was called up and passed. The bill to drop from the rolls unemployed officers of the army was then called up. Mr. WILSON moved that it be indefinately postponed. After a long animated debate this motion prevailed. A resolution of thanks to Gen. SHERMAN and his army was passed.

abstract: Press on Failing Spirit of the South; Spirit of the South Breaking; Submission will be met with Leniency
snippet: Press on Failing Spirit of the South; Spirit of the South Breaking; Submission will be met with Leniency
lead_paragraph: For the first time during the last four years, or since the great Southern rebellion began, we now begin to see some indications of that for which we have always looked so anxiously and so vainly -- some indications that the imperious, defiant, rebellious spirit of the Southern people is beginning to break. It is not merely in the measures of policy adopted by the rebels that we see this; for the grounds, the import, the bearing, the purpose and the effect of their measures may often be misjudged by us; and for more than two years past they have very often acted in a way that can be characterized as no other than desperate or despairing. But under it all, in all circumstances and amid all fortunes, the popular temper, so far as we could judge it through its exponent, the press, has been unyielding in its devotion to the rebellion, and unflinching in faith of its final success. There has been temporary despondency often enough, but there is a great difference between despondency and its indications, and the indications of despair. As might have been expected, and as is natural, the most constant and extreme assertions of this unbending spirt of the rebellion have been from the press of Richmond.

abstract: The re  election of Senator HOWARD, of Michigan, and the election of Gov. YATES, of Illinois, and the virtual election of Mr. Secretary FESSENDEN in Maine, are solid, practical and cumulative proofs, not only that the loyal States, ...
lead_paragraph: The reelection of Senator HOWARD, of Michigan, and the election of Gov. YATES, of Illinois, and the virtual election of Mr. Secretary FESSENDEN in Maine, are solid, practical and cumulative proofs, not only that the loyal States, East and West, desire to sustain President LINCOLN's Administration, but that they are anxious to see men of eminent discretion, experience and moderation, filling the seats of the highest legislative body during the great crisis of reconstruction. The time is upon us when partisanship must give way before a broad and liberal statesmanship, it the legislation which the termination of hostilities will render necessary, is not to create new sectional evils as bitter in their fruits, as those that have produced the present rebellion. To the Senate, especially, the country will look for calmness and deliberation, for, temperateness of decision, and for a complete disavowal of narrow and sectional purposes. These elections to the Senate mean this if they mean anything. And we record them with satisfaction.

abstract: To-morrow will be New-Year's Day, and great preparations are going on to celebrate the natal day of what the soldiers generally believe will be the last year of the war. On Christmas Day, jollity and mirth was the order of the day, and right royally was it obeyed. Evergreen wreaths, emblematic arches and trophies, could be seen everywhere, and whole camps decorated with planted shrubs, and many similar modes and typical signs were observable.

abstract: Grey Sir G and New-Zealand; Affairs in
snippet: Grey Sir G and New-Zealand; Affairs in
lead_paragraph: The situation of affairs in New-Zealand is altogether unsatisfactory. The anticipations of the colonial press touching the close of the rebellion have not been realized. The few native chiefs who submitted and made a surrender of their lands to Sir GEORGE GREY, did not represent the feelings and wishes of the mass of the natives. The body of the Waikatoes are still in arms; they have retired indeed from the frontier portion of their territory, and the war is for the moment suspended, but they have evidently retired with the determination of renewing the conflict next season, and attempting to recover possession of the abandoned districts. Nor would this enterprise prove difficult of execution were the Imperial Government, as is threatened, to withdraw most of its troops from New-Zealand, and leave the colonists to deal with the enemy single-handed, for, in that case, the Maories would meet but feeble opposition from the scattered settlers of the border, and would speedily become again masters of the confiscated territory.
headline: {'main': 'Affairs in New-Zealand.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Affairs in New-Zealand.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A dispatch from Memphis, dated Jan. 3, says Gen. DANA has received information from an expedition under Gen. GRIERSON, sent out Dec. 21, to destroy the Mobile and Ohio Railroad. They struck the road five miles below Corinth, and by Dec. 27 had utterly destroyed it to a point below Okalona, burning 29 bridges, much trestlework, and capturing 32 cars, 300 wagons and 4,000 carbines. The expedition would continue its work to Meridian. As this is the line by which HOOD's army has received its supplies, this work is of great importance.

abstract: Toner, John, Murdered in Chatham-square
snippet: Toner, John, Murdered in Chatham-square
lead_paragraph: MURDER IN CHATHAM-SQUARE. -- Coroner GOVER held an inquest at No. 23 First-avenue, upon the body of JOHN TONER. The testimony of several witnesses was taken, showing that late on the night of the 3d inst., TONER was among a gang of thieves who had gathered near WM. VARLEY's drinking saloon in Chatham-square, and there created a disturbance; that PRIER THOMPSON, having been struck and very seriously wounded, entered VARLEY's, where he was acquainted, and took thence a cart-rung; that he then returned to the street and engaged the fellows in a free fight; that he prostrated two or three, and that, on reentering the liquor-store, he remarked: "I've laid two of them out!" Shortly after this occurrence, Officer MAHONEY, of the Fourth Precinct, appeared on the scene and dispersed the gang, not, however, until he had apprehended THOMAS VARLEY and PETER THOMPSON. The prisoners were held until Wednesday morning, and then, no complainant appearing against them at the Halls of Justice, they were dismissed; but, subsequently, TONER failing rapidly, and being evidently at the threshold of death, they were rearrested. After listening to the testimony of several witnesses, the jury rendered a verdict as follows: "We find that JOHN TONER came to his death by compression of the brain, the result of blows on the head with a club, at the hands of PETER THOMPSON, on the night of Jan. 3, 1865, at the corner of East Broadway and Chatham-square. We further believe 'Irish Tom' and MICHAEL WHITE to be accessories." The Coroner required THOMPSON to find $1,000 ball to await the action of the Grand Jury, and the police authorities were directed to find WHITE and THOMAS KERRIGAN, alias "Irish Tom." The latter were accordingly taken into custody. TONER was a native of this city, aged 27.

abstract: In view of numerous serious assaults with the knife and revolver recently, our Police Justices have resolved to deal summarily henceforth, with ...
lead_paragraph: In view of numerous serious assaults with the knife and revolver recently, our Police Justices have resolved to deal summarily henceforth, with any person who may be apprehended for disorderly conduct and carrying concealed weapons. Bail in $1,000 is to be required, and in default the prisoner is at once to be sent to Blackwell's Island; and to the end that there may be no delay, the Commissioners of Charities and Corrections have promised to keep a vehicle constantly in readiness to take prisoners on their involuntary journey.

abstract: This fine new hospital transport arrived from Hilton Head on Friday morning. Assistant Surgeon THOS. MCMILLIN, United states Army, in charge. She brings about four hundred sick and wounded soldiers from Gen. SHERMAN's army. Two deaths on the passage -- ISAAC J. EDWARDS, Company K, Fifty-third Indiana Regiment; J. MOTT, Company G, Fifty-third Indiana Regiment. They were brought to this city and buried, by Mr. A.J. CASE, in the Cypress Hill Cemetery. A number of the men belonged to the Ninetieth Illinois Regiment and the Twenty-fifth Ohio. A small number only belong to the One Hundred and Twenty-seventh New-York. The colored troops were mostly from the Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Massachusetts Regiments. The men were transferred to the hospital transport Thomas P. Way, and all taken to the De Camp General Hospital, David's Island, where they were kindly received by Surgeon WEBSTER, and where they will be well cared for.

abstract: Tenant Right Question in; Tenant Right Question in Ireland; of Irish Incumbered Estates' Court on Tenant Right
snippet: Tenant Right Question in; Tenant Right Question in Ireland; of Irish Incumbered Estates' Court on Tenant Right
lead_paragraph: The tenant-right question in Ireland has entered on another stage. The existing state of the law has been treated by Judge LONG, of the Encumbered Estates' Court -- one of the most accomplished jurists in the kingdom -- in a very able address delivered before the Dublin Statistical Society, and he has made certain recommendations which, coming from each a quarter, will possibly produce some effect on the House of Commons, though the experience of the past course of that body on this question, does not warrant much hope. To agitation by the tenantry simply, the only body which has any interest in agitating at all, it is clear that no assemblage composed in the main of landlords or connections of landlords, will ever pay the slightest attention.

abstract: Negro Auxiliaries; Brigades at Nashville
snippet: Negro Auxiliaries; Brigades at Nashville
lead_paragraph: The recent letter of our Tennessee correspondent, an eye-witness of the battle before Nashville, is another evidence, if any were needed, of the fighting qualities of the negro troops. The colored brigades are described by this trustworthy observer, as charging at the double-quick up a hill, down whose sides was pouring a storm of grape and canister, capturing the fort and a fine field battery within it with a considerable number of prisoners, and thus materially aiding the victory in one part of the line. That the battery was not taken by any cowardice of the defenders, is shown by the fact, that every horse was killed and caisson exploded, and thirty-two out of the seventy rebel gunners were killed or wounded.

abstract: Tennant, Policeman, Tried for Attempt to Shoot Capt. Hartt; Stated Meeting; Lecture on Law of Progress; Americus Club, Annual Ball of; Hecker, John,Card from on Injunction
snippet: Tennant, Policeman, Tried for Attempt to Shoot Capt. Hartt; Stated Meeting; Lecture on Law of Progress; Americus Club, Annual Ball of; Hecker, John,Card from on Injunction
lead_paragraph: Since the announcement that the quota of NewYork was only about 3,500 on the last call, the people seem to have folded their hands in content and dismissed from their minds all fear of conscription. If this apathy continues until the 15th of February, the deficiency will be but little reduced by enlistments. The County Volunteer Committee only received ninety-two men during the week just past, hardly as many as they formerly had in a single day, and the prospect for this week is not very encouraging. The action of the Board of Supervisors in voting $4,000,000 fort he payment of bounties, and the proposal to pay $1,000 to recruits, with the subsequent action of the Volunteer Committee declining to increase the bounty, has almost stopped recruiting in this county. The men, who are willing to go look around for the highest bounty offered, and finding that New-York is the lowest bidder, go elsewhere. Those who want to enlist here are holding off with the expectation that the county will be compelled to raise the bounty to $1,000, as recently proposed by the Supervisors.The committee have the money now, and if their efforts to fill the quota are seconded by the people, there will be no draft. And while engaged in the laudable endeavor of avoiding a conscription, they can also obtain first-class men in abundance, if their efforts are put forth in the proper direction. This paper has once before suggested the offer of a special bounty to veterans, of whom it is believed there are some 15,000 in this city. It is well known that the Government is raising a corps composed exclusively of this class, and has offered unusual inducements to men enlisting in it, without any marked success. Let the Volunteer Committee give $1,000 bounty to all veterans who will enlist in HANCOCK's corps, and be credited to this county, and with the cash Government bounty of $300, each man will receive $1,300 as soon as mustered in. Certainly this will bring out the veterans, fill the quota of the city, and till it not with limping imbeciles, or too active bounty-jumpers, but with the best class of trained soldiers. Patriotism and interest both call upon the committee to take this course.

abstract: Wounded near Savannah
snippet: Wounded near Savannah
lead_paragraph: Col. J.H. KETCHAM, of the One Hundred and Fiftieth New-York Volunteers, was severely wounded on the 21st, while at the head of his troops near Savannah, Ga. His brigade had been ordered to hold Argyle Island and the South Carolina shore opposite, and thus to intercept the retreat of the rebels northward. Two days afterward, Savannah surrendered, and the brigade was ordered back. Argyle Island and the main land adjacent being a swamp full of ditches and dykes, to withdraw the troops was a most difficult and dangerous undertaking. They were outnumbered and unprotected. The enemy pressing their rear, a river before them, only small boats and scows in which to cross it, the wind all the time blowing furiously. The One Hundred and Fiftieth New-York was the first to cross, got safely over, and was ordered to protect the crossing of the remainder of the brigade. Its position was very uncomfortable and dangerous. The Colonel passed along the lines to see that his men were not unnecessarily exposed; he had just returned to the right of the line when a shower of bullets fell around him. He was standing unprotected on the dike, and received a very serious, though not mortal wound. Col. KETCHAM had just returned to his regiment, the first of all the officers who left Atlanta to come North to election. Having been triumphantly elected to Congress from the Twelfth District, he returned to duty the first opportunity, notwithstanding his orders permitted him to remain here until Gen. SHERMAN should occupy Savannah. He traveled by night after he landed in Georgia, over a road constantly shelled by the rebels; went immediately into action, received this severe wound, which will probably prevent his serving the country further for the preent: perhaps until he takes his seat in the next Congress.

abstract: Record of
snippet: Record of
lead_paragraph: Brig.-Gen. CHAS. K. GRAHAM is at present in town on a furlough of twenty days, having just returned from the Wilmington expedition, where the army gunboats, commonly known as the "Naval Brigade," did efficient service under his command in landing and embarking troops before Fort Fisher. Gen. GRAHAM is a well-known New-Yorker, who relinquished a lucrative profession early in the war, to take command of a regiment in the "Excelsior Brigade." He served with distinction in MCCLELLAN's Peninsula campaign, and was severely wounded at Gettysburgh in 1863, where he was captured and suffered a long confinement in Libby Prison. He was released in time to take part in the active movements of the year just closed, although still suffering from his wounds. Having been assigned by Gen. BUTLER to the command of the flotilla of army gunboats, on account of his experience in the naval service of which in his early manhood he was an officer, he led the advance up the James River, moving ahead of Admiral LEE's squadron, capturing the rebel signalman, and covering the landing of Gen. BUTLER's forces at Bermuda Hundred.

abstract: The Senate was in session yesterday. Notice was given of a bill to appropriate $200,000 for the relief of sick and wounded soldiers from this State in the service of the United States. Also to appoint a commission to revise the tax laws of the State and report at the next session. For want of a quorum, the Senate then adjourned until Monday morning. The Assembly was not in session, having adjourned from Friday to Monday evening.

abstract: Terrible Fire of Porter's Fleet; Richmond Dispatch; Submission to England, Wilmington, >amp;c.
snippet: Terrible Fire of Porter's Fleet; Richmond Dispatch; Submission to England, Wilmington, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: How comes it that we meet with so many gloomy and despondent Individuals at a time when there is nothing in the position of our affairs to justify such gloom and despondency? The enemy, after a most vigorous, and, on their part, far the most bloody campaign of the war, do not occupy half as much of Confederate territory us they held one year ago. Their currency has depreciated and their debt increased much more rapidly than during any other year of the war. They are almost entirely cut off from supplies of gold from California, and without gold they cannot sustain the war.

abstract: Our Minister in
snippet: Our Minister in
lead_paragraph: A factious journal of this city is indignant because Mr. Minister ADAMS chose to return a civil answer to the address of a number of Englishmen of high social and intellectual standing, who have been from the beginning ardent sympathizers with the Government of the United States in its efforts to restore the National supremacy. The argument is that if a number of Englishmen had the right to be listened to by the American Minister, when they tendered him their friendly congratulations on the success of the national cause, they had the same right to approach him with a remonstrance against the policy adopted by President LINCOLN in putting down the rebellion. And in illustration of its reasoning, the factious organ proceeds to contrast the conduct of Mr. SEWARD, in rejecting the English peace address, with that of Mr. ADAMS, who gives a welcome reception to an address equally impertinent. It is hardly necessary, we presume, to defend Mr. SEWARD from the questionable compliments which it is thus intended to thrust upon him. It is only necessary to recall the fact, so far as the Secretary of State is concerned, that he has been repeatedly the President's organ since the rebellion broke out, to convey to liberal associations, both in England and the Continent of Europe, the thanks of the Executive for friendly addresses. The Swiss address, for example, could not have been forgotten, when Mr. ADAMS was assailed for deviating from the policy marked cut by his superiors. The peace address of the English rebel sympathizers was rejected by the President, because it was an insulting appeal to the United States Government to prostrate itself before the starving conspirators of Richmond. The congratulations of a body of liberal and intelligent Englishmen on the progress of the National arms, and the complete vindication of the National policy, are accepted in the President's name by our Minister at St. James, because these congratulations establish the community of feeling which everywhere prevails among the friends of human freedom and the progress of mankind. Such addresses, however friendly, are not necessary to sustain the Government of the United States in the course it has marked out for itself. But they may fairly be accepted as a counterpoise to British opinion which has been so sedulously manufactured in the interest of the rebels for the past four years, Doubtless, the rebel organs here would prefer more peace addresses to an address like that presented to Mr. ADAMS. Their indignation is natural.
headline: {'main': 'OUR MINISTER IN ENGLAND.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OUR MINISTER IN ENGLAND.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: through Union and Rebel Invasion of Mexico; Enquirer's Expedient for Peace; Invasion of Mexico
snippet: through Union and Rebel Invasion of Mexico; Enquirer's Expedient for Peace; Invasion of Mexico
lead_paragraph: It is surprising to find how fertile in expedients for averting the final overthrow of the Confederacy the rebel journalists have become. The arming and emancipation of the slaves, an appeal to France and England for a joint protectorate, backed up with an offer of unlimited supplies of cotton, a return to a condition of colonial vassalage, an alliance offensive and defensive with the new Emperor of Mexico, are a few of the more noticeable theories that are now daily urged on the consideration of the rebel people. But none of them come up in point of originality to a device of the editor of the Richmond Enquirer. This popular instructor proposes to threaten the Emperor of France with an alliance between what remains of the rebel soldiers and the army of the United States for the express purpose of driving the French invaders out of Mexico. We must quote textually, as the scheme can only be perfectly described in the words of its propounder. Says the editor of the Enquirer:

abstract: Southern Protectorate--Probable View of; Views on Southern Protectorate; Protectorate of South, Probable, English and French View of
snippet: Southern Protectorate--Probable View of; Views on Southern Protectorate; Protectorate of South, Probable, English and French View of
lead_paragraph: The recent proposal in the columns of the Richmond Sentinel, for a European Protectorate or defensive alliance, was evidently semi-official. That is, it was a "feeler" by the Confederate Government to sound the public opinion of the South on this desperate measure. As such, it is believed to be regarded by our own Department of State. It is not a matter to be dismissed, as only the despairing talk of the rebels, feeling themselves in the last extremity. It is a most important diplomatic proposal, and should be carefully considered on this side of the line. Whether, if accepted by the European Powers, it would also be ratified by the masses of the Southern States, we will not here discuss. It is enough at present to know that it is seriously deliberated upon by the Confederate authorities and that these authorities are, militarily, absolute. The great question for us is, "How would the European Powers, or, more distinctly, England and France, receive such an offer from the Confederacy, accompanied with the promise of emancipation?"

It it not probable that this scheme will remain the same for some weeks to come.

abstract: Custom-House Abuses, >amp;c; Cases to be Severely dealt with; Custom-house Abuses; in Custom-house; Duties and Abuses
snippet: Custom-House Abuses, >amp;c; Cases to be Severely dealt with; Custom-house Abuses; in Custom-house; Duties and Abuses
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column, to-day, a communication from an authoritative source, drawn out by our recent article on Customhouse abuses. In that article we pointed out two alleged grievances suffered by importers; one the abstraction of merchandise from packages in the bonded warehouse, and the other, unnecessary delay in the delivery of goods from Custom-house store, as the penalty of refusal by merchants to pay illegal fees to Custom-house employes. In response to the inquiry made by "S," we have to say that the "delays" referred to by us were in obtaining the necessary withdrawal permits. If correctly informed, these delays have sometimes, within the last few months, amounted to a week or more, in a given instance, and not a few hours only, and this at a time when foreign merchandise was hourly in danger of large depreciation by reason of the violent fluctuations in gold. No merchant can do business safely in such a state of things.

abstract: New-York Weekly Review; New Paper; New-York Weekly Review
snippet: New-York Weekly Review; New Paper; New-York Weekly Review
lead_paragraph: -- The new literary enterprise in this city, the New-York Weekly Review, is an exceedingly elegant, valuable, sprightly and attractive journal. Its first issue came out on Saturday last, and its success in every respent was proved at once. The lighter topics in literature, in art, especially in music, and in theatrical gossip and general affairs, are treated with ability and vivacity. It gives evidence that there is abundant talent in this city for the conduct of a journal of its cast, as we are sure there is a sufficiently large community of the right kind to give it a handsome support. We have said this is the first issue of the journal, but the Weekly Review is really a continuation, in a new form and character, of the old and popular Musical Review. In giving the latter greater scope and making it of wider interest as an organ of general literature, it will by no means lose sight of its old speciality of music, as is shown in the present issue. We hope this will supply the want that has long existed in New-York for a literary journal, and that by its high tone and character it will merit the support it is sure to receive. Mr. C.B. SEYMOUR is its editor, and he is aided by a large corps of writers.
headline: {'main': 'NEW LITERARY PAPER.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'NEW LITERARY PAPER.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Hester-street, Eichhorn's Saloon
snippet: Hester-street, Eichhorn's Saloon
lead_paragraph: Coroner COLLIN held an inquest, yesterday, at Bellevue Hospital, upon the body of WILLIAM BEEBE, (or FITZGERALD) a soldier, who, after fifteen months' service in the army, was recently furloughed, and who, accompanied by several convivial companions, went to HENRY EICHHORN'S lager-bier saloon, on Tuesday evening last, and there received a mortal wound, from which he died on Saturday. BEEBE was a native of Philadelphia, aged 23 years. Two years or longer ago he lived in Northport, Conn., and was there known as WILLIAM FITZGERALD; but, becoming warmly attached to the gentleman with whom he resided, he adopted his patron's name, and was thereafter known as BEEBE. The circumstances under which he received his death wound are to be found in the following testimony, which is from a mass of affidavits that were taken before the Coroner's jury:

abstract: The Pressing
snippet: The Pressing
lead_paragraph: -- The Bankrupt Bill is still before the Judiciary Committe of the Senate. There are but little more than seven weeks remaining to the present Congress, to finish up the business it has on hand. It would be too much to expect that in all the details of the Bankrupt Bill passed by the House, the Senate should entirely agree. The measure, therefore, may be expected to be thrown back for revision, either in the House or in a Conference Committee of both Houses. In view of this, is it too much to hope from the Senate promptness of action in the preliminary steps it has to take before the measure comes up again for open debate? There are few questions so really pressing, so entirely practical, so universally regarded with interest. It will be a most serious discouragement if it is not brought to a final solution before Congress closes its labors.
headline: {'main': 'THE BANKRUPT BILL.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE BANKRUPT BILL.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SUICIDE OF A MARINE. -- A private of the Marine Corps, on board the receiving ship North Carolina, lying off the Navy-yard, named JEREMIAH P. GROVE, committed suicide on Sunday morning, by shooting himself with his musket. He had been placed on guard upon Cobb Dock, and when the relief came, at 6:15 o'clock, he was found weltering in blood. He had pulled off his right boot, and, placing the muzzle of the gun under his chin, discharged the piece with his toe. His head was completely shattered. Deceased had been in the service ten months, was a native of Maryland and 33 years of age. The Purser of the North Carolina has $250 of his money in the safe, on board. GROVE showed occasional evidences of insanity, and it is supposed that he put an end to his existence while laboring under one of these fits. Coroner LYNDS held an inquest, and a verdict of suicide was rendered.

abstract: THE ACCIDENT ON THE BERGEN TUNNEL. -- Some errors have been made in giving the names of those injured in the recent collision on the Bergen Tunnel. PETER SCHENCK, who was killed, was a son of W.J. SCHENCK of No. 323 Fifth-avenue. REMSEN SCHENCK, a brother of the deceased, was slightly injured in the left leg below the knee. ANDREW PRUYN, who lost his left arm, is a son of Mayor FRANCIS PRUYN of Albany. VICTOR WILSON, a son of A.L. WILSON, of Norwalk, Conn., had his foot crushed. All these young men were on their way to school in Bloomfield, Conn. Mr. L.S. HASKELL, whose injuries it is feared may prove fatal, was a permanent citizen of Orange. Young ROBERTSON, son of Gen. ROBERTSON, who was reported injured, was not on the train.

abstract: Events in the Southwest have justified my anticipations (frequently stated in the TIMES) of the important consequences to flow from the advance of our armies from the West. It would have rejoiced the nation to have taken Richmond at any time during the war; but at no time could it have been of half the importance of a continuous march from the West cutting off the Southwestern States, destroying ...
lead_paragraph: Events in the Southwest have justified my anticipations (frequently stated in the TIMES) of the important consequences to flow from the advance of our armies from the West. It would have rejoiced the nation to have taken Richmond at any time during the war; but at no time could it have been of half the importance of a continuous march from the West -- cutting off the Southwestern States, destroying the lines of communication, practically annihilating the principal resources of the Confederacy, and reducing, not merely Richmond, but what Richmond holds, the rebel Government, to the last extremity. This process has been begun, and partly accomplished, by SHERMAN's victorious march through Georgia. But it will be far more apparent in what is to follow, if SHERMAN pursues his course, with the military sagacity which has heretofore guided him. His march on the single line of railroad through Branchville, (at any point on it which he may select,) his march on the railroads of North Carolina, and thence on the Roanoke, (at Danville,) utterly destroying all communication between LEE and his supports, are matters of course, unless the rebels can throw an army across his path stronger than that of LEE. How probable that is, we may know by reference to some obvious facts.

abstract: Quotas Under Call not to be Reduced by Credits
snippet: Quotas Under Call not to be Reduced by Credits
lead_paragraph: Gen. HAYS has received instructions from Washington not to fix the quotas of sub-districts in accordance with the order issued by Provost-Marshal General FRY, already published, and has been directed to report to the Department all the enlistments up to the 31st day of December. The object of this call for information is probably to arrange new quotas on the basis of the enlistments up to that date. It will be seen, by the order printed elsewhere, that the Government intends to have 300,000 men in the field as the proceeds of the last call in addition to all credits heretofore allowed. No credits will be allowed for officers or invalids, or men enlisted in the navy upon papers, and assigned previous to the 19th day of December, or for anything but able-bodied enlistedmen -- a very judicious determination on the part of the Government. The contemplated change in the quotas, it is to be hoped, will not deprive New-York of any of the credits which have been so justly awarded to her. Supervisor BLUNT went to Washington last night to see that the interests of the county are protected, and to make the proper representations to the Department. In view of this new order from the Department, and the uncertain position of districts, it will be well for every man who can spare the amount necessary for a substitute, to deposit the money for that purpose at once with the Volunteer Committee. There are now plenty of substitutes offering, and no substitute money in the hands of the committee.

abstract: and Thomas' Campaigns in Cotton States
snippet: and Thomas' Campaigns in Cotton States
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Examiner, of Friday last, says it is confirmed that SHERMAN'S troops have crossed the Savannah River and are believed to be marching toward Grahamsville, in the direction of Charleston. The rebels are now as much puzzled in regard to the nature and direction of the next campaign of SHERMAN as they were about his last campaign at the time of its inauguration and during its progress. They know that it must be eastward and northward, as there is no enemy in the whole region west of the Savannah worthy of his attention. But is he going to strike first for Augusta, or for Branchville, or for Charleston? Or, will he adopt his Georgia policy and move his forces so as to appear to be striking for several places in one direction, while his real objective is another place in a different direction? It will be as hard for the rebels to find out as it would be for us to tell; but as the Unionist dispatches from Savannah a few days since announced that "SHERMAN's army was being rapidly reorganized and reequipped, preparatory to the commencement of a campaign as remarkable as its last," and, as the rebel dispatches are already beginning to report movements on SHERMAN's part, of a singularly incomprehensible character, we think it not unlikely that before the close of the present month, they will find out the whole secret of his puzzling plans.

lead_paragraph: In view of numerous serious assaults with the knife and revolver recently, our Police Justices have resolved to deal summarily henceforth, with any person who may be apprehended for disorderly conduct and carrying concealed weapons. Bail in $1,000 is to be required, and in default the prisoner is at once to be sent to Blackwell's Island; and to the end that there may be no delay, the Commissioners of Charities and Corrections have promised to keep a vehicle constantly in readiness to take prisoners on their involuntary journey.

abstract: This board met at 2 P.M., yesterday, President HAYES in the chair. Mr. KEENAN presented a resolution authorizing the Comptroller to sell at auction the site formerly occupied by the Colored Orphan Asylum in Fifth-avenue, near Forty-fourth-street, and to place the amount obtained to the credit of the Sinking Fund; and further authorizing the Comptroller to select a suitable site for the asylum on land belonging to the city, above One Hundred and Tenth-street, and report to the Common Council for their approval. The resolution was adopted.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented relative to the establishment of a naval depot for the Northern lakes; for an increase of the pay of army officers, and for an appropriation of money for the support of Southern refugees.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions were presented relative to the establishment of a naval depot for the Northern lakes; for an increase of the pay of army officers, and for an appropriation of money for the support of Southern refugees. The resolutson to distribute the proceeds of the Savannah cotton among the officers and soldiers of Gen. SHERMAN's army was indefinitely postponed. The resolution to free the wives and children of colored soldiers was taken up and debated with great animation. Several amendments were rejected, and the resolution was then passed.

abstract: Thomas' Gen. Army and its Work
snippet: Thomas' Gen. Army and its Work
lead_paragraph: Gen. THOMAS, we learn, is concentrating his magnificent army at Eastport, in the northeastern corner of the State of Mississippi, near the point where the railroad to Mobile crosses the Memphis and Chattanooga road. He will thus have the most convenient base of supplies that our Western army has had since GRANT fought the battle of Shiloh -his line of communication being by water, on the Tennessee River. He has not only driven the rebels entirely out of Tennessee, but has put the State in a perfect condition of defence, so that he may be free, at his convenience, to enter on his new campaign southward.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone or public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The late collission in the Bergen Tunnel has revived the uneasiness felt by those compelled to travel over the Morris and Essex Railroad at the alleged lack of proper vigilance to guard against accidents, and yesterday morning a meeting of passengers, presided over by Mr. W.J. BEEBE, was improvised on board the ferry-boat Hoboken, as she was making her trip to this side the river. After brief and spirited speeches a committee of five commuters was appointed to take the matter in charge, and to urge upon the managers of the road the necessity of immediately adopting certain precautions. The manner in which the ferry-boats have frequently been over-crowded has lately given rise to considerable excitement. A committee of passengers appointed to remonstrate against this abuse, waiated upon the Superintendent of the Ferry a short time ago, and were answered that the matter should be looked after and that teams should not be allowed to trespass upon the space set apart for passengers. A few mornings since, however, upon the deck hands of the ferry-boat attempting to override this pledge, the passengers took the business into their own hands, and as they were armed with umbrellas, presented such a serried array to the teams as they attempted to pass on board the boat, turn they easily and effectually repelled their advance. The occurrence caused quite a stir, although it has not effectually remedied the evil complained of. A larger number of boats, that more frequent trips may be made, are imperatively demanded by the increased travel which the change of the terminus of the Morris and Essex Railroad to Hoboken has thrown upon this ferry. Then two ferrymasters should be regularly detailed to attend the gates during those hours of the day when the largest number of passengers are crossing, as individuals are frequently belated in consequence of the inability of one ferrymaster to take the tickets.

The manner in which the ferry-boats have frequently been over-crowded has lately given rise to considerable excitement. A committee of passengers appointed to remonstrate against this abuse, waiated upon the Superintendent of the Ferry a short time ago, and were answered that the matter should be looked after and that teams should not be allowed to trespass upon the space set apart for passengers. A few mornings since, however, upon the deck hands of the ferry-boat attempting to override this pledge, the passengers took the business into their own hands, and as they were armed with umbrellas, presented such a serried array to the teams as they attempted to pass on board the boat, turn they easily and effectually repelled their advance. The occurrence caused quite a stir, although it has not effectually remedied the evil complained of. A larger number of boats, that more frequent trips may be made, are imperatively demanded by the increased travel which the change of the terminus of the Morris and Essex Railroad to Hoboken has thrown upon this ferry. Then two ferrymasters should be regularly detailed to attend the gates during those hours of the day when the largest number of passengers are crossing, as individuals are frequently belated in consequence of the inability of one ferrymaster to take the tickets.

abstract: George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. At the opening of the court, yesterday morning, Mr. Evarts, before resuming his consideration of the topics which he was examining at the adjournment on Friday.
lead_paragraph: George Opdyke vs. Thurlow Weed. -- At the opening of the court, yesterday morning, Mr. Evarts, before resuming his consideration of the topics which he was examining at the adjournment on Friday, made some suggestions as to the legal rule governing the claims of parties against the city for property destroyed by ricters. The claim of the owners of the armory, destroyed on 13th July, 1863, against the City of New-York, was based on the statute of 1855; and the measure of such claim is the actual value of the specific property destroyed at the time of its destruction, and in its mere quality as property, without any allowance for use and enjoyment, or for gains expected or accruing. The relation of the county is that of an insurer or indemnator. (2d Philipe, p. 58, citing Laurent vs. Chatham Ins. Co., 1 Hall, 41.) Addressing the jury, Mr. Evarts resumed his consideration of the "Gun Claim" against the city, and passed to the machinery and tools. There were no difficulties in presenting a complete account of the tools and machinery, the material and the articles in an unfinished state; for these elements had to be considered in making up the claim in its present shape. The proper way was to set down the schedule of machinery and tools, and giving its value as it stood at the time of its destruction. Setting down the articles at their value, they would then come to the portion of the carbines which had a fixed price, then the labor expended, and thus the claim would have been made distinct and clear, beyond the material and labor, of over $20,000 for petantee's fees on arms that had never been completed, and also the profits expected on future construction of the guns. But how does the claim for machinery and tools appear to have been made? The principle and result, us exhibited in the schedules, was not to give values, but, dollar for dollar, all that had been expended by the capitalists and speculators on the subjects contained in the schedules. In the statement of the claim before the Board of Supervisors there was no suggestion that the cost of 1,050 guns delivered to the Government was not included. An opportunity of explanation was offered to Mr. Farley and Mr. Opdyke, and they failed to give it. All the expenditures were considered at the cost of making the 6,000 guns, and in that view there was an absolute suppression and exaggeration of the claim by what appeared in the general expenditures and outlay as attributable to the 1,050 carbines being carried to swell the cost of the 6,000. Suppose certain machines had been sold, would it not have been dishonest not to have deducted the product of their secondary sale? The $185,000 should have had a reduction by the $15,000 received from the Government, but which being balanced in the cash-book does not appear as a reduction. Counsel adverted to the attempted impeachment of Mr. Stover. Of course it would not have been attempted had his testimony been unimportant. But the witnesses who were brought to impeach him were not much acquainted with him, and the attempted impeachment was a failure, Mr. Gibbs said that in the claim as presented, to the Board of Supervisors there was a large swindle. Was there not an artifice in the presentation of that claim? It was a deliberate artifice on the confession of the plaintiff. All the sums put in were put in as cost and not profit. There was not a lisp of the money got from the United States Government, nor of the portion that was to go to the patentees, nor of the profit to the owners. And when the claim was paid the patentee was kept out of his portion on the principle of "equity." The testimony before the Board of Supervisors was taken down, read over to the witnesses, and by them signed, and now the plaintiff wanted you to read it all backward with this and that interpolated. Mr. Weed based his allegations upon the testimony as it was rendered, and for so doing he was held for accountability at this tribunal. The question was, had injustice been done by the defendant to the plaintiff, by the narratives which appeared in the public prints? The evidence showed that Mr. Weed was the assailed party, and that he undertook to unmask his assailants, among whom was the plaintiff. And from testimony drawn from the friends, employes and dependents of Mr. Opdyke, the facts upon which the charges rested, had been abundantly shown. The plaintiff had overlooked the fact of his public relations. He had put himself on the level of Farley, McNeil and Jones in the gun contract, and treated himself as under no obligation of strict official duty, of honor, of dignity, of public spirit, of public character, toward this community. So, likewise, in regard to the Mariposa matter; Mr. Opdyke had treated himself as a private individual, and not in his assumed position of devotion to the public interests and the public good. So, too, in regard to the Surveyorship; he put himself on the level of the common plotters to secure office by means of money, political management and strategy. He never had been a subject of comment by the defendant, except in the light of his public relations, and of his ostentatious and paraded claim that he had no connection with these kinds of pursuits since he became a public man. And what was his justification? That he was not a thief, a robber, a forger, an escaped felon? If a man displays himself for admiration, he must run the risk of admiration. If he is afraid of the glare of the footlights, let him shoot the pit. Diogenes sought for an honest man with a lantern. We, in our joy at the discovery, have place two lanterns at the doors of our Mayors, and Fernando Wood and George Opdyke are the latest illustrations of our success. [Laughter.] They come, one after the other, from opposite parties, so that we can feel no disappointment of party feeling. We made them, and we must stand by them and share their fate. How much came from placing rich men in office? Principle, character, moderation, self-control, are the test whether a man be rich or poor. Many a poor man has remained poor because he has been shifting, vascillating, and either actually dishonest, or so near it that be never was trusted. These evil habits are quite as likely to grow upon what they feed upon as to become eager from abstinence. It was out of a crowded harem that King David desired Uriah's wife. This case is already decided. The evidenee has been impartially displayed by the press and promulgated all over the land. The question is not so much what the evidence or conclusion is, but whether you and I, and all of us have virtue enough of our own to put a true standard of measurement upon this transaction. We have a maxim in our law that when the guilty escapes, the tribunal that tries him is convicted. So it will be with us to-day. It is the measure of our judgment that is asked for. You have that issue in your hands. You have the keeping of the public fame, public character and public safety. Now, if you like this kind of public men, or public conduct, and think that evil has been done to this community by the comments and denunciation of the defendant, clothe the plaintiff, is he asks you, in the purple and fine linen of your applauding judgment, put the golden chain of your favorable verdict about his neck, carry him from this court-room on your Ajax shoulders, blow your sychophantic trumpets for him, and proclaim, until it shall ring through the land, as my friends say, "Thus shall it be done to the man that the people delight to honor."

abstract: We are Opposed to; Negotiations Inv lve Recognition; Diplomacy Objectionable; by War Preferable to Blair's Mission
snippet: We are Opposed to; Negotiations Inv lve Recognition; Diplomacy Objectionable; by War Preferable to Blair's Mission
lead_paragraph: We trust there is no truth in the renewed rumor that Mr. F.P. BLAIR has gone to Richmond for the purpose of talking with the rebel authorities about peace. No good can possibly come of such a mission, and it may interfere more or less injuriously with the natural progress of events toward a substantial and a lasting peace. The Government has up to this time held precisely the right position in refusing to have anything whatever to do with the Confederate authorities, or their agents, which should involve, directly or indirectly, any recognition of their claim to represent the people of the Southern States. We trust it will hold this position to the end. Peace, when it comes, must not come as a concession from JEFF. DAVIS, or through him as the agent of an organized community. To admit his rightful power to make peace, is to admit his rightful power to make war, and this is substantially and to all practical intents and purposes a recognition of the nation of which he claims to be the Executive head. None but national authorities can wage war or make for peace; and the moment we enter into negotiations with the rebel Government for terms of peace, that moment we have actually and legally conceded everything for which they have been making war.

abstract: Hoboken, Indignation Meeting on Boat; John Curtin, schooner, boilers,verdict
snippet: Hoboken, Indignation Meeting on Boat; John Curtin, schooner, boilers,verdict
lead_paragraph: BOILER EXPLOSION AT THE GEORGE WASHINGTON FIRE -- INQUEST BEFORE CORONER WILDEY. -- On Friday last a steam boiler exploded on board the wrecking schooner John Curtin, at Pier No. 9, North River, and HAMILTON MERRITT, the engineer, was killed and blown overboard, and his brother, Capt. ISRAEL MERRITT, special agent of the Board of Underwriters, was severely scalded. Coroner WILDEY impanneled a jury on Saturday, and yesterday several witnesses were examined, among them Mr. JOSEPH C. COFFEE, of No. 56 Barclay-street, Chief of the Boiler Inspection Bureau. Mr. COFFEE, having heard several statements, examined the Curtin's boiler, and expressed the opinion that at the time of the explosion the boiler was carrying a far too great pressure of steam, there being, probably, from 100 to 125 pounds to the square inch, when only about 75 pounds pressure could be carried with perfect safety. Other testimony showed that the engineer threw a pailful of water into the furnace with a view of quenching the flames, and that the explosion followed. The jury found a verdict accordingly, and, in view of the fact that the schooner's boiler had been five years in use without inspection, recommended that henceforth all steam boilers be inspected frequently under direction of the proper authorities.

abstract: Kennedy, J L, Treasurer New-York Institute for the Blind
snippet: Kennedy, J L, Treasurer New-York Institute for the Blind
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERMAN's Christmas gift to the nation, of the City of Savannah, not only brought great joy to the people at large, but filled with elation a limited class, who saw at once, in the capture, a splendid chance for filling their pockets, by supplying the needy inhabitants with the good things of life, to which, for weary months, rebellion has made them comparative strangers. During the past two weeks, hundreds of applications have been made to the customs authorities for information, permits, &c., from merchants and speculators, who are anxious to make shipments, and particularly from the swarm of sutlers and hucksters at Hilton Head and Beaufort, who would like to "change their base" of operations to the more extended market thus opened to their wares. To all these applications the invariable answer was given, that no clearances could be granted without the special authority from the Treasury Department at Washington.

abstract: One Hundred in 1864; Crime in New-York; Criminal Code Complete, and Should be Adopted; Abuse of
snippet: One Hundred in 1864; Crime in New-York; Criminal Code Complete, and Should be Adopted; Abuse of
lead_paragraph: The number of homicides committed in this city, during the past year, is officially reported as one hundred. The number of unsuccessful attempts to kill we have not ascertained, but we are satisfied that if we set them down at four hundred, we shall be under the mark. So that it may be safely said that, since the 1st of January, 1864, five hundred attempts to kill, successful or unsuccessful, have been made. During the last week, five men were mortally wounded -- three in drinking saloons, and one while standing at his own door, by a shot from the window of a house on the opposite side of the street; and within the same period there were nine attempts to kill.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, notice was given of a bill to provide for the regulation and government of the Central Park; to extend the Second-avenue Railroad in New-York. Among the bills introduced was one to provide a parade-ground for the military of New-York; to fix the compensation of members of the New-York Common Council at $2,500 per annum; to provide for the appointment of five Commissioners of Appeals; a resolution appointing Messrs. MUNGER, WHITE and HUMPHREY a committee to investigate into the affairs and management of the several departments of the New-York City Government, was adopted; a resolution was also adopted requesting the President to waive all non-essential questions, and promptly direct an exchange of prisoners on equitable terms.

lead_paragraph: The Money market worked easy yesterday. Business was generally dull on Wall-street owing to the rain-storm. At the Stock Exchange, the Railways were irregular through the forenoon, and, with few exceptions, weaker than on Monday. There was a steadier feeling in the after noon. Government stocks steady or partially better. The general market, later in the day, closed firm. Gold down two or three per cent.

abstract: Historical Society Communications opened with Georgia Society; Historical Society Reopens Communication with Georgia Society
snippet: Historical Society Communications opened with Georgia Society; Historical Society Reopens Communication with Georgia Society
lead_paragraph: At the annual meeting of the New-York Historical Society on the 3d inst., Dr. OSGOOD, the Domestic Secretary, read in his report a copy of the letter addressed to the Georgia Historical Society, at Savannah, on the resumption of communications with that city. He reminded that society of friendly intercourse in former years, in the national affinity under which Georgia and New-York had won their historical name, and suggested that the intercourse might be renewed as between scholars and gentlemen engaged in kindred studies and as citizens bound to share a common destiny. The letter was received with hearty applause.

abstract: CITY AND COUNTY OF NEW-YORK. In accordance with the programme of Messrs. WM. R. STEWART and RUFUS F. ANDREWS, the Special Committee appointed by the Union State Central Committee to reorganize the Union party of the City and County of New-York, the Union delegates elected to the General Committee, assembled at the corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street, on Thursday evening, Jan. 5, for the purpose of organization.
lead_paragraph: CITY AND COUNTY OF NEW-YORK. -- In accordance with the programme of Messrs. WM. R. STEWART and RUFUS F. ANDREWS, the Special Committee appointed by the Union State Central Committee to reorganize the Union party of the City and County of New-York, the Union delegates elected to the General Committee, assembled at the corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street, on Thursday evening, Jan. 5, for the purpose of organization. At the hour appointed, Messrs. STEWART and ANDREWS appeared on the platform and announced that delegations had been regularly returned from thirteen of the seventeen Assembly Districts of the city. They further announced that in consequence of protests and other irregularities, they had decided to call the roll of the uncontested delegates, and ask each delegate to name his preference for temporary Chairman, after which they would turn over me disputed delegations to the Committee, for settlement.

abstract: Great Military Choice (of operations)
snippet: Great Military Choice (of operations)
lead_paragraph: That must have been an exciting moment to the great leader of our campaigns, when, in his tent on the James, he sent forth the silent message which was to launch fifty thousand veterans, either toward the East or the South, and in effect determine the issue of the struggle. His distinguished Lieutenant, almost an associate in his fortunes, had just returned on his line of communications from Atlanta, and probably, to the great surprise of both, had discovered that his spirited enemy was abandoning the whole South and East to his advance. When that fact was communicated by Gen. SHERMAN to Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, the latter must have seen at once that the time for the grand blow of the war had come. He knew the ability of Gen. THOMAS, and what powerful reinforcements could be concentrated in Nashville, and what a formidable line the Cumberland and the fortresses between Nashville and Chattanooga are; and he saw that for the first time in the struggle we had a large army unopposed to hurl upon any portion of the enemy's territory he desired.
headline: {'main': 'The Great Military Choice.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Great Military Choice.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A NEW FRUIT PIECE BY ROBIE. -- All our tasteful readers, who relish every choice thing in art, will find new gratification at SCHAUS' gallery, No. 749 Broadway, where a new fruit piece, just finished by ROBIE, of Brussels, is now on exhibition. ROBIE's high rank in this line of painting is conceded by critics, and his productions fully appreciated. This new work can only add to his fame. Though the artist has handled his brush with remarkable freedom, his fidelity to nature is complete. The canvas is unusually large for a fruit piece, the subjects being natural size, and the truthfulness and depth of color and shading is most exquisitely done.

abstract: Commissioner, on Vagrant Children; Mr. Acton's Report
snippet: Commissioner, on Vagrant Children; Mr. Acton's Report
lead_paragraph: Again "the cry of the children" comes up to us -- this time through the President of the Police -- telling us of those unfortunate exceptions to our civilization who throng the poor alleys, the docks, the markets and the tenement houses of our great city -- the uncared-for children of the vagrant poor. We hardly need the reminder of the police that they exist; they meet us at every street-crossing, and before all places where pity or habit can extract some pennies for their relief. Those thin faces and shivering little forms, and the begging hands held out with such piteous requests, are the bane of our city to every kind-hearted man, and make him glad to escape where poverty is not forever reminding him of her sad woes.
headline: {'main': "The Vagrant Children Mr. Acton's Report.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Vagrant Children Mr. Acton's Report.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: Mayor GUNTHER yesterday addressed a letter to the New-York Sanitary and Chemical Compost Company, suggesting that they modify their offer for cleaning the streets, so that the Street Cleaning Commission may be enabled to accept it. The offer of the company is merely to sweep the streets for the sum of $300,000 per annum, but they say nothing about removing the ashes and garbage. The removal of the ashes and street sweepings would entail a further expense on the city of some $300,000 -- making $600,000 in all.
