abstract: Relief for
snippet: Relief for
lead_paragraph: It would be ungracious to undervalue in any degree the efforts of the great mercantile community represented by the Chamber of Commerce and in the Produce Exchange, for the relief of the poor of Savannah. But we think we have a right, looking to the lengthy discussions which have taken place in the first named body, as well as to the elaborate resolutions passed in the Corn Exchange yesterday, to suggest that prompt action, accompanied with less verbiage, is exceedingly desirable.

abstract: The steamship Moravian, from Liverpool 29th, via Londonderry on the 30th ult., arrived at Portland at noon yesterday, with five days later news. The steamships Hansa and Bavarian, from New-York, arrived out on the 28th. The political news is unimportant, as also the commercial advices, owing to the inactivity caused by the holidays. The order of General DIX to pursue rebel raiders into Canada attracted much attention, and the leading journals hope it will not be acted upon, as trouble might ensue. The papers generally discountenance the idea of being driven into unfriendly relations with the United States, and the Times says that the rebels could desire nothing better. The news of the successes of SHERMAN and THOMAS caused a decline of three per cent. in the rebel loan, and American securities were more buoyant.

abstract: CITY NOTES. FREDERICK DOUGLASS will lecture at Cooper Institute to-morrow (Friday) evening, in behalf of the Union Bazaar Association. The funds realized from the admission fee of 25 cents are to be devoted to the relief of sick and wounded soldiers....Miss SEDGWICK will give the second of her course of readings this (Thursday) evening, in the lecture-room of the Historical Society .... Private...
lead_paragraph: CITY NOTES. -- FREDERICK DOUGLASS will lecture at Cooper Institute to-morrow (Friday) evening, in behalf of the Union Bazaar Association. The funds realized from the admission fee of 25 cents are to be devoted to the relief of sick and wounded soldiers....Miss SEDGWICK will give the second of her course of readings this (Thursday) evening, in the lecture-room of the Historical Society.... Private MILLES O'REILLY, Forty-seventh Regiment New-York Volunteers, has written a remarkable book, called Bounty Swindling as a Fine Art, and Bounty Jumping as One of the Exact Sciences, It will contain richly humorous illustrations, and all its material allegations will be supported copiously by official reports, affidavits and documents, turning this whole matter of iniquity inside out, and placing the responsibility where it belongs. CARLETON is the publisher.... Monsieur DUBOIS, who is known as the "Funny Frenchman," announces that he will lecture at Dodworth Hall this evening and to-morrow evening. The Boston journals say that his budget of French and English blunders are so witty and ludicrous that the most solemnly inclined persons are provoked to laughter.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bills for the improvement of the Central Park; to incorporate a home for disabled soldiers; to provide a military parade-ground in New-York; were favorably reported. Notice was given of a bill to aid the National Government in providing defences on the lakes, and to repeal the fare restriction clause in the railroad consolidation act of 1853.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bills for the improvement of the Central Park; to incorporate a home for disabled soldiers; to provide a military parade-ground in New-York; were favorably reported. Notice was given of a bill to aid the National Government in providing defences on the lakes, and to repeal the fare restriction clause in the railroad consolidation act of 1853. Bills were introduced to incorporate the Studio Building Association of New-York; and to amend the assessment law; the joint resolution urging President LINCOLN to adopt measures for the early exchange of all our prisoners of war was adopted. The argument in the Ninth Senatorial District contested seat case was resumed by Mr. FOLGER in behalf of Mr. LOW, the contestant.

abstract: Will have Independence or Annihilation; The Futility of; Expedients; Slaves or Monarchy; Government will hold out (Blair Mission)
snippet: Will have Independence or Annihilation; The Futility of; Expedients; Slaves or Monarchy; Government will hold out (Blair Mission)
lead_paragraph: Mr. Blair, in going to Richmond on a private peace mission, of course goes to confer with JEFF. DAVIS and his friends. He would not be admitted, through the rebel lines into Richmond, with any other purpose, any more than our own Government would admit a rebel through its own lines, into its capitsl, to have communication with its Northern opponents, instead of itself. This single fact is enough to settle that the errand will be bootless.

abstract: Rumors; The McMullen Resolutions; Rumors; McMullen Resolutions; McMullen's Peace Resolutions in Rebel Congress
snippet: Rumors; The McMullen Resolutions; Rumors; McMullen Resolutions; McMullen's Peace Resolutions in Rebel Congress
lead_paragraph: In addition to the dispatches and rumors about the Blair mission to Richmond, with which the public have been entertained for the last week, we have now a statement, by telegraph from Washington, that a proposition has passed the rebel Congress at Richmond for the appointment of a commission of fifteen members to hold conference on the subject of peace with an equal number of Commissioners to be appointed from the North. The dispatch is greatly deficient in greatly-needed details; and up to two o'clock this morning, we were unable to obtain anything more than the bald statements to be found in our telegraphic columns.

abstract: An important report reaches us from Washington to the effect that the rebel House of Representatives, in compliance with a resolution introduced several weeks ago, has appointed a board of fifteen commissioners to proceed to "some convenient point" for the purpose of negotiating terms of peace. Among the commissioners thus appointed are several who are well known as being desirous of bringing about a cessation of hostilities -- Vice-President STEPHENS, Messrs. BOYCE, of South Carolina, and LEACH and GILLMORE, of North Carolina.

abstract: A meeting of the members of the Produce Exchange was held yesterday afternoon, at 1 o'clock, at the Exchange Building, to take action in reference to the relief of the suffering citizens of Savannah. Mr. GEORGE D. CRAGIN, President of the Exchange, presided, and introduced Col. JULIAN ALLEN, who said it gave him great pleasure to find that the people of the North were so ready to respond to the call in aid of the destitute of Savannah. He believed the people of Savannah were worthy of all the sympathy that had been expressed for them, and he was glad to know that something of a substantial character was about to be added for the relief of their wants. He did not come to beg for the citizens of Savannah. He had been sent on a far different mission. Anything given willingly and unasked for, to the poor and suffering, was a noble charity. It did his heart good to find the North taking this view of the matter. The people of Savannah, as a general thing, were loyal; but if only a few of them were true to the Union, the case was not altered. It was better that ten guilty rebels should be fed than one loyal man die of starvation. The enemy had left the people of Savannah in an exceedingly destitute condition. When, as has been remarked, Gen. SHERMAN found himself accidentally in the city and Gen. HARDEE accidentally out of the city, the people had nothing to eat. The speaker believed that the Union sentiment was not confined to Savannah, but extended throughout the State. He spoke of the meeting of citizens after the occupation of the city by Gen. SHERMAN, and said that hearty cheers were given for the Union and the President of the United States. It must not be thought, because many of the former residents of Savannah were in the rebel ranks, that the people were not at heart loyal. Those who were in JEFF. DAVIS' army were conscripts, and were compelled to fight under the rebel flag. Col. ALLEN concluded with an eloquent appeal to the citizens of New-York to send immediate relief to the destitute of Savannah. The Chairman said a letter had been received from the Committee of the Chamber of Commerce, which had been answered by the officers of the Exchange. The following is the correspondence:

abstract: THE COLD WEATHER ON THE COAST. -- The brig Argyle, from Maitland, Nova Scotia, Capt. SMITH, loaded with salt, arrived here on Tuesday and put in at Congress-street. The crew, consisting of colored men, were all frost-bitten. One of them, known as "Alfred," was killed by the falling of a spar during the storm on the 7th inst. The body of the deceased was brought on shore and an inquest was held by Coroner LYNCH. A verdict in accordance with the facts was rendered. The crew belong to Philadelphia, and all went on to that place yesterday.
lead_paragraph: THE COLD WEATHER ON THE COAST. -- The brig Argyle, from Maitland, Nova Scotia, Capt. SMITH, loaded with salt, arrived here on Tuesday and put in at Congress-street. The crew belong to Philadelphia, and all went on to that place yesterday.

abstract: -Mr. HENRY WARD, who has been appointed Superintendent of the city lines of the American Telegraph Company, has inaugurated a system of direct through connections of the wires, at the Fifth-avenue and other hotels, and the various city telegraph stations, so that the public can hereafter avail themselves of this important connection to telegraph direct from all these stations to Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington, Boston, and all other parts of the country. The same facilities are also extended to all the down stations of the city lines of the American Telegraph Company.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. COLLAMER introduced a bill relating to postal laws, which was referred to the Committee on Post-offices and Post Roads. Mr. COLLAMER also introducd a bill relating to clerkships in the Post-office, which was referred to Postal Committee. Various petitions for increase of the pay of army officers were presented by Messrs. WILSON, TRUMBULL and HARRIS, and were referred to the Military Committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. COLLAMER introduced a bill relating to postal laws, which was referred to the Committee on Post-offices and Post Roads. Mr. COLLAMER also introducd a bill relating to clerkships in the Post-office, which was referred to Postal Committee. Various petitions for increase of the pay of army officers were presented by Messrs. WILSON, TRUMBULL and HARRIS, and were referred to the Military Committee. Mr. DOOLITTLE presented a memorial from the Chamber of Commerce of Milwaukee, on the subject of canal navigation around the Falls of Niagara, which was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs. A bill was reported and passed providing that no person shall be allowed to draw a pension who is on the payroll of the Invalid Corps. A bill was passed to authorize the appointment of a Second Assistant Secretary of War. The House bill to advance line officers of the navy fifty numbers in rank for special merit was also passed. The Reciprocity Treaty was taken up and debated at some length. Messrs. HALE, RAMSEY and HOWE spoke strongly against the repeal of the treaty, and Messrs. SUMNER, SHERMAN and COLLAMER spoke in favor of it.

abstract: The Loss of; The steamer Mellville
snippet: The Loss of; The steamer Mellville
lead_paragraph: Following close upon the loss of the transport North America and its two hundred passengers, we have to chronicle to-day another disaster scarcely less heart-sickening, in the foundering of the steamship Melville, bound hence for Hilton Head. In both cases the record is the old stereotyped story of the boats being either launched too late, launched too hurriedly, or monopolized by the crew, to the utter and total disregard of the lives of the men, women and children registered as passengers.

abstract: Caledonian Club; Eighth Ball
snippet: Caledonian Club; Eighth Ball
lead_paragraph: The Eighth Annual Ball of the New-York Caledonian Club took place last evening, at the City Assembly Rooms. The ball-room was very neatly decorated. The balcony at the west end of the room was hung with the American colon and the club flag, and on the balcony at the opposite end of the room were displayed the tattered and war-worn colors of the veteran Seventy-ninth Regiment Highlanders. The Quadrille and Promenade band furnished some excellent music; and two bagpipes, played by the pipers of the club, gave forth their peculiar sounds, to the evident gratification of the merry Scotchmen. The members of the club were dressed in their national costume, and taeir numerous plaids and bright jewels contrasted beautifully with with the exquisite dresses of the ladies. The rooms were very well filled, and all present seemed to enter fully into the enjoyment of the evening. At the sound of the bugle the couples took their places promptly on the floor, and the dancing was conducted with great spirit throughout. There was no lack of partners, and the ladies needed no urging.

abstract: Carrying
snippet: Carrying
lead_paragraph: The thanks of the community will be due to the Police Justices if they carry out the resolution to which, it is said, they have come, of dealing summarily with persons carrying or attempting to use concealed weapons This practice is at the bottom of most of the cuttings, shootings and murders of which we now present nearly every day such an odious and disgraceful record. Policemen now make every arrest, for even trifling offences, at the risk of their lives; and it is impossible to resent, even in words, any outrage or insolence committed by the great army of ruffians with which the metropolis abounds, without exposing one's self to instant assassination. And, what is less to be regretted, a quarrel hardly ever occurs between the thieves and bullies of the grogshops, which does not end in a homicide. It is very rare, indeed, to hear of a life being taken in a city with such apparent coolness and unconcern and such complete apparent indifference to consequences, as that of HARRY LAZARUS, who, though one of a class whose very existence is a danger to our civilization, was still under the protection of the law.

abstract: -- By the European mail which arrived yesterday we have the text of a Bull which has just been issued from the Vatican at Rome, under the sign and seal apostolic of His Holiness the Pope. The letter denounces the pernicious writings of those who seek to overturn the foundations of the Catholic religion. Addressing the Bishops and clergy throughout the world, His Holiness reminds them that the promulgation of evil doctrines have excited "a horrible storm." He refers to former encyclical letters and allocutions in which he felt bound to denounce "the monstrous opinions which particularly predominate in the present day;" but as these letters and allocutions have not produced the desired effect, His Holiness makes this new appeal. Especially does he dwell with fervor on what he considers the false prevailing notions as to the relation of civil Government to the Church. Thus, he says, for example, that,

abstract: Melville, Steamship, Foundered at Sea
snippet: Melville, Steamship, Foundered at Sea
lead_paragraph: Bark Rechabite, of New-Glasgow, Capt. LEEMAN, from Ragged Island, Dec. 27, with salt to BRETT, SON & CO., arrived yesterday morning. On the 4th Inst., in lat. 32 long. 73, she picked up one bale of cotton. No date, lat. 30 42, long, 72 55, she spoke schooner J. Smith, ORLANDO, from Fortress Monroe for Wilmington, with sails split and loss of foreboom; supplied her with twine. On the 8th inst., lat 38 long. 74, about 3 A.M., the Captain reports that his attention was attracted by calls from the water. He lay to and lowered a boat, and after some searching discovered a piece of hurricane deck, part of a wreck, floating upon which was a man named ALBERT L. BAYDON. BAYDON stated that he had taken passage on board of one of WHITNEY & HATHAWAY's steamers, the Melville, which sailed from New-York on the 5th inst., bound to Hilton Head, and had encountered heavy southwest winds, with a heavy sea, until the 7th, when at about 9 P.M. the steamer's bows were stove in by the sea. The captain ordered a boat lowered, when he, the chief engineer, the first cook and one seaman, with several others, were swamped in it. The passengers, by bailing with buckets, were enabled to keep the vessel afloat until about 11 o'clock the next day. (Sunday morning,) when the remaining boat was lowered -- a metalic life-boat -- but before we could get the lady passengers into it, the Melville went down, port bow first, upsetting the life-boat. There was a vessel in sight from about 12 o'clock at night, which was seen often until we foundered, when she was seen no more. I saw a great many perish, and many clinging to pieces of the wreck. I was in company with the life-boat, and within hailing distance of her until about sunset. She was then free of water, and had only three persons in her -- I think two men and one lady; they answered my call, but kept clear of me. We were in sight of portions of the wreck until sunset. The boats' crew made no efforts to save any who were still clinging to the wreck. We even burned our mail, consisting of three newspaper bags and one letter bag, with all the matrasses and every combustible thing on board, to signalize the vessel in sight. We had about sixty-five passengers, five of them ladies, and about sixteen officers and crew.

lead_paragraph: -- The necessity of providing some means for making comfortable the soldiers who have to spend long, weary hours in waiting- for the train at the New-Haven Railroad Depot, has induced some of our philanthropic citizens to make an effort to supply this want. Col. GEORGE BLISS, Jr., informs us that a convenient building has been engaged, and an association of experienced ladies are ready to take charge of it as soon as it is fitted up. Contributions for this object may be sent to Col. BLISS, whose well-known character is a sufficient guarantee for their proper application.

abstract: THE QUOTA OF KINGS COUNTY. -- The committee of the Board of Supervisors who were authorized to proceed to Washington for the purpose of procuring a reduction of the quota, if possible, returned yesterday morning, and report that they were favorably received, and the assurance given that the quota would be fixed upon the basis of the number of men reported by the Supervisors. The committee, therefore, recommend that the correction of the enrollment lists be completed by Saturday next. If this is accomplished by that time, there will be a considerable reduction and no further trouble. It is understood that credits are also to be given for enlistments made previous to the 1st of December last.

abstract: RELIEF FOR SAVANNAH -- DONATIONS RECEIVED. -- The Rebecca Clyde is now loading with provisions for Savannah at Pier No. 14 East River, foot of Wall-street. All goods should be directed to AROHIBALD BAXTER, Chairman of Chamber of Commerce Committee. Yesterday the following donations were received and shipped on board the Clyde: 147 bbls. of flour; 200 bbls. salt meat; 75 bbls. corn meal; 180 sacks of [salt; 50 bbls. of beans; 5 bbls. beef hams; 10 drums codfish; 28 boxes cracker; 5 tierces hams: 5 bbls. lard. About 1,000 bbls. flour are expected for shipment by to-morrow-night.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going, to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, in made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared, commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports items of agricultural and domestic interest, complied from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Americans Naturalized in British Colonies not Protected out of
snippet: Americans Naturalized in British Colonies not Protected out of
lead_paragraph: The British Government has caused it to be officially announced through the Embassy at Washington that Americans, who have become naturalized subjects of the Queen in the colonies, are not entitled to British protection beyond the provincial lines. This is not an unexpected decision. But its operation at this crisis of affairs might produce some queer results. The Queen has one or two American denationalized citizens in her Councils to-day. One of them is Treasurer of all the Crown moneys in the neighboring Province. If he came here, and were to be drafted, what then? A Crown Minister high private in front of Petersburgh! And why not?

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a message from the President was read, and ordered to be printed, in relation to the agreement between the United States and Great Britain concerning the naval force on the lakes. The committee appointed to inquire if legislation was necessary to enable the President to call an extra session of Congress without giving sixty days' notice, have discovered that no notice is required. A resolution of inquiry into the cause of failure at Wilmington was adopted. The resolution to repeal the Reciprocity Treaty was taken up and debated. Messrs. HOWE, of Wisconsin, HALE, of New-Hampshire, and others spoke against, and Messrs. MORRILL, FOOTE and DOOLITTLE in favor of, the motion to repeal. A motion to refer the matter to the Judiciary Committee was lost. The yeas and nays were then called on the passage of the resolution, which was adopted by a vote of 31 to 8. A resolution was adopted to investigate the charges against Col. CHIVINGTON, who is accused of extreme cruelty toward the Indians in Colorado.

abstract: Hocker, John, by Street-Sweepers; Hecker, John, Assaulted by Street-sweepers
snippet: Hocker, John, by Street-Sweepers; Hecker, John, Assaulted by Street-sweepers
lead_paragraph: About noon yesterday, as Mr. JOHN HECKER was crossing the City Park with his counsel, for the purpose of attending court, where his injunction is to be argued, he was attacked by a number of street sweepers, who surrounded him and hustled him upon the steps leading to the Supreme Court chambers. One of the sweepers struck Mr. HECKER on the back of the neck and knocked him down, causing a cut on his face by the fall against the steps. Several gentlemen came to Mr. HECKER's assistance, and he retired into the court room while the doughty sweet sweepers vented their rage on his hat which had dropped off, and which was kicked about the Park until it was destroyed. Capt. THORNE and a strong force of police took possession of the passage ways leading to the court room, and removed all and had no business there. Mr. HECKER was taken into the Judge's private room, where he remained until the afternoon, when Mr. JOHN E. DEVLIN, the Corporation Counsel, came out on the court-room steps and requested the crowd to retire quietly to their homes; and informed them that probably by Saturday next all disputes about their pay would be settled.
headline: {'main': 'Assault on Mr. Hecker by Street Sweepers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Assault on Mr. Hecker by Street Sweepers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Negotiation and Jeff. Davis; Negotiations and Jeff Davis; Desire for a Respite
snippet: Negotiation and Jeff. Davis; Negotiations and Jeff Davis; Desire for a Respite
lead_paragraph: The idea of JEFFERSON DAVIS negotiating himself out of existence, or allowing himself to be negotiated out of existence, as President of the Southern Confederacy, is one which must be hard of entertainment by those who comprehend his character, or who have studied his rebellious career as it has appeared in his speeches, proclamations and deeds during the last four years; or who have noted the desperate expedients and projects he himself has set forth within a short time. If DAVIS has any prominent characteristics, they are self-possession, determination, energy -- a self-possession not to be affected by any event or circumstance, or course of events or combination of circumstances -- a determination which will scruple at nothing whatever to compass its ends -- an energy remorseless and unflagging, capable of executing, under any circumstances, whatsoever is dictated by necessity or his judgment. In the greatest stress of fortune, he has never given any sign of the least yielding; and, whoever among the rebels might at any moment be discouraged, he has always stood imperious and firm, hurling maledictions and defiance, and backing up his most desperately ferocious words by still more fiendishly ferocious deeds. He has had concentrated in his hands all the power that exists in the South; and over and again has he sworn that to the end, and to the last extremity, would he use all that power for the accomplishment of the purposes for which this great rebellion was projected, and has been for four years prosecuted. He has wielded and now wields those powers with a skill which even his enemies must pronounce consummate.
headline: {'main': 'The Question of Negotiation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Question of Negotiation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. FOLGER reported the State Bounty Bill. It allows $300 for one-year men, $400 for two-years' men, and $600 for three-years' men, and prohibits all local bounties. The majority of the committee favor the raising of the whole of the indebtedness thus to be created this year by taxation. The minority of the committee favor borrowing the amount of money required, the same to be paid within eighteen year's. The opinion of the Attorney-General on the legality of this proposed indebtedness was ordered to be obtained. The bill to repeal the fare restriction in the Railroad Consolidation Act was introduced. The argument in the contested seat case was then resumed, and continued until the recess.

abstract: the Cause of our Differences; and State Rights; and Slavery--Const. Amend; in Congress, Defending Slavery from Scripture; Constitutional Amendment and State Rights
snippet: the Cause of our Differences; and State Rights; and Slavery--Const. Amend; in Congress, Defending Slavery from Scripture; Constitutional Amendment and State Rights
lead_paragraph: The favorite argument of the Democrats in the House, who have time far spoken against the Constitutional amendment prohibiting slavery, is, that it is a violation of the inherent sovereign rights of the States; that, though it may not conflict with the bare letter of the Constitution, it is yet a usurpation by the majority of the States over a minority such as was never contemplated by the framers of the Constitution, and such as would have kept many States from acceding to the Constitution, had it ever been anticipated.

abstract: Regiments; Record in State Archives; Bill to Preserve records of New-York Regiments
snippet: Regiments; Record in State Archives; Bill to Preserve records of New-York Regiments
lead_paragraph: -- A bill has been introduced into the Assembly by Hon. SAMUEL C. REID, of this city, having for its object the preservation in the State archives, of the records of service in the field of all the New-York regiments. A work of this nature, properly collated, will be a patriotic legacy to posterity. The record of the New-York regiments, made during this war, is eminently brilliant and heroic, and one of which all our citizens may well be proud. In taking measures to prepare these regimental histories for publication and preservation, the Legislature obeys the dictates of the popular heart, and shows that New-York is among the first to officially recognise the bravery of her sons, as well as among the foremost to place them in the ranks for Union and Liberty.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. LAIMBEER presented a petition numerously signed by wealthy citizens of New-York, asking for an immediate investigation into the affairs of the city departments. Bills were reported favorably to confirm the Bounty Act of the New-York Supervisors; to incorporate the Studio Building Association of New-York; to amend the law relative to the assessment of bank stock.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. LAIMBEER presented a petition numerously signed by wealthy citizens of New-York, asking for an immediate investigation into the affairs of the city departments. Bills were reported favorably to confirm the Bounty Act of the New-York Supervisors; to incorporate the Studio Building Association of New-York; to amend the law relative to the assessment of bank stock. Bills were introduced, providing for the repayment of moneys illegally collected by the Health Commissioners of New-York; authorizing the Trustees of the Seaman's Fund and Retreat to borrow $30,000; making appropriations to the New-York Dispensaries; to enable qualified voters of this State in the military service of the United States to vote in the field, and whenever ten or more are together, they to choose their own Election Judges.

abstract: Ira Bride was tried in this Court yesterday upon an indictment for grand larceny. It appeared from the evidence that a rustic individual from Connecticut, anxious to see the sights in New-York, wandered into a concert saloon on Broadway on the night of the 3d of January last. While there he became acquainted with Miss Hattie Smith, one of the pretty waiter girls of the establishment. He yielded to her blandishments, and accompanied her to her home in Greene-street. In the dead hour of the night he was awakened by the flashing of a light in the room, and saw the prisoner in the act of stealing his vest, which contained the sum of $80. He was about to get up and seize Bride, but his friend Hattie suggested the prisoner had a revolver and would be apt to use it if he was molested. The complainant escaped to the street, procured the assistance of an officer, and had the whole party arrested. The jury convicted the prisoner, and he was sent to the State Prison for two years.
lead_paragraph: Ira Bride was tried in this Court yesterday upon an indictment for grand larceny. It appeared from the evidence that a rustic individual from Connecticut, anxious to see the sights in New-York, wandered into a concert saloon on Broadway on the night of the 3d of January last. abstract: The Cunard steamship China, with dates to the 1st inst., arrived here yesterday morning. The situation of SHERMAN in front of Savannah was the subject of most anxious expectation, as also the St. Albans robbery trials. The rebel loan had declined 6 per cent, under the pressure of the news received.
lead_paragraph: The Cunard steamship China, with dates to the 1st inst., arrived here yesterday morning. The situation of SHERMAN in front of Savannah was the subject of most anxious expectation, as also the St. Albans robbery trials. The rebel loan had declined 6 per cent, under the pressure of the news received. A great meeting had been held at Dublin, on the, subject of tenant rights and the Irish Protestant establishment. There was no disturbance. The British export trade shows an increase of 16 per cent for eleven of the mouths of 1864, against the same period of 1863. From France there is a report that 120,000 men of the Imperial army are to be put in the reserve force. The French papers generally severely criticise the Pope's Bull. It is said to be exceedingly offensive to the French Government. Our Paris letter, which we publish this morning, is of unusual interest. The Inman steamer Edinburgh, Capt. ROSKELL, which left Liverpool at 10:30 on the morning of the 28th and Queenstown on the 29th December, arrived here last nigh. Her news is anticipated.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented in behalf of the soldiers captured in the Streight raid into Georgia. It was referred to the Military Committee. A resolution was offered, and referred to the Military Committee, instructing the Secretary of War to report to the Senate the number of men furnished by the loyal States ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented in behalf of the soldiers captured in the Streight raid into Georgia. It was referred to the Military Committee. A resolution was offered, and referred to the Military Committee, instructing the Secretary of War to report to the Senate the number of men furnished by the loyal States under the call of the President in July last for 500,000 men. The Consular Appropriation Bill was taken up, and after being amended by inserting the words "Republic of," before the word Mexico, was passed. After some debate, the resolution of HARLAN, relative to charges against Col. CHIVINGTON, was adopted. The Senate then adjourned until Monday.

abstract: The Court Journal, not a reliable authority, by the way, in noticing the arrival out of Lord LYONS, says: "We cannot understand that the state of Lord LYONS' health alone is the cause of his departure from Washington; for he has, according to report, been put down for a berth at once, and will exchange with the present English Ambassador at Vienna. Doubtless the real secret of his retirement from Washington is the arduous nature of the duties he has had, and still would have, to perform to keep all smooth between England and the American Government."

lead_paragraph: As we greatly feared at first, the many rumors of peace we have had during the past week, have been steadily growing smaller, and are now altogether unpromising. One of the principal outgivings on the subject, we yesterday showed to be a pure concoction or a grievious misapprehension; and the resolutions of Mr. MILES in the Confederate Congress would seem to throw doubt even on the statement that fifteen Commissioners had been appointed to confer with the North on the subject of peace. As to the alleged mission of the Elder BLAIR, we have nothing further except a statement of the Richmond Dispatch of Thursday last, that up to that time he had not made his appearance in the Confederate capital. "He has not," says the Dispatch,

abstract: Queen of Spain's Speech on; Ministerial Crisis. Peruvian Question; Narvaez Policy on Peru
snippet: Queen of Spain's Speech on; Ministerial Crisis. Peruvian Question; Narvaez Policy on Peru
lead_paragraph: The Spanish ministerial crisis is past, and NARVAEZ and his colleagues are again in office. On the resignation of the Duke of VALENCIA, Senor ISTURIEZ was sent for by the Queen, and instructed to form a Cabinet. This he undertook to do, and nearly accomplished; but when ISABELLA learned that the men whom he had called to power had not the confidence of the dominant party in the Cortes, and would be sure to involve her in trouble, she decided, rather than intrust them with the reins of government, to effect a reconciliation with NARVAEZ, and allow him to resume the conduct of affairs. The Ex-Minister was accordingly summoned to the Palace, and, after mutual explanations between him and his Sovereign, was induced to withdraw his resignation and become State helmsman once more.

lead_paragraph: CITY NOTES. -- The steamship Arago, from Port Royal, S.C., brought up seventy-eight bags of letters, thirty of which were from the soldiers of Gen. SHERMAN'S army. The steamship Ajax left this port yesterday for Savannah, taking eighty bags of letters and newspapers... Rev. JOSEPH P. DURYEA will deliver a discourse to-morrow evening at the Collegiate Church, Lafayette place, by invitation of the Young Men's Christian Association, on "Recreations of the Young."....Prof. J.E. FROBISHER will give readings and recitations this evening before the Cooper Union Literary Class.... The annual meeting of the New-York State Military Association will be held at Albany on Tuesday evening ... EDGAR CONKLING, Esq., special agent of the Ohio Relief Commission, to procure aid for Southern White Refugees. Is in town. He seeks means wherewith to furnish seeds and farming implements to the needy people of the Border States, whose homes have been devastated by the tide of battle.... DANIEL EWEN, a well-known city surveyor, died on Thursday night at his residence, corner of Rutgers-street and East Broadway, at the age of 69 years. He was a brother of Gen. JOHN EWEN.

abstract: -A.D. RICHARDSON, Esq., of the Tribune, who was captured by the rebels while running the batteries at Vicksburgh nearly two years ago, announces by telegraph, from Knoxville, his arrival in the Union lines at that point. We cannot tell whether Mr. RICHARDSON was exchanged or whether he escaped, though the latter would seem most probable. Mr. RICHARDSON has had a terrible two years' experience in the very bowels of the Confederacy, and his friends will congratulate him most heartily upon his escape.

abstract: There are some marvellously graceful and pleasing pen-and-ink sketches by Miss JULIA WILLARD on exhibition at MACFARLAND's bookstore, corner of Twenly-third-street and Broadway. These sketches comprise a great variety of subjects. Including animal life, forest glades, purling brooks and rustic bridges, but in all of them the drawing is facile and vigorous, the grouping picturesque, and the shading so exquisitely delicate that it would bear microscopic inspection and scarce lose any of the softness of its finish. Miss WILLARD prepared an album of her sketches for the Now-York Sanitary Fair last Spring, the sale of which added handsomely to the receipts at the booth of the Twelfth-street Grammar School for Young Ladies, in which institution she is beloved and honored teacher.

abstract: M. Kaussman on; Prefect of the Seine, on Elections; The, and their Prefect
snippet: M. Kaussman on; Prefect of the Seine, on Elections; The, and their Prefect
lead_paragraph: The Municipal Council of Paris having obtained a new lease of office from the Emperor, M. KAUSSMAN, Prefect of the Seine, and their chief, thought it incumbent on him, at their first reunion, to address them touching the nature and importance of their duties, and the advantages of their being the nominees of NAPOLEON, rather than the elected representatives of the Parisian populace. M. KAUSSMAN took a very effective way of impressing on the minds of the Councilors the conviction of the vast superiority of the appointment system. For he assured them that, if the system of election had been in vogue, it was highly probable that not a man of them would have been chosen. The natives of the metropolis of fashion and civilization had been weighed in the balance and [???]ound wanting. It had been demonstrated that they did not possess intellect, or acumen, or discernment enough to select proper municipal representatives. Nay, they could not even appreciate the merits of those whom their Sovereign had been graciously pleased to choose for them. But this was not to be wondered at. The Parisians are, in fact, not Parisians. The capital of the Second Empire, according to M. KAUSSMAN, has no "large permanent population." The mass of its citizens are "mere crowds, who come and go," and know nothing of municipal interests, or municipal affairs. While the few, who boast of being Parisians pur sang, "are isolated from each other, change with extreme facility their lodgings and quarters, and never attach themselves to the mairie of an arrondissement, or the parochial church."
headline: {'main': 'The Parisians and Their Prefect.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Parisians and Their Prefect.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: and Lee owned Secession was Wrong; Denies Drunkenness; Letters of Resignation and to his sister; South, Element of Disunion; Gen. A Glimpse of; Davis calls a miserable scoundrel; elected Senator from Arkansas
snippet: and Lee owned Secession was Wrong; Denies Drunkenness; Letters of Resignation and to his sister; South, Element of Disunion; Gen. A Glimpse of; Davis calls a miserable scoundrel; elected Senator from Arkansas
lead_paragraph: There is no man associated with the Confederate cause in whom the Southern people have so great confidence, as Gen. LEE. Yet, of all the Southern leaders, he is the most taciturn. The attitude of silence which he has maintained has been a serious habit, and not a bare theatrical assumption, as in the case of weaker men. Even the position which he holds to-day, is not one for which he has striven, or which, having obtained, he consciously assumes, as more ambitious men would have done; and he has shown none of that calculating sagacity which awaits opportunity for self-advancement. It can scarcely be denied that, from the first, his counsel has been often overborne even in the adjustment of policies, where his judgment ought to have been commanding; but he has never exclaimed at the reverses which have followed upon the mistakes of those higher in authority. He has not shown irritation, nor thrown up his commission. He has not, like DAVIS and LETCHER, and TOOMBS, and BEAUREGARD bristled with manifestoes. As a military man, he has not been prodigal of promises, and his dispatches have been decent. Like all the rest, he has been a traitor; but the venom and fanaticism of their treason has not been exhibited in his career. In a bad and ruinous cause, he has yet shown himself simply a soldier.

lead_paragraph: The contributions of our citizens for the relief of the destitute people of Savannah fully sustain the noble reputation of New-York for philanthropy. The committees appointed by the Chamber of Commerce and the Produce Exchange have been exceedingly successful in obtaining large subscriptions, most willingly made, from our merchants and business men generally. Already the hold of the Rebecca Clyde is nearly filled with provisions, and when she sails, which will probably be as early as Tuesday next, she will take out not less than 1,700 barrels of flour, beside an assorted cargo of that meats, beans, bread and not a few luxuries. Mr. BAXTER, of the Chamber of Commerce, is devoting most of his time to the loading of the Clyde, and pier No. 14, East River, presents a more than usually busy scene. Col. ALLEN seems to be endeavoring to outvie the committees in his efforts to promote the good work. The Government has placed under his control the steam-transport Daniel Webster, and up to yesterday he had purchased on his own account $40,000 worth of provisions. The Colonel is also receiving donations dally, and the indications are that the Daniel Webster will be ready for sea nearly, if not quite, as soon as the Clyde. Many of our citizens, too modest to have their names brought prominently before the public, have liberally contributed money anonymously, and letters inclosing greenbacks signed "A Friend," "Cash," &c., are not infrequently received. In addition to the acknowledgment of subscriptions already published, Mr. S.D. BABCOCK, Treasurer of the Relief Fund, reports the following:

abstract: Among the emigrants landed at Castle Garden, yesterday, by the steamship Great Western, from Liverpool, were ninety-three Englishmen who shipped for the avowed purpose of enlisting in the United States Army. Immediately after reaching the Government dock, they visited Supervisor BLUNT at his recruiting Station, on the Battery Grounds, and were examined. About forty of them "passed muster," and were paid their bounties and sworn in.

abstract: and Northern Retaliation
snippet: and Northern Retaliation
lead_paragraph: -- A telegraphic dispatch from Washington ascribes to the President the threat that, if the rebel authorities "harm" their fugitive Member of Congress, H.S. FOOTE, he will retaliate upon "five of the most distinguished rebel prisoners in our hands." This strikes us as simply absurd. What have we to do with FOOTE, any more than with any other adherent of the rebel Government? True, he has become disgusted with secession, and was trying to secure his personal safety by escaping within our lines. But that gives him no more claim upon us than any other deserter has, and we certainly do not threaten "retaliation" for punishments the rebels inflict upon their soldiers for attempted desertion. It is unfortunate for Mr. FOOTE that he can't get away; but he could easily have avoided that difficulty by never joining the rebels. Having done so, he must stand the consequences. Neither the President nor anybody else in authority, we venture to say, has ever made the remark ascribed to him. If Mr. FOOTE succeeds in reaching Washington, he will probably find himself under arrest, as one of the active and responsible leaders in the rebel cause, though he may doubtless count safely on the Executive clemency. But until he does come, he has certainly no claim to the protection or aid of the Government.

abstract: Health and Health Wardens
snippet: Health and Health Wardens
lead_paragraph: Since the 1st of January, 1864, there have been over twelve hundred cases of typhus fever in the most crowded and needy districts of this city. This dreadful disease has sometimes swept through whole blocks, scourging family after family of poor laborers. From these quarters, it has spread to more wealthy streets, and has been carried by persons to the country, during the last Summer, so that far more cases of it have occurred in the rural districts of our State this year than in any previous year.

abstract: and Gen. Butler's Removal; Butler, Gen. at Wilmington
snippet: and Gen. Butler's Removal; Butler, Gen. at Wilmington
lead_paragraph: Some of our cotemporaries deem it necessary, or find it agreeable, to contest the justice of Gen. BUTLER'S removal, and to treat that act as due to professional jealousy or personal hostility on the part of Gen. GRANT and Secretary STANTON. This is simply absurd, and will only damage the person it is intended to serve. We regret that Gen. BUTLER himself should have so far yielded to personal resentment and forgotten what was due to the proprieties of his position as to impute to still worse motives his removal from command. In his farewell address to the troops who had been under his orders, he seeks to impress upon them the belief that he was removed because he had not exposed them to useless slaughter. We trust that he has good sense enough to regret having made so absurd and criminal an intimation.
headline: {'main': 'Gen. Butler at Wilmington.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Gen. Butler at Wilmington.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- More than a million of dollars have been received in marine and fire premiums by this company during the past year. With assets exceeding seven hundred and fifty thousand, its receipts have been greater than triple its capital. It has just declared a dividend of ten per cent. to its stockholders, payable on demand, and a scrip dividend of fifty per cent. to its profit-sharing patrons. Both fire and marine company, its operations in each branch are nearly equal, the marine slightly preponderating. Losses were liquidated in 1864 to the amount of nearly four hundred thousand, and the surplus fund is almost half a million. The business in the last twelve months was double that of the preceding year, and two hundred thousand have been added to its assets. The company was organized in 1854, and has been eleven years in active operation. Under enterprising and judicious management, it has attained its present importance, with a capital of three hundred thousand. Insurers are reimbursed in gold if the premiums are similarly paid, and seventy-five per cent. of the net profits are returned to the participating customers. The office is well represented in all the principal cities of the country, its agents numbering almost three hundred. -- Journal of Commerce.

abstract: Atlantic Progress of; Progress of
snippet: Atlantic Progress of; Progress of
lead_paragraph: A letter from GEORGE SAWARD, Esq., Secretary and General Superintendent of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, to CYRUS W. FIELD, Esq., after alluding to the absolute electrical perfection of the cable now being manufactured, states the amount completed up to the 30th of December at 750 miles. The cable is now being manufactured at the rate of eighty miles per week, without hurry and without nightwork. It will be finished by the end of the first week in June. Two tanks on board the Great Eastern, for the stowage of the cable, are constructed, and the third is rapidly progressing. There is no reason to doubt that the cable will be all on board, and the great ship ready for sea, with every appliance of the best kind, and in the best order, during the month of June. Mr. SAWARD has no doubt that the cable will be successfully laid and worked.

abstract: San Jacinto; The Loss of; on Bahama Banks
snippet: San Jacinto; The Loss of; on Bahama Banks
lead_paragraph: By the United States transport Continentals which sailed from Key West on the 10th inst. and arrived at this port yesterday morning, we learn that the steam sloop-of-war San Jacinto, Capt. R.W. MEADE commanding, was lost on the morning of the 1st inst., on a reef off No-Name Key, on the Bahama Banks. The day previous to her wreck she had been chasing a blockade-runner, which escaped by reaching neutral waters. Darkness coming on, the San Jacinto stood in shore with the hope that during the night the blockade-runner would stand out for the Hole-in-the-Wall.

abstract: Spitz-Kugchi; New German Paper; New-Yorker Music Zeitung; New Paper
snippet: Spitz-Kugchi; New German Paper; New-Yorker Music Zeitung; New Paper
lead_paragraph: The various places of amusement are getting along so comfortably, and the city is content with so little excitement just now, that the managers have prudently resolved to let well alone. Novelties, we know, are in absolute readiness at three of our leading theatres, but while the public continues to crowd those same theatres it would be folly to make an alteration in their programmes. Hence we have nothing in the way of novelty to announce to-day. "Hamlet" continues to be the attraction at the Winter Garden; the old Comedies at Wallack's; the "Streets of New-York" at the Olympic; the "Shamrock" at Niblo's; "Solon Shingle" and the "Live Indian" at the Broadway; the "Ring of Fate" and the Pantomime of "Blue Beard" at the Hippotheatron. We have recently referred to the new additions at the Menagerie, and need only add that the animals are now in fine condition, ROBERT HELLER, at the Salle Diabolique, offers to-night a selection of sensations; some classical illusions, and three new piano-forte solos.

abstract: Relief and Northern Goodwill; and Rebellion now Identical; Northern Good Will to South (Savannah Relief)
snippet: Relief and Northern Goodwill; and Rebellion now Identical; Northern Good Will to South (Savannah Relief)
lead_paragraph: The Rebecca Clyde left this harbor, and the Greyhound left Boston, on Saturday, laden with provisions and other necessaries for the suffering people of Savannah. The Daniel Webster will leave our docks to-morrow or next day on the same errand. Large contributions for the same purpose are being made in Philadelphia and other Northern cities. Whilst this relief is going forward, it is important that the South should distinctly understand that in no sense has it had a party origin. The conductors of the enterprise, and the hundreds who have subscribed to the funds, have acted independently of all their party connections. Republicans and Democrats, war men and peace men, vied with each other in the good work. If there is any difference, it lies in favor of those who voted for Mr. LINCOLN at the recent election. It could be easily shown, we think, that from that side are the largest number of contributors and the greatest amount of contributions. But we do not care to go into any such inquiry. It is enough for the Southern people to know that this succor comes from no party source and has no party object -- that it is a free, whole-souled offering of Northern goodwill, a guerdon that we are ready, with heart and hand, to welcome back those who have been estranged from us.
headline: {'main': 'A Pledge of Northern Good-Will.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Pledge of Northern Good-Will.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ROBBED AND SENT TO THE HOUSE OF DETENTION. -- THOMAS BROWN went to a lodging-house in Baxter-street, on Thursday night last, and was robbed of $1,220 in gold and $15 in currency. He made his loss known to Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct, and JOSEPHINE MILLER, HANNAH MILLER and JOSEPHINE SANDS were arrested and $734 in currency were recovered. The prisoner's statement is that one WM. MCGRANE and JOSEPHINE MILLER committed the robbery; that MCGRANE gave her a handful of gold as her share; that she deposited the same in the hands of JOSEPHINE SANDS, and that the latter exchanged the gold. The prisoners were committed by Justice HOGAN to the Tombs, and the complainant was sent to the House of Detention.

abstract: Edward, Death of
snippet: Edward, Death of
lead_paragraph: We are startled this morning by the announcement of the sudden death of EDWARD EVERETT. He died of apoplexy yesterday morning, at his residence in Boston. Mr. EVERETT has latterly held no public position, but his death will create as much deep and respectful regret as if he had held the highest office in the land. His accomplishment as a scholar, his eloquence as an orator, his public services as a patriot and his personal qualities as a man, have commanded for him the universal respect and esteem of his countrymen. No young man ever entered more brilliantly or with more deserved applause than he upon the public career which was so long and so honorable -- nor were the promises of youth ever more completely fulfilled than in his instance. Mr. EVERETT was almost the last of the great orators of this country. He had cultivated eloquence as an art. Everything he said, whether the occasion was great or trivial, was the best, and was said in the best style and manner, which the most careful and conscientious preparation could devise. All the resources of his splendid scholarship were made tributary to the completeness and effect of his public speeches. Some of his orations will stand permanently as the very best productions of American eloquence, not merely in a single department, but on all the various topics, of which he seemed to be equally master; and all his writings are characterized by eminent clearness and purity of style, and the utmost grace and felicity of language. But Mr. EVERETT's strongest claim upon the affectionate gratitude of the American people, lies in the complete and absolute consecration of the last years of his life to the cause of his country. Previous to the outbreak of the rebellion, foreseeing its imminence, and despairing of the ability of any party or political successes to avert it, he devoted himself, with all his heart and strength, to a systematic appeal to the patriotism of the people, as embodied in their love for the memory of WASHINGTON; and from the moment the existence of the Government was threatened by armed insurrection, he brought every faculty of his mind, and every energy of his soul to its defence. With a degree of laborious industry which find few parallels, he has used his voice and his pen upon every opportune occasion, and with eminent ability, in support of the Government, and in aid of every movement to increase its energy, or supply the necessities and relieve the sufferings of those engaged in its defence. It would not be easy to name any man to whose labors, within his proper sphere, the country is more largely indebted than to Mr. EVERETT. He has spent a long and laborious life in the service of the public; he had reached a ripe age before his labors were interrupted, and his memory will be held in lasting honor by his grateful countrymen.
headline: {'main': 'Death of Edward Everett.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Death of Edward Everett.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Brownell, Bishop; Obituary
snippet: Brownell, Bishop; Obituary
lead_paragraph: The Right Rev. THOMAS CHURCH BROWNELL, D.D.LL.D., who departed this life at his residence in Hartford, on Friday morning at 5 o'clock, in the 80th year of his age, was born at Little Compton, R.I., in 1779. He graduated at Union College, Schenectady, N.Y., in which college he was for a time afterward Professor of Chemistry and Natural History. He made on foot, while a young man, what is known as "the tour of Europe." Returning home he became a Presbyterian clergyman, which position he occupied until he was nearly forty years of age. In 1817 he was made a Deacon in the Protestant Episcopal Church, and in the following year was made a Priest. In 1819 he was consecrated Bishop and was supposed to be the oldest Protestant Bishop in the world. He has been the presiding Bishop of the United States for the last ten years. He was Bishop of the Connecticut Diocese up to the date of his death, although, on account of having broken his leg some ten years age, which disabled him from active service, he has not discharged the active duties of the office since that accident happened. During his life he was prominently connected with several important institutions in the State. For many years past he has been President of the Insane Retreat. Trinity College numbers him among its founders. From the time of the establishment of the college, in 1823, to the year 1831, he was its President, and to the time of his death was its Chancellor. He was also active in founding the Connecticut Historical Society. Bishop HOPKINS, of Vermont, being the oldest Bishop surviving, will become the successor of Bishop BROWNELL as presiding Bishop of the United States, and Assistant Bishop JOHN WILLIAMS will succeed him as Bishop of the Diocese of Connecticut.

abstract: Matches to Come
snippet: Matches to Come
lead_paragraph: A match game for the championship of America and the possession of the golden cue, between DUDLEY KAVANAGH, its present custodian, and WILLIAM GOLDTHWAIT, who expects to take charge of the muchcoveted emblem, will take place at the Academy of Music, on the evening of Friday next, the 20th inst. KAVANAGH achieved the championship at the great National Tournament, in June, 1863, when he encountered seven of the most expert players in this country, and was successful in every game save one. Since that occasion he has maintained his supremacy in four single contests, the present being the fifth attempt to wrest the honors from his grasp. He is well known as one of the most brilliant living demonstrators of the game of billiards. COLDTHWAITE has, for some time past, been looked upon as a successful rival to KAVANAGH, his manipulations in the specialty being equally remarkable. At a contest between these parties in June list. COLDTHWAITE maintained a large advantage until near the close of the game, when he seemed to become enervated, and KAVANAGH, by his superior physique, was enabled to secure the victory by seventy-eight points in a score of fifteen hundred. Although the contest was nearly equal on that occasion, the friends of KAVANAGH still have unlimited confidence in his ability to vanquish GOLDTHWAITE, or any other player at the American game; and for the match of Friday evening, offer any reasonable amount at an odds of $100 to $75; yet, even at this difference there is little speculation. Notwithstanding this match several times has been unavoidably postponed, it is now arranged under most favorable auspices, and will no doubt prove a brilliant seance. Many persons have already applied for reserved seats and private boxes, and it is presumed a large number of ladies will grace the occasion.

abstract: Criminal Prosecutions in New-York
snippet: Criminal Prosecutions in New-York
lead_paragraph: -- As we recently took occasion to make certain criticisms on the lax administration of justice in this city in criminal cases, we now note with pleasure an improvement in this respect. Mr. OAKEY HALL, prosecuting officer of the county, stated upon the trial of IRA GARADIER on Thursday last, that "the public expected punishment to be swift in following the conviction of a guilty party, and it was due to them that it should be so." In the case of FRIARY, brought up for trial yesterday for the murder of LAZARUS, the District Attorney so strenuously and successfully resisted an application for delay, that the prisoner's counsel were obliged to obtain it for their client by the unusual method of throwing up their briefs and withdrawing from the case. The court seconded the District-Attorney by promptly assigning other counsel and ordering the trial to proceed to-day. Let such examples be followed. Let justice shake off her leaden wings and swoop upon the criminal with swift certainty, and our good city will soon be reduced from its present state of chronic riot to a quiet and peaceable abode for orderly citizens.

abstract: Renewed Attack on
snippet: Renewed Attack on
lead_paragraph: The rebels, on Friday last, were probably as much startled by the fact, as the people of this city were yesterday astonished by the news, of another naval and military attack on Wilmington. It is just what they might have expected, however, had they taken into consideration the cause of failure in our last attempt, or the character of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT. The dispatches of GRANT, published on Saturday last, show that he it is who has the main direction of this matter, and those who recall the incidents of his military career, and especially the Vicksburgh episode, know very well that when he has set his heart on the execution of a work, it is not one failure that will induce him to give it up. Then again the cause of the failure three weeks ago -- which is ascribed by Gen. GRANT to the delay resulting from the gunpowder experiment -- is one which furnishes no argument whatever adverse to the feasibility of perfect success now.

abstract: Vigorous offensive operations against Fort Fisher and the defences of Wilmington have already been resumed. Admiral PORTER'S fleet left Beaufort, N.C., on the 10th, and on the 13th was reported by a rebel dispatch from Wilmington to be again off Fort Fisher, with a smooth sea.
lead_paragraph: Vigorous offensive operations against Fort Fisher and the defences of Wilmington have already been resumed. Admiral PORTER'S fleet left Beaufort, N.C., on the 10th, and on the 13th was reported by a rebel dispatch from Wilmington to be again off Fort Fisher, with a smooth sea. The flag-of-truce steamer New-York, from Richmond on Saturday, brings a report that the attack had actually been renewed. A large land force, considerably increased over that in the late demonstration, accompanies the expedition, and is under the immediate command of Maj. Gen. TERRY, though it is not unlikely that an officer of still greater prominence has general direction of affairs.

abstract: Information has been received in this city of the arrest of Ex-Gov. HENRY S. FOOEE, at Occoquan, in Prince William County. The charge upon which the arrest was made has not yet been made public. It is understood to have been without instruction from the authorities in this city. Whether, being made. It received their approval, we are not informed. Ex-Gov. FOOTE has not occupied his seat in the House of Representatives for two or three weeks. In his last speech in that body, he announced his purpose to withdraw from its deliberations and "retire to some requestered spot where he could enjoy repose from the embarrassment of the times." In a few days after this he went toward the Potomac for the purpose of sending his family across that they might reach their home in Nashville. He has not since been in this city. We forbear comment on the arrest until the facts are better known.

abstract: San Jacinto, Wreck of, Further Particulars
snippet: San Jacinto, Wreck of, Further Particulars
lead_paragraph: The United States steam sloop-of-war San Jacinto, rendered famous as being the vessel which, in November, 1861, under command of Capt. WILKES, took from on board the British steamer Trent the rebel commissioners, SLIDELL and MASON, when on their way as Ministers of the Southern Confederacy to France and England, was wrecked on a reef of No Name Key, on the Bahama Banks, on the morning of the 1st inst., particulars of which were published in yesterday's TIMES.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented, asking that the rebel prisoners now in Northern prisons be placed under the care and control of discharged Union prisoners, and be furnished with the same rations and clothing furnished Union prisoners in the South. On motion of Mr. HOWARD, the matter was referred to the Military Committee. Mr. SUMMER offered a resolution in regard to the expediency of giving Her British Majesty's Government the notice required for the termination of the Extradition Treaty. The resolution was adopted. A bill was introduced, and referred to the Committee on Commerce, relative to commerce between the loyal and rebel States. A communication was received from the Secretary of the Interior, in reference to Pension Agents.

abstract: Knoedler's Gallery; Reopening of
snippet: Knoedler's Gallery; Reopening of
lead_paragraph: Mr. KNOEDLER reopens his gallery (No. 772 Broadway) to-day. It has been closed during the past few days for the purpose of hanging an entirely new collection of French and Belgian pictures. We have had a brief opportunity of examining some of these works. They are small in number, but most excellent in merit. Indeed we have seldom seen, in a gallery where every frame is for sale, a more uniformly good gathering of the first class artists.

abstract: BARNUM's MUSEUM. -- The eminently successful spectacle of "The Ring of Fate" -- one of the most beautiful productions that Mr. BARNUM has yet, in the plenteousness of his disposition, given to the public -- will be withdrawn from the programme after the present week. It is a work of real holiday merit and has been placed upon the stage in a way that reflects credit even on this admirably-conducted establishment. A new local piece is in preparation here, of which we already hear favorable rumors.

abstract: -- There will be a meeting at the Mayor's office to-day at noon, of civil engineers, railroad men and others, for the consideration of a plan that will be presented for the relief of carmen and the traveling public from the delays and damages caused by the use of the present kind of city carrails....A meeting is announced for this evening in which a number of our ministers, of various denominations, will set forth the methods of City Evangelization, for the information of the community generally, and for the purpose of calling out a more generous sympathy and a greater amount of personal effort in this direction....The New-York Typographical Society, now in its fifty-sixth year, will commemorate the One Hundred and Fifty-ninth Anniversary of BENJAMIN FRANKLIN's birthday, by musical and literary exercises this evening, at No. 3 Chambers-street. ....Bishop PORTER has appointed the following Presbytors of this city as a delegation to attend the funeral of Bishop BROWNELL, at Hartford, to-day: Rector of Trinity, Dr. DIX, Rev. Dr. HAIGHT, Rev. Dr. PRICE, Rev. Dr. MUHLENBERG and Rev. Dr. MORGAN....Mrs. BLACKWELL, who is to lecture at Clinton Hall, this evening, made herself famous a few years ago, for her eloquent advocacy of Woman's Rights, while she was Miss ANTOINETTE L. BROWN....Miss BRIDGET O'DONOHUE, who accidentally tell overboard from a Staten Island ferry-boat at Quarantine Landing on Sunday last, was rescued from drowning by Mr. PAUL CORNELL, of the shipnews department. CORNELL gallantly plunged into the water, regardless of its frigid temperature, and sustained the young woman until relief came to both of them....Hon. E.G. SQUIER will address the Farmer's Club of the American Institute this day, at 1 1/2 o'clock P.M., at the rooms of the Institute in the Cooper Union Building, on "The Agriculture of Peru."

abstract: Expediency of Repealing; Reciprocity Treaty; Expediency of Repealing; Expediency of Repealing
snippet: Expediency of Repealing; Reciprocity Treaty; Expediency of Repealing; Expediency of Repealing
lead_paragraph: When the Chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations suggests an inquiry into the expediency of terminating a treaty with a friendly Power, we presume, as a rule, that there is reason to doubt the fairness of its operation. We presume also, as a general principle, that the proposed inquest has the approval of the Executive. We have found at least in two very recent instances of a notable kind, that in the matter of the suspension or abrogation of important conventions between Great Britain and the United States, there has been perfect accord between the Executive and both houses of Congress. The appearance of rebel pirates on the lakes has compelled us to terminate the convention by which both Powers were prevented from maintaining naval armaments thereon. The questionable neutrality of the British colonial authorities -- quite as much as the inequitable operation of the Convention of 1854 -- has determined the fate of the Reciprocity Treaty. The revival of the passport system belongs logically to the same train of events. And no one who is careful to study the rapidity with which great measures succeed each other in reevolutionary times, will be surprised on finding in the Congressional report this morning, that the first step has been taken toward putting an end to the Ashburton Treaty.

abstract: Travels of a Hotelkeeper; Police--Corson, >amp;c., Humbug of
snippet: Travels of a Hotelkeeper; Police--Corson, >amp;c., Humbug of
lead_paragraph: Gen. DIX and his subordinates have had an object in view in striving, as they have done since the night of the incendiary attempt to lay our city in ashes, to create the impression that they were making no movements with a view to the apprehension of the incendiaries. And the event proves their action to have been judicious at least, if not the most gratifying that the newsmongers could have conceived for, now that the vail has been partially lifted, we discover four prisoners against whom the accumulated proofs are said to be overwhelming, and learn that our officials have gathered such facts as will enable them, in due time, to establish a clear case against many another rebel who now reposes in fancied security.

abstract: The Rumors of; Army must be Defeated before Peace
snippet: The Rumors of; Army must be Defeated before Peace
lead_paragraph: We reiterate the conviction we have already expressed, that the reports of attempted or intended negotiations for peace, which are so diligently pressed upon public notice, are utterly without foundation. We see nothing here or at Washington to give them the slightest claim to the slightest credit. Unless the most explicit assurances in the highest quarters are utterly unreliable, neither Mr. BLAIR, nor Mr. SINGLETON, nor anybody else has gone to Richmond, either to open negotiations with the rebel Government or to sound the rebel officials as to their wishes and expectations in regard to peace. That Mr. BLAIR being at Richmond will talk about peace is very likely; and it is possible, though not at all probable, that he will learn from Mr. DAVIS and, Company something on this subject, which we do not know already. Mr. BLAIR sought permission to go to Richmond exclusively on the plea of private business; and he has no shadow of authority, director indirect, to say one syllable on behalf of the Government concerning terms of peace.
headline: {'main': 'The Rumors of Peace.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rumors of Peace.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The news of the capture of Fort Fisher, given officially and in detail this morning, following so closely on the heels of the late failure, will surprise and delight the country. It was accomplished on Sunday afternoon and evening, by a joint assault of the army and navy after the fort had been subject to a furious bombardment of two days by Admiral PORTER's fleet. The assault was protracted in its character, the fighting lasting from 3 P.M. to 10 P.M. before the entire defences were finally secured. The entire garrison, 2,500 strong, were captured, including Gen. WHITING and Col. LAMB, two leading officers, who were both wounded. The number of guns captured is 72, every battery on the point being taken. The rebels lost heavily in killed, and our loss is 900 killed and wounded. Among the wounded are Gen. CURTIS, and Cols. PEANYBACKER and BELL, all commanding brigades. The rebel pirates Tallahassee and Chickamauga were in the fight, and both driven up the river. Our gunboats went up the river on Monday. Wilmimington is thus sealed and another nail driven in the coffin of the rebellion.

abstract: Stupendous Combinations; Victory at and Grant's Combinations; Victory Baste s
snippet: Stupendous Combinations; Victory at and Grant's Combinations; Victory Baste s
lead_paragraph: The victory won by our army and navy at Wilmington on Sunday last, is one of the greatest and most important we have ever achieved. The damage is crushing beyond compute to the Southern Confederacy. The place lies about midway between the positions occupied by our great armies on the Savannah and on the James; and its bearings are as wide as the region of country between these rivers, in which the conclusive campaigns of GRANT and SHERMAN must now be speedily brought to their culmination and consummation.

abstract: -- Now that Gen. SHERMAN is so near to Charleston, it will be seen by our rebel extracts that the Mercury of that city pronounces a glowing and elaborate eulogium upon him and his army. Its admiration is unbounded. But it is very severe upon the rebel troops thereabouts, whom it describes as a lawless mob, and characterizes as "ruffians." We find articles in the Courier to the same effect. Both these journals are in a terrible rage with their leaders and their so-called soldiers; and will doubtless be greatly rejoiced when SHERMAN, whom they so much admire, pays them a visit with his army, which they so profoundly worship. Is this really South Carolina?

abstract: Col. YOUNG's cadets, 40 in number, from the New-York Volunteer Institute at Suspension Bridge, arrived in this city, via the Erie Railroad, yesterday morning. The cadets are all well, and have met with the greatest hospitality in every town they have passed by the way. Their headquarters for one week will be at No. 648 Broadway, where they will be happy to receive their friends....The time for receiving proposals at the office of the Army Clothing and Equipage Bureau, Philadelphia, for furnishing supplies to the Government, has been extended to 12 M. on Wednesday, the 25th inst....Notwithstanding the storm, there was skating yesterday on the Fifth-avenue pond, Maj. OATMAN having kept a strong force of laborers constantly plying their brooms. The ice on all the ponds will doubtless be in good condition to-day.

snippet: Editor of did not Intend Visiting Richmond; Discussions; The Tribune; to Richmond Injurious; N. Y, and Peace Mission to Richmond; Tribune says Gov. does not insist on
lead_paragraph: Our neighbors of the Tribune continue to be sanguine as to the beneficial results of the alleged peace mission of the senior member of the house of BLAIR to the rebel authorities in Richmond. As we believe that mission to have been purely imaginary, we do not share in these hopeful anticipations. Indeed the Tribune itself seems to be in something of a fog as to the exact nature of the service which Mr. BLAIR is supposed to have rendered. Upon one point only does it seem to be clear, and that is set forth in the following paragraph:

abstract: -- Yesterday, Justice MANSFIELD committed JOHN MCGIVENS, and held for identification his brother, JOSEPH MCGOVERNS, both of whom are alleged to have been engaged in a burglary in Mr. ANDREW BURNETT's house, No. 121 West Twenty-seventh-street, on the night of the 1st inst. The burglars were attacked by Mr. BURNETT while in his house, and the boy JOHN fired upon bim, but missed aim, and fled; after which the elder burglar, who was in Mr. B.'s grasp, escaped by slipping his coat and leaving that garment in Mr. BURNETT's possession. The accused were arrested in Eighth-avenue, by officer IRVING, of the Twentieth Precinct.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented the memorial of the Boston Board of Trade, asking for the postponement of the Bankrupt Law. A petition from Ex-Surgeon-General HAMMOND was presented, asking for a court of inquiry in his case. A bill was offered, and referred to the Judiciary Committee, to amend the judicial system of the United States. A resolution was offered, and laid over until to-day, to add to the standing committees of the Senate a committee of five for the investigation of corruption of the Government in all its departments. Mr. MORGAN introduced a bill, which was referred to the Committee on Commerce, to regulate the management of captured and abandoned property in the rebel States. Mr. SUMNER presented a report for the House resolution terminating the treaty of 1817 with Great Britain. Ordered to be printed.

abstract: Rebels Cannot Belittle Loss of
snippet: Rebels Cannot Belittle Loss of
lead_paragraph: -- The rebels THE REBELS ON WILMINGTON, The rebels have never concealed from us the supreme value of Wilmington to their cause. The great commerce in war materials, in general supplies and in cotton that they have carried on there, has been for nearly two years as their very lif-eblood. The port was found to be impossible of blockade by a naval force; and the rebels, with the aid of their English friends, have taken the utmost advantage of this circumstance, by keeping lines of fast steamers running perpetually between there and British and West India ports. The Southern correspondent of the London Times lately gave us a glimpse of this great traffic, and asserted that the fall of Wilmington would be the heaviest blow that could now be dealt to the Southern Confederacy. The rebels have said so much to this effect that they cannot possibly now belittle their loss. They may stick to it, if they please, that Fort Fisher cannot be taken, but they must not say the loss would be a slight one if it could be.
