abstract: Cotton Stored at; Cotton at Savannah and Wilmington
snippet: Cotton Stored at; Cotton at Savannah and Wilmington
lead_paragraph: There was at first some considerable doubt in this city as to the accuracy of the official report that at the capture of Savannah we had come into possession of thirty-three thousand bales of cotton. But since the matter has been looked into, at Savannah, there is reason to believe that the official estimate was much below instead of above the mark. The Boston Traveller gives the statement of a wealthy and enterpising merchant, of that city, who has just arrived from Gen. SHERMAN's Department. He fully confirms the report of the immense quantities of cotton found in the city, and says that not only are the storehouses filled, but in many private places bales of cotton are concealed. In the seaboard region, south of the city, also, as far as the Altamaha, where Kilpatrick's cavalry lately operated, large quantities of cotton were seen; and as the railroad was destroyed as far as that river, and no rebel troops are there, the cotton will doubtless quickly find itself within our lines. As Wilmington has been the great export city for cotton for the last two years, we may possibly get a large haul when it falls into our hands one of these fine days.
headline: {'main': 'COTTON AT SAVANNAH AND WILMINGTON.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'COTTON AT SAVANNAH AND WILMINGTON.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Desertion and Federal Victories; Army
snippet: Desertion and Federal Victories; Army
lead_paragraph: It is no wonder that the desertions from the rebel army of LEE are now so numerous, reaching as high, lately, as fifty a day. Even the stupidest private soldiers in the rebel ranks are now beginning to see that the cause for which they have fought so long, and suffered so much hardship, and swallowed so many lies, is an absolutely hopeless cause. A thousand places we have taken, which, up to the moment of their capture, the rebel leaders persisted in declaring we could never take. In a hundred battles we have not only won the victories, but reaped their fruits, while the rebel papers indulged in frothy talk of our defeat. Vast tracts of country we have seized, and hold irrevocably, which the rebels declared we could never either hold or cover. Nearly all the large cities of the South are in our peaceable possession, though it was again and again declared, on behalf of their citizens, that they would perish before submitting to our flag. The great river highways, the great mountain chain with its fastnesses and military positions, the seaboard and its cities, are ours, though nature herself seemed to back up the rebel assertion that we could never seize or command them.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday notice was given of bills confirming the ordinance of the New-York Common Council, authorizing the extension of the Third-avenue railroad tracks; to amend the act authorizing the New-York Supervisors to raise money by tax, and relative to the expenditure thereof, and concerning passengers arriving in vessels at the port of New-York. Bills were introduced amending the act to aid the National Government in providing defences for the Northern lakes, and amending the act authorizing the Brooklyn Common Council to issue bounty bonds. A resolution was passed, calling on the Harlem Bridge Commissioners for information in regard to their expenditures.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday and organized by the reelection of Mr. TWEED as Chairman and Mr. JOSEPH B. YOUNG as Clerk. Mr. TWEED, in his address to the board, gave some interesting statistics as to the work done by the Committee on Volunteering, and also as to the financial condition of the county. A resolution by Mr. ROACH was adopted, instructing the Committee on Volunteering to inquire whether any measures have been taken or are contemplated for presenting to any person employed in the Enrollment Bureau any testimonial or present, and if so, to forbid the presentation. The salary of the legal adviser of the board was fixed at $2,000 per annum. The Board adjourned to noon on Monday next.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday and organized by the reelection of Mr. TWEED as Chairman and Mr. JOSEPH B. YOUNG as Clerk. abstract: Fry, William Henry
snippet: Fry, William Henry
lead_paragraph: We are called upon to record the death of Mr. W.H. FRY, the well known composer and journalist. A few weeks since we stated, with hopefulness of good consequences, that he had taken his departure for the West Indies. He was then very feeble, and had been suffering from recent hemorrhage of the lungs, but he was courageous and cheerful, and his friends were pleased to think that a genial climate might yet ameliorate his condition. They spoke of his return in April next, and parted with him, not so sadly as we now know the occasion warranted. He barely reached his destination. The voyage to St. Thomas, although pleasant, was exhausting. Thence he proceeded to Santa Cruz, and on the 21st of December he spent his last breath in the air that was to have healed him.

abstract: Burlington, Vt, Pioneer Mechanics' Shop, seven killed
snippet: Burlington, Vt, Pioneer Mechanics' Shop, seven killed
lead_paragraph: From the report of the City Dispensaries for the month ending Dec. 31, 1864, it appears that medical and surgical services, vaccination and medicine were afforded gratuitously, to 8,697 per sons. Of these there were visited and treated at their dwellings 1,821, at the Dispensaries 6,876, and 905 were vaccinated; 15,037 prescriptions were gratuitously dispensed at the several offices being an average of more than two to patient. The principal causes of death were consumption and marasmus. The prevailing diseases chiefly affected the respiratory system. Among the most important were typhus fever, small-pox, pneumonia and diphtheria.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday bills were reported favorably to amend the Brooklyn Bounty Act; to facilitate the organization of lands for Croton water purposes; and fixing the compensation of members of the New-York Common Council. Bills were introduced relative to passengers arriving in vessels at the port of New-York, and amending the act enabling the New-York Supervisors to raise money by tax. The Ninth Senatorial contested seat case was then taken up, and settled by admitting the claims of Mr. Low.

abstract: Millspaugh vs Adams; Divorce Case
snippet: Millspaugh vs Adams; Divorce Case
lead_paragraph: Andrew J. Millspaugh vs. Seth Adams. -- The plaintiff in this case is an importer doing business in this city, and brings this action to recover damages from the defendant for alleged criminal intercourse with his wife. The case, as stated in the opening of the counsel for the complainant, possesses peculiar features. It is alleged that in 1862 Mrs. Mary Millspaugh, the wife of the plaintiff, accompanied Seth Adams, the defendant, to the Town of Fort Wayne, in Indiana, and after remaining there a few days filed a bill of divorce against her husband on the ground of habitual drunkenness. In order to do this she was required by the laws of Indiana to swear that she had been for one year a bona file resident of that State. This she did, and having submitted testimony as to her husband's habits, the courts of the State granted her a divorce. Returning to this State she subsequently proceeded to Boston, Mass., and was there married to the defendant, Seth Adams. The plaintiff ignores this marriage, and claims that the defendant and Mary Millspaugh are now, and have been since the year 1862, living together in adulterous connection. The parties have resided at various hotels in this city, and are now living together at the Bancroft House. After opening the case, Mr. Fullerton, for the plaintiff, called the defendant as his first witness.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial from the Philadelphia Board of Trade was presented, asking for the postponement of the Bankrupt Bill. The resolution recently offered by Mr. POWELL was taken up and debated at some length. Mr. HOWARD, from the Military Committee, reported a resolution, which was ordered to be printed, recommending that measures of retaliation be adopted, in order to prevent the continuance of the barbarities practiced at the South on Union prisoners. The Senate then took up and passed the resolution ratifying the notice given Great Britain by the President of the termination of the treaty of 1817, limiting the naval forces on the lakes. Resolutions of thanks to Gen. TERRY and Admiral PORTER were offered, and referred respectively to the Naval and Military Committees.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a memorial from the Philadelphia Board of Trade was presented, asking for the postponement of the Bankrupt Bill. abstract: to the Union, unchanged Sherman on; Gen., on Reconstruction and Georgia People; Gen. Sherman on and Gov. People; People of, and Reconstruction; Gen Sherman
snippet: to the Union, unchanged Sherman on; Gen., on Reconstruction and Georgia People; Gen. Sherman on and Gov. People; People of, and Reconstruction; Gen Sherman
lead_paragraph: We need not direct attention to Gen. SHER MAN'S letter on the rebellion, which will be found in another column. It commends itself to public favor by its clear common sense and its practical character. It ignores entirely all the subtle theories by which the matter of reconstruction has been befogged and treats it in the most direct and practical manner. Georgia, as a State, he says, has never been out of the Union, and there is no necessity, therefore, to devise means for getting her back. Some of the people of Georgia have been and still are rebelling against the Government of the United States; and that Government is compelled to levy war against them to suppress that rebellion. But when this has been accomplished -- when the people lay down their arms and cease fighting, the war will stop, and things will go on, in all essential respects, just as they did before the war began. The war in its progress has made some very important changes in the affairs of Georgia as of other States. An immense amount of property has been destroyed, -thousands of their people have perished, slavery has been extirpated, and the whole structure of society has been shaken and shattered as by a convulsion. These things cannot be restored. Some of the losses may in time be repaired, but the internal condition of Southern society can never again be what it was before the war.
headline: {'main': 'Gen. Sherman on Reconstruction.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Gen. Sherman on Reconstruction.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Arrival at Richmond
snippet: Arrival at Richmond
lead_paragraph: An official dispatch from Secretary STANTON to the President announces the resumption of Gen. SHERMAN'S movement. On the 14th instant the Fifteenth and Seventeenth Corps, under the command of Gen. HOWARD, were transferred from Savannah to Beaufort, and moved out from that point upon the line of the Charleston and Savannah Railroad, at Pocotaligo, the rebels abandoning their strong works in that vicinity. The army is thus placed within thirty miles of Branchville, and within fifty miles of Charleston.

abstract: Parliament; Opening of
snippet: Parliament; Opening of
lead_paragraph: -- The Provincial Legislature assembled yesterday at Quebec. There are two points of more than local interest in Lord MONCK's opening speech. He promises a Government bill to provide more effectually for the prevention of robberies on the borders by rebel refugees. And he takes courage openly to announce that the Federation scheme is designed to make British America "an independent nationality." The speech otherwise is not of general interest.

abstract: Devastation will be Repaired after War; The
snippet: Devastation will be Repaired after War; The
lead_paragraph: One hears every day, from the refugees and others, who come North from those portions of the South which have been the scene of active operations, of the terrible devastation and ruin wrought by the war, of the desolation which broods over farms and plantations and seaports, and of the poverty and suffering which large numbers, of persons, who never before knew what want was, are now undergoing; and so vividly has the imagination of a large part of the Southern people been impressed by spectacles of decay which meets them on every side, that most of them are persuaded that it will take half a century of peace and order to restore the South to what it once was.
headline: {'main': 'The Resurrection of the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Resurrection of the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Com on Foreign Affairs; Treason among; in Rebel Congress on Negotiation
snippet: Com on Foreign Affairs; Treason among; in Rebel Congress on Negotiation
lead_paragraph: In the House, Jan. 16, immediately after the opening of the day's business, Mr. ORR, of Mississippi, rose, as he said, to a question of privilege in reference to an article in a newspaper of that city. The Speaker decided that this was not a question of privilege. The gentleman could only proceed by leave of the House. Mr. ORR, under leave of the House, rose to a personal explanation. He had the clerk read an article from the Sentinel of the 14th, headed "Treason." He then said; "The Speaker, the editor of this paper, is public and private printer of this House, and it is the commonly received organ of the Executive. This is my apology for noticing the slanderous article, which I have had Clerk read. It is apparent to this House, and to those who are familiar with our proceedings, that the article is intended as a criticism upon the report from the Committee upon Foreign Affairs, submitted to them on last Thursday. It is no less than the grave charge of treason against that Committee, and an implication of like import against members of this House who were cognizant of the substance of the report, and voted to receive it in secret session, I trust that the reputation of the members comprising that committee, is sufficient to satisfy the country that the article is false and slanderous.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday resolutions of thanks to Geu. TERRY and Admiral PORTER, and their officers and men, were unanimously passed. The joint resolution to appoint a committee to investigate the treatment of the Indians was passed. The consideration of the act to regulate commerce between the several States was postponed until Tuesday next. A bill was passed to amend the act defining the pay of army officers, which defines that a brevet rank shall not entitle the holder to any extra pay, A bill in reference to the special income tax was introduced, and referred to the Committee on Finance. A bill to amend the act to encourage immigration was introduced, and referred to the same committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday resolutions of thanks to Geu. TERRY and Admiral PORTER, and their officers and men, were unanimously passed. A bill was passed to amend the act defining the pay of army officers, which defines that a brevet rank shall not entitle the holder to any extra pay, A bill in reference to the special income tax was introduced, and referred to the Committee on Finance. A bill to amend the act to encourage immigration was introduced, and referred to the same committee.

abstract: Manhattan Co. Swindle; on N Y Gas Swindle
snippet: Manhattan Co. Swindle; on N Y Gas Swindle
lead_paragraph: -- The special attention of every tax-payer should be directed to the synopsis which we publish of the Comptroller's remonstrance against the attempted gas-swindle. The Common Council, in winding up the year's business, among other things, proceeded to the unprecedented length of declaring the contract between the city and the Manhattan Gas Company at an end. That contract has three years to run. It gives the company the sum of $25 yearly for each street-lamp on the island, or altogether, $440,000. The price is high, but the company are determined, if possible, that it shall be still higher. And instead of guarding the interests of the tax-payers, the Common Council, subjected to certain well-understood influences, votes almost unanimously that the company shall have its way.

abstract: We publish, this morning, a highly important report of proceedings in the rebel Congress, on Monday last, which clearly reveals the rapid progress of disaffection and disorganization throughout the Southern Condfederacy. The debate took a wide range, and it will be seen that the rebel President was handled without gloves by the Opposition speakers. Mr. ORR, of Mississippi, cast bold defiance in his teeth, and Mr. SMITH, of Alabama, withdrew from his seat, in disgust at the management which, he avers, has brought ruin on the Confederacy. The confessions of Mr. ORR establish the fact that the Committee on Foreign Relations, to which was referred the peace propositions of the rebel Congress, reported unanimously in favor of sending Commissioners to sue for peace, and that this issue is rapidly disrupting the whole framework of the Confederacy.

abstract: New March of and previous Record
snippet: New March of and previous Record
lead_paragraph: Now that the knotty case of Wilmington may be considered as successfully settled, the eager attention of the whole country is di- rected to the new campaign of General SHERMAN, the first step in which has just been taken. We give an important letter this morning from the Department of the South, by which it will be seen that at the very moment when our army and navy appeared before Wilmington, and commenced the operations which resulted in the capture of Fort Fisher, SHERMAN's army was put in motion -- the right wing marching upon the Charleston Railroad, where it quickly achieved a handsome and most valuable victory at Pocotaligo, and the left wing moving almost simultaneously from Savannah, on a line which the enemy may possibly ascertain for himself. The enthusiastic spirit with which this veteran army moves, and the confidence in its own prowess and invincibility with which it is possessed, may be judged by the letter of our correspondent. The skillful veteran soldier who leads this army -- of whom the Lieutenant-General says that the "world's history gives no record of his superiors, and shows few equals" -- is possessed of the same heroic spirit and invincible resolution as his troops; and he is as proud of them as they are of him. He has fought and marched all over the Southwest, during the last four years, from the day on which his abilities shone forth at Shiloh, onward through his two Vicksburgh campaigns -- his great march across Mississippi -- his subsequent marvelous march from Memphis to Chattanooga, or rather to Knoxville, engaging in a great battle on his way -- his Atlanta campaign, with its twenty battles -- his late march across Georgia, ending in McAllister and Savannah; -- and when a soldier with this vast experience declares that he can carry his army anywhere through the Southern States, he speaks according to the record. Though this is the case, we have the best reasons for believing that Gen. SHERMAN does not commence his new campaign without exhibiting a due appreciation of its conditions, its difficulties and its necessities. The fact that the Lieutenant-General has sent him reinforcements from the West, has been published in every newspaper on the continent; and if the South Carolina rebels can draw any consolation or strength of spirit from the fact, they will doubtless draw it. SHERMAN, too, as appears from the news, has begun his movement very cautiously and adroitly; and the rebels are doubtless as much puzzled now to learn whether his first objective will be Augusta, Branchville or Charleston, as on his leaving Atlanta in November, they were puzzled to discover whether his objective was Lynchburgh or Beaufort or Pensacola. We may also repeat a remark we made a few days since, that our success at Wilmington greatly simplifies his new campaign, be furnishing him, as it were, a halfway house on his onward march.
headline: {'main': "Sherman's New March.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Sherman's New March.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Hudson R Train over Embankment
snippet: Hudson R Train over Embankment
lead_paragraph: About 5 o'clock Thursday morning the "Montreal Train" on the Hudson River Railroad ran off the track about two miles above Yonkers, precipitating two of the passenger call over an embankment fifteen feet into the river, upsetting the stoves, filling the cars with smoke, and serving one of them on fire. The passengers, about fifty in number, were rescued from their perilous situation through the uppermost windows of the mutilated cars. Strange to say, none were seriously injured. A few were slightly burned by the upsetting of the stoves, a number were considerably bruised by the concussions and all the passengers suffered much by exposure to wet and cold. A number of physicians from New-York were on the train, but happily, their services were not required. After a brief, though rather unpleasant detention, cars were obtained in which to bring the passengers to this city.
headline: {'main': 'Accident on the Hudson River Railroad Two Cars Thrown into the River Narrow Escape from Serious Disaster.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Accident on the Hudson River Railroad Two Cars Thrown into the River Narrow Escape from Serious Disaster.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Inman steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 4th, and Queenstown on the 5th, arrived at this port last evening. Her advices are interesting. The continued favorable advices for the Union cause were producing a profound impression. The rebel loan had still further declined, making a total fall of 10 per cent. within one week. The tone of the English papers, particularly the London Times, was unusually candid and favorable. The Canadian difficulties attracted much attention, but the action of the President, countermanding Gen. DIX's order, gave much gratification. The Pope's letter was giving much dissatisfaction in France.

abstract: Kavanagh and Goldthwait; Championship Match
snippet: Kavanagh and Goldthwait; Championship Match
lead_paragraph: The match between DUDLEY KAVANAGH, the present champion, and WILLIAM GOLDTHWAIT, a well-known professional player, for possession of the Golden Cue and $1,000, was played last evening at the Academy of Music. The match has caused much excitement in the billiard world, and it attracted an immense audience. As early as six o'clock, parties began to gather around the building, and when the doors were opened the rush was so great that it was almost impossible, even with the aid of a large body of police, to preserve anything like order, and prevent persons not supplied with tickets from entering with the crowd.

abstract: Congress squabbling and Confederacy Breaking down; The
snippet: Congress squabbling and Confederacy Breaking down; The
lead_paragraph: It is only about a fortnight since that there began to be observed, and that we wrote an article in these columns upon, certain new manifestations in the spirit of the South. We began to see, what had not appeared before during the four years of the war, signs of the breaking-down of faith in their cause and its success -- indications of the departure of hope, the advance of despair. It appeared mainly by certain expressions in in the rebel press of Richmond, and certain statements as to the tone of public feeling and the direction of public action, as well as by certain propositions and expedients which were put forth to meet existing, moral and military emergencies. The conclusions on the matter which we reached at that time, however, were mainly inferential.
headline: {'main': 'The Counter Revolution in the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Counter Revolution in the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the House of Representatives yesterday resolutions of thanks to Gens. TERRY and THOMAS and Admiral PORTER and their officers and men, were unanimously passed. A joint resolution was passed authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to give notice to the owners of the Merchants' Exchange in New-York, now occupied as a Custom-house, to purchase the same for $1,000,000. The House concurred in the Senate's amendments to the Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation Bill. The bill authorizing the advance of officers of the navy and marine corps for distinguished services, not exceeding thirty numbers in rank, was passed. A bill was passed to inquire into permits granted to trade with the enemy. The Senate bill was reported and passed in reference to qualifications for practice in the Supreme Court of the United States. The Amendatory Loan Bill was then taken up and debated at considerable length. An amendment was agreed to restricting the issue of legal tenders, and the bill was then passed.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday a bill providing for the completion of the Rattery extension was reported favorably. Notice was given of bills to amend the Brooklyn Sewerage Act; to regulate the use of wharves and slips in New-York; to repeal so much of the registry law as applies to towns and villages. A bill was passed to provide a parade-ground for the military of New-York. The bill amending the charter of the New-York Guarantee and Indemnity Company was ordered to a third reading. A concurrent resolution was offered, expressing the thanks of the people to Admiral PORTER and Gen. TERRY.

abstract: Opinion in and the Rebellion
snippet: Opinion in and the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: A week from hence the files of the London Times will hardly be recognizable. Those received by the City of Baltimore last evening contain the amplest assurance possible that the "leading journal" is about to lead in a direction precisely the opposite of that toward which it has lent itself, and led its dupes heretofore. It would be unsafe to hazard the opinion whether this revolution has been brought about by the decline of ten per cent, in the Confederate cotton loan, by the glorious achievements of SHERMAN in his march through Georgia, or by the decisive victories of THOMAS in front of Nashville. There has been a very serious complication of events altogether -- tending most materially to disturb the prevalent sentiment of Europe. So much so, indeed, that the London Times almost vies with the loyal press here in its denunciations of the international justice administered in the neighboring Province, in the matter of rebel robberies on the border.
headline: {'main': 'The Rebellion and Opinion in Europe.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rebellion and Opinion in Europe.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Capt. McNITTE, of the above schooner, reports cleared hence the 15th ult. for Matamoris, and on the 5th of January, lat. 35  12', long. 62  40', while laying to in a heavy gale from northwest was struck by a sea, which threw the vessel on her
lead_paragraph: Capt. McNITTE, of the above schooner, reports cleared hence the 15th ult. for Matamoris, and on the 5th of January, lat. 35 12, long. 62 40, while laying to in a heavy gale from northwest was struck by a sea, which threw the vessel on her beam ends, when she filled at the after gangway. We succeeded in getting ourselves lashed to the bulwarks, to the windward, where we remained in that condition about four hours, when the mainmast went by the board, after which she righted; we then got a spar lashed from the foremost to the forerigging, on which we sat to keep us from the sea that was constantly breaking over us. After remaining in that condition about twelve hours the gale abated a little so that we succeeded in getting some spars lashed together to form a drag. After we got it overboard, we let go the part anchor. This with the help of the drag brought her to the wind and sea. After remaining in this condition for 34 hours. The gale abated. Finding her too much disabled to save anything, having lost all sails, water and provisions, and vessel full of water, concluded to abandon her on the first opportunity, and on the evening of the 6th was taken off by the brig Udola, Capt. WHITTEMORE, from Malaga, and brought to this port.
headline: {'main': 'Loss of Schooner Amelia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Loss of Schooner Amelia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Gold Room had a further fall of 7 cent. yesterday morning, making 14@15 cent. for the two days. But the bidding rallied in the afternoon 5@6 cent., after a day of much gambling excitement in and around the Room. At the Stock Exchange there was an additional pressure to make cash sales of the Railways, and this was also followed by an afternoon reaction. Government 5-20's were sold lower at the morning Board, and as quickly rallied on Wall-street and at the Second Board.

abstract: Letter to People of Georgia
snippet: Letter to People of Georgia
lead_paragraph: In the letter which we publish this morning, our correspondent at Port Royal gives a very interesting account of the progress of Gen. SHERMAN'S new campaign. The affair at Pocotaligo Bridge, previously announced, proves to have been a very brilliant and important success, resulting in the capture of the bridge and of twelve heavy guns, nearly all of which, however, were spiked. This was the most important station on the Charleston and Savannah Railroad, and heretofore has been defended by the rebels with great vigor. Reliable information places the main body of the rebels at Ashepoo, a station on the railroad thirty miles south of Charleston, where it is supposed they will endeavor to make a firm stand. At the date of our correspondent's letter, the left wing of Gen. SHERMAN's army was moving from Savannah; and it may be considered certain that the rebels have no force sufficient in numbers to check his onward progress. Deserters report that they contemplate the evacuation of Charleston, and have removed most of the Government machinery from that city.
headline: {'main': 'THE REBELLION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE REBELLION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Encyclical Letter
snippet: Encyclical Letter
lead_paragraph: In the excitement of our own affairs, the American public should not overlook the grand "Declaration of War" just made by the Pope of Rome against the ideas of the Nineteenth Century. We but repeat the voice of the liberal Roman Catholic party through Europe when we say that such a return to the spirit of the Middle Ages has not been made by any public official for more than a hundred years.

abstract: The Senate has adjourned until Monday evening without taking final action upon the Bounty Bill. The bounty question has, however, been brought to a definite point. The Senate has ordered the bill to a third reading; the Select Committee of the Assembly has reported precisely the same bill, and the Convention of Supervisors recommended the enactment of a law evidently copied from the main features of this bill.

abstract: WM. D. SNOW was elected to the U.S. Senate by a two-third vote of both Houses of the Legislature on the 29th ult., in joint convention. Mr. SNOW was born in Webster, Worcester County, Mass., in 1830, and anti-slavery in his principles, he has always acted with the old Whig and Republican parties. The Legislature is composed mostly of men born in the slave States, numbering seven eights of the members.

abstract: RECAPTURE OF AN OFFENDER. -- Officer CHAS. E. FREEMAN, of Capt. THORNE's forces, went to Camp Perine, at Trenton, N.J., last week, and apprehended one CHARLES A. SCOTT, a person who escaped from the Tombs Police Court recently, while complaint papers were being made. SCOTT, whose atlases are too many to admit of enumeration, was originally arrested for receipting for other people's goods at the steamboat and barge offices on the North and East River piers, and selling the same in Brooklyn. It is known that previous to his arrest he had thus stolen more than $7,000 worth of property; and so adroitly did he conduct his operations that he might have baffled the steamboat men and policemen for months longer, had not our officers accidentally learned from a carman that a consignment of flour had been taken from a steamboat office and set down in Court-street, Brooklyn, whence the carman, happening again to be in that neighborhood an hour later, saw another carman take it up. Learning this fact, our officers had a clue to SCOTT's plan of operations; and following this clue, they captured SCOTT, and with him recovered about $2,000 worth of stolen goods. The prisoner was commuted by Justice DOWLING. He is a keen business man, of good address, and only 26 years of age.

abstract: London Times Getting New Light
snippet: London Times Getting New Light
lead_paragraph: The public will learn with great pleasure that President LINCOLN has formally disapproved the order of Gen. DIX with respect to the pursuit of the Confederatemarauders across the Canadian frontier, and that the order has been virtually recalled. Nothing less could have been expected from any Governmentwhich claims a place among civilized nations. To break with us by putting on us an insult like the violation of our territory, would be ungrateful and unjust, as well as imprudent. These considerations were so likely to prevail, that it is without surprise we learn that the hostile demonstrations of Gen. DIX have been rebuked. There is every reason to hope that this cause of difference between the two countries will soon pass away. Should there be any repetition of the acts which have led to it the Northern States will have just cause of complaint, and it is therefore satisfactory to learn that the Canadian Government and people were fully sensibleof the necessity of repressing such outrages. The exploit of the St. Albans raiders must not be repeated. Technical questions of jurisdiction must not be allowed to imperil the dearest interests of British America. Not only are the Canadians bound as neighbors and friends to prevent the egress of murderers and robbers from their territory but a due regard for the future of their own province, and of that great Confederation which it is their purpose to form, should cause them to use every effort in keeping the peace. They must always be closely connected with the Federal States, whatever may be the future polity of either nation. They have a large and increasing trade with the Union, their readiest means of communication with Europe is through Federal territory, and a misunderstanding will, at any time, inflict upon them incalculable evils. As long as this war lasts it is the duty of the Canadian Government to see that the American territory is not violated from their frontier. They have sufficient men for the purpose, and they cannot use them better than in preventing enterprises which may at any time cause a rupture. It is stated that the authorities intend to send thirty companies of volunteers at once to guard the frontier. If they do this and take measures for the restitution of the stolen property they will only have performed their duty, and shown the American Government that, while resolute to maintain their own independence and honor, they know what is due to a neighboring people:

abstract: Retaliation for Cruelties to Prisoners called for; Cruelties to Prisoners; Retailiation Called for; Our, the Wrongs of Again
snippet: Retaliation for Cruelties to Prisoners called for; Cruelties to Prisoners; Retailiation Called for; Our, the Wrongs of Again
lead_paragraph: No one but a person placed at the centre of opinion like an editor can imagine how hot the passion of the country is growing over the wrongs of our prisoners in the hands of the rebel slave-holders. If any of our readers, not personally interested in this terrible question, will imagine his own brother, or son, or friend, gradually starving during twenty months -- the light of reason giving out under want of food, the influence of bad quarters, miasma and filth, subjected to brutal and cruel jailors, bodily strength failing, and life dying out in wretchedness and despair -- a man who might have been an honor to the nation thus slowly murdered by inches, and ending as a lunatic or idiot, his only crime that he had served his country -- he will appreciate the tide of indignation and wrath which is now slowly rising with irresistible power against these damnable wrongs in the hearts of our people. The conviction has taken fast hold of the public mind that this whole thing is a deliberate and devilish plot of the leaders of the Confederacy to force us to exchange an army of healthy and vigorous soldiers (made so by our humanity) for an equal number of these broken wrecks of manhood (made so by their cruelty.) The same cool system of murder seems to have been tried in South Carolina (where we had been led to expect more generosity,) as in Virginia, where we counted on nothing but cruelty and dishonor. The same close confinement, want of shelter, and deprivation of wood for fires or building, was enforced in Andersonville, where wood and space abounded, as in Richmond, where they might have been scant; the same scarcity of food in Georgia, where the land was overflowing with abundance,as in Virginia, where rations were short. There is evidently system and method in such barbarity. It cannot be the result of accident.

abstract: Freedom of the Press in; Freedom of the Press in France
snippet: Freedom of the Press in; Freedom of the Press in France
lead_paragraph: There is not much prospect that M. PERSIGNY'S prediction touching the future freedom of the French press will be verified in our day, since, instead of relaxing its fetters, the French Government and French courts are incessantly laboring to strip it of the few privileges which yet remain to it. A case has lately been decided by the "Tribunal of Rouen,"' illustrative of the persecution to which the French press is exposed under the Second Empire. It is the correspondents, however, not the editors, whose rights are now in jeopardy. Hitherto the former have been allowed a tolerable measure of liberty, but henceforward, if the Court of Correction is as adverse as the lower tribunals, they must submit to the gagging system as well as their principals.

abstract: Raid from Canada; Post on Absurdity of Border Raids; Malignity not Satisfied with Civilized War
snippet: Raid from Canada; Post on Absurdity of Border Raids; Malignity not Satisfied with Civilized War
lead_paragraph: The London Morning Post, the official organ, recognizes, in as strong terms as we could use ourselves, the futility and absurdity of the attempt which the Confederates are making to add a new article to the code of international law, clothing brigandage committed on an enemy from neutral soil with the immunities usually accorded to acts of regular belligerents. The theory which the Richmond authorities are endeavoring to force upon the acceptance of foreign nations is, that bands of adventurers may start from the territory of a neutral, kill and plunder on the other side of the frontier line, and get back again, without rendering themselves liable to any other punishment than such as the neutral's municipal law affixes to breaches of its neutrality, if they can show a commission from any power strong enough to keep an army in the field.

abstract: The Navy Department, yesterday, received a dispatch from ADMIRAL PORTER, saying that, in addition to the blowing up of Fort Caswell, the rebels also destroyed the pirates Tallahassee and Chickamauga. The Admiral also speaks hopefully of our forces soon getting into Wilmington. From the tone of the Richmond papers of the 19th, received at Washington, it is apparent that the rebels are in great trepidation respecting their ability to hold Wilmington against the force now operating against it.

abstract: and Southern Indebtedness; Boston and Philadelphia Petitions against Bankrupt Bill
snippet: and Southern Indebtedness; Boston and Philadelphia Petitions against Bankrupt Bill
lead_paragraph: By the acts of secession passed by certain Southern States in 1861, our New-York merchants lost over one hundred and twenty million dollars in gold. By the same Scheme of rebel confiscation, such commercial cities as Boston, Philadelphia and Baltimore lost some eighteen or twenty millions each. The three last together probably sacrificed something over half as much as New-York. During last session of Congress the Philadelphia Board of Trade busied itself with petitions against the Bankrupt Bill, primarily on the ground that certain Philadelphia tradesmen would be unable, if it should become law, to collect their different accounts after the restoration of the Union. The same sort of petition came up on Tuesday in the Senate from the Boston Board of Trade. And the report says that the Board set forth that "there is now due by the people of the revolted States to merchants of the North, between $150,000,000 and $200,000,000; that there has been no opportunity to press the claims for settlement in the local courts; and that, if the Bankrupt Bill should become law. the rights of these creditors would be seriously prejudiced."

abstract: If there be any city in America, as muddy as Nashville, in this fourth winter of the rebellion, I should like to know where it is. I emphasize the period, for the rebellion has much to answer for, for the present frightful accumulations of filth, making side-walks, streets, lanes, alleys, yards, look some  thing like a certain phase of the ocean as seen by the "ancient mariner" from the deck of his haunted ship.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Wednesday, Jan. 11, 1865.

abstract: Bids for Central Park Improvement Fund Stock, paying 6 per cent, interest, were opened in the Comptroller's Office yesterday. The amount required was $234,000. Bids amounting to $289,500 were received, ranging from par to 4 per cent, premium, but, as the Comptroller decided to accept only those at and over 2 per cent premium, only $75,000 were taken.

snippet: The, on Humanity; Proprietors, Charleston Mercury on the Spirit of; Mercury Wants More Killing to be Done
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Mercury says that in order to save the Confederacy more killing is necessary. "Men in command must not be afraid to die -- they must not be afraid to kill. Officers must be killed -- not mere privates. Reform must begin at the top, not at the bottom of the service. To reach the private, Captains must be shot. We want no child's play -- we want an army."

abstract: Confederacy; The Tottering
snippet: Confederacy; The Tottering
lead_paragraph: -- The structure of the Southern Confederacy has been tottering and tumbling ever since first it was reared by rebel hands. Its original cornerstone of slavery was a rotten affair, and neither the materials nor the workmen were of such a character as to insure its permanency. It had hardly got itself erected, when the fire of our artillery and the force of our steel were brought to bear upon it. Wall after wall was brought low, pillar after pillar was tumbled into ruins, and, with the fall of each f[???]ll hosts of its builders and defenders. The aspect of it now, is one vast wreck and ruin, with but here and there a blackened column still standing. Even of these we begin to see signs of the speedy fall; and when they do fall, they will carry down with them (he guilty men who have insulted earth and Heaven by attempting to rear in our fair land a temple to human slavery.

abstract: From information received from Judge CULVER, United States Minister at Caracas, we are advised that the Government of Venezuela has ordered a "National Exhibition of the Products of Nature. Industry and Art," to be held at the City of Caracas, the capital of that Republic, on April 10 next. The exhibition is not to be restricted to the products of Venezuela, but will embrace those of any or all nations desiring to contribute thereto. Provision is made in the decree, that all articles intended in good faith for the exhibition, shall be exempt from import and export duties, and from all costs and charges for freight, transportation, &c., from the port whence they are shipped to the place of exhibition, and return to such port. The Venezuelan Consul in New-York or Philadelphia will be able to furnish any and all information in detail as to the time and manner of shipping, and character of articles to be shipped. Venezuela intends this exhibition shall be on a magnificent scale, and will regard it as the great starting point in the development of her hitherto unknown riches and resources.

abstract: Extradition of; Deceit in Burleigh Case
snippet: Extradition of; Deceit in Burleigh Case
lead_paragraph: The Toronto journal, which speaks for the rebel interest in the Province, is given as an authority for the telegraphic statement that the case of BURLEIGH, the Lake Erie pirate, may be carried from the Recorder's Court before one of the Queen's Bench Judges, and thence, if necessary, to the Privy Council of England. The journal in question herein makes a needless effort to deceive its readers. There is no appeal to the English Courts or to the Privy Council, in criminal cases. There is not even coordinate jurisdiction between the English and Canadian Courts of Queen's Bench. This point was settled a few years ago in the case of a negro fugitive charged with felony. The decision of one of the Provincial Judges to surrender the criminal was attempted to be reversed by a writ of habeas corpus by the Lord Chief Justice of England. A conflict of authority was prevented solely by the reversal of the first decision in the Provincial Court of Appeal. The Sheriff of the county where the fugitive was in custody was, however, fully advised to disregard the order from the British court if the messenger put it in his hands. And during the ensuing session of the local Parliament, a law was passed which formally declared the non-existence of coordinate power between the British and Colonial courts in all matters of criminal jurisdiction.

abstract: London Corps of Commissionaires; London Corps of
snippet: London Corps of Commissionaires; London Corps of
lead_paragraph: It is something to have fought and bled for one's country, by sea or land, and to have retired with wounds, upon a good name and a pension. But many a brave soldier and sailor, disabled, and unable to procure a transfer to the Invalid Corps, has found the small pension given him too little to supply his necessary wants; and being unable to find such employment as would be suitable to his condition, is really suffering from want. There are many of this kind among us now, and there is every possibility of that number being greatly increased. To point out a way by which this suffering may be alleviated, by giving these worthy men an honorable vocation, is the object of this communication.
headline: {'main': 'THE LONDON CORPS OF COMMISSION- AIRES.; How Our Disabled Soldiers and Sailors May Secure a Support.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE LONDON CORPS OF COMMISSION- AIRES.; How Our Disabled Soldiers and Sailors May Secure a Support.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Through letters received from Collector DRAPER, and other sources, news has reached this city of the rapid shipment of cotton in Savannah for New-York. It is said that it will require at least twenty vessels to bring the staple to this port. No delay is experienced in getting the cotton on shipboard, as the military authorities have ordered that there shall be no hindrance of the work by claimants, though a record of the claims will be kept. The Collector advises our citizens not to engage in any trading adventures in the direction of Savannah at present. He also says that the stories of suffering have been greatly exaggerated, and that there are comparrtively few cases of destitution. The confidence of the army in Gen. SHERMAN is described as remarkable. The soldiers consider the success of the new campaign beyond a doubt.

abstract: The, Reported British Armament for; Naval Armaments on the Lake
snippet: The, Reported British Armament for; Naval Armaments on the Lake
lead_paragraph: There is no doubt that the British Govern ment are making preparations to send a naval armament, of greater or less proportions, to the lakes. And probably the London journal that announces Capt. SHERARD OSBORN as the designated commander of the force, has quasi official authority for its statement. But there is great reason to question the report received yesterday as to the number of vessels and men detailed by the British Government for this new service. We doubt whether there are thirty gunboats in the British service of a class at all adaptable for lake service. The locks of the St. Lawrence canals are of ample length -- two hundred feet; but their width is only twenty-six feet, and their depth only ten, while the Welland locks are but one hundred and fifty feet in length, with dimensions otherwise the same as the St. Lawrence. We very much doubt whether there is now such a fleet of serviceable gunboats corresponding with these measurements, and also whether such a fleet could be ready by the opening of lake and river navigation. But the story otherwise is improbable. It comes through a rebel, or at least most unfriendly channel. And it is difficult to believe that the British Government, by commencing with so formidable an armament, would desire to enter into a competition with us in a naval enterprise which is solely and purely defensive -- and defensive not as against Great Britain or her colonies, but as against outlaws and pirates who find now, or may find hereafter, refuge on British territory.
headline: {'main': 'Naval Armaments on the Lakes.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Naval Armaments on the Lakes.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Sanguine Hopes of; and Lee Mean to Fight it Out
snippet: The Sanguine Hopes of; and Lee Mean to Fight it Out
lead_paragraph: Despite the favorable military position, the good news of a dissension between two parties in the rebel Government, and Mr. BLAIR'S mission to Richmond, we warn our readers against too sanguine hopes of a speedy peace. The constant advance of our armies, the fearfully chaotic condition of the insurgent States themselves, and the apparent signs of a peace-party in the rebel Congress, are all ominous tokens of that great event which is surely coming, and which will gladden every right-thinking man -- the restoration of peace. But they are not necessarily tokens of its speedy advent. A powerful army, hardened in a hundred battles and numbering probably over 60,000 men, still holds Richmond and defies the utmost power of the Union. It is commanded by two men of great determination of character, of intense pride and remarkable ability -- LEE and DAVIS. We have no reason to suppose these two leaders of different purpose, or with any less firm resolve than ever, to fight out the war to the end.
headline: {'main': 'Too Sanguine Hopes of Peace.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Too Sanguine Hopes of Peace.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: N. Y.; Overcrowding of Population
snippet: N. Y.; Overcrowding of Population
lead_paragraph: In a recent report of the "First Ward In dustrial School," which has reached us, we learn certain facts in regard to the tenement-house population of that ward, which are sug gestive. We hear of a "family living in Washington-street; the father and two boys lodge in an underground room, about 12 feet by 30; within this narrow space there are twelve beds, each one containing three occupants or more, making at the lowest number thirty-six lodgers, men, women and children. The man and his two boys pay 50 cents a night; they provide themselves with 15 cents worth of scraps and 10 cents worth of bread, and thus they live. The boys are both of them in our school, but irregular in attendance, as a part of their time is devoted to boot-blacking. Drinking is going on in this cellar, and drunkeness is the order of the night."
headline: {'main': 'Over-Crowding of Population.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Over-Crowding of Population.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A rebel deserter, who came into Gen. TERRY's lines, reports that the rebels have evacuated Wilmington, after setting fire to thirty millions' worth of cotton. It was thought that our troops were near enough to prevent its destruction. Another report says that on the night of the 18th, five blockade-runners unsuspectingly ran into Old Inlet, and were captured by our fleet. A dispatch from Fortress Monroe says that most of the larger vessels of Admiral PORTER's fleet have returned, and that all the smaller vessels had entered Cape Fear River.

abstract: Arming Slaves; Proposition; Rebel Propositions for
snippet: Arming Slaves; Proposition; Rebel Propositions for
lead_paragraph: There are now only three months at the very most before the opening of what is called "the Spring campaign;" that is before it becomes feasible for armies to move in Virginia, and until military operations on a great scale become possible throughout all the Border States; until, in short, the period of the year at which the South has always hitherto found itself assailed at all points, and its strength subjected to the severest strain; and yet we do not perceive the slightest sign of the adoption of any plan by the rebels for arming and enlisting the negroes. There are vague reports that Gen. LEE favors it, and that DAVIS and his Secretary of War are prepared to resort to it, whenever there is clearly no other mode of saving the Confederacy, but there must be and certainly is also a vast deal of opposition to it, latent as well as expressed, and of which we shall only know the full strength when an attempt is made to put the scheme into legal shape.

abstract: Brooklyn; Linstedt's Piano Factory--$36,000
snippet: Brooklyn; Linstedt's Piano Factory--$36,000
lead_paragraph: THE LOSSES BY THE LATE FIRE IN MAIN- STREET. -- The destruction of the piano manufactory of Mr. J.E.L. LINSTEDT, Nos. 66, 68 and 70 Main- street, on Friday night, involved a loss of about $20,000 on stock, $15,000 on building, and $1,000 on building distillary of Mr. J.S. TROTT. The contents of the factory were insured for $10,000 in the following offices: Grocers', Firemen's Trust, East River, Park and Brevoort. The building, owned by Mr. BENJ. LODER, was insured, for $5 000 in the Harmony, Manhattan, Lennox, Park and International Companies. Mr. TROTT was insured for $15 000 in the National, Citizens', Harmony, Exchange, Croton Home and Williamsburgh City.

abstract: FALCONER'S comedy of "Men of the Day" will be produced at Wallack's Theater to-night. It has been prepared carefully, and will deserve the atten tion which all revivals at this house command.
lead_paragraph: FALCONER's comedy of "Men of the Day" will be produced at Wallack's Theater to-night. It has been prepared carefully, and will deserve the atten tion which all revivals at this house command. There are no changes to note in the bills of Niblo's. the Winter Garden, the Olympic, and the Broadway. At the last-named establishment it it officially announcedthat Solon Shingle will be withdrawn, after three more performances. Mr. BARNUM offers to his friends a new patriotic drama, written especially for the Museum by Mr. MILNES LEVICK, and called the "Union Prisoner or the Patriot's Daughter." It will be played this afternoon for the first time, and in the evening for the second.

The necessity of such a bureau is dictated alike by considerations of gratitude to those who are to be benefited as well as by motives of public morality.

abstract: ALLEGED THEFT OF A CERTIFICATE OF DEPOSIT. -- Mr. JAMES A. THOMPSON, of No. 110 Chatham-street, appeared at the Halls of Justice yesterday, and made affidavit that on Friday afternoon, after having been in a saloon at No. 328 Pearl-street, where WILLIAM J. MOLONY is bartender, he missed a certificate of deposit, which had been drawn for $2,500 in gold by Messrs. EUGENE KELLY & CO., bankers, and that on Saturday MOLONY presented this certificate at Messrs. KELLY & CO.'s banking-house and demanded payment. The paper not being properly certified, the paying teller declined to honor it, and MOLONY went from the bank, but was subsequently arrested by Policeman OBER, of the First Precinct, and committed by Justice DOWLING.

abstract: -- The naval and merchant service of the Confederacy suffered severely last week. Admiral PORTER sends word that the rebels have not only blown up Fort Caswell, but the pirates Tallahasse and Chickamauga as well. And a later arrival at Philadelphia yesterday, with Wilmington dates to the 20th, brings the satisfactory news, that on the night of the 18th five blockade-runners ran into Old Inlet and were captured by our fleet. It may be doubted whether these successive losses will be felt most severely at Richmond or at Liverpool. At the present rate blockade-running does nut promise to be a paying business for any great length of time. Nassau, Halifax and Bermuda will all feel the shock of these events in Cape Fear River before long, and altogether the Anglo-rebel mercantile interest seems to be in anything but a flourishing condition.

abstract: On Saturday night, the third concert of the present season was given at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The house was filled an hour before the time of commencement, and, as the directors permitted the sale of hundreds of tickets beyond the capacity of the building, the place was thoroughly and uncomfortably jammed. The orchestral programme consisted of HAYDN's Symphony No. 3, in E flat major, LISTZ's poem, Symphonique, "Tasse," and RIES' "Festival Overture." The verdict of the audience seemed to favor the "Tasse" and the "Festival Overture," although the symphony, and particularly the first two movements, was as felicitous in rendition as in conception. Miss LAURA HARRIS, the vocalist of the evening, was greeted with the warmest applause, and sang, with pleasing and graceful effect, cavatinas from "Lucia" and "Linda." Miss HARRIS has cause for congratulation that her first concert appearance in Brooklyn was before the Philharmonic Society, where professional knowledge and lay culture combine, forming an intelligent opinion of ability and attainment. The facile feats of vocalization, and the brilliant flights of fioriture, in which the young lady indulged, elicited outbursts of applause, and secured a triumphal encore. Madame CAMILIA URSO's violin performances, accompanied by orchestra or piano, were the feature of the concert, Mr. J.U. PATTISON appeared before the society in a difficult position. Piano-forte concertos are not popular, and the performer, who deliberately sacrifices miscellaneous approbation for the sake of enduring reputation, deserves most honorable recognition. BEETHOVEN's second concerto for the piano, with RUBENSTEIN's cadenza, was the task which Mr. PATTISON allotted himself, and by which he, has made his name welcome to the cultivated ear of Brooklyn.

abstract: The Army and Navy Gazette says the Canadian difficulty will, in all probability, lapse, but not harmlessly. The display of attachment to Great Britain and of patriotic zeal which the recent events called forth, will add to the many sources of irritation which the contest in America has opened, and will transfer to the Canadians a full share of the overflowing animosity with which Great Britain is regarded by the mass of the Northern people, but the Canadians have certainly established fresh claims to imperial sympathy.

abstract: Hopes' Potomac Army at Cumberland Landing
snippet: Hopes' Potomac Army at Cumberland Landing
lead_paragraph: A remarkable military picture is now on exhibition at the Derby Gallery, No. 625 Broadway. It is by a New-York artist -- L. HOPE -- who having formerly been a Captain of Volunteers, saw the pageant which he here transfers to an extensive canvas. It represents the Army of the Potomac (1862) at Cumberland Landing, on the Pamunky River, where for the only time in the history of the war 80 000 men were encamped on a single-field. The artist was detailed by Gen. Baldy SMITH and made a careful sketch of the spectacle, to the accuracy of which, many officers have borne willing testimony. The details of such a work are necessarily embarrassing. By the exercise of the rarest patience, Mr. HOPE has brought them before the eye in a remarkably vivid an I striking manner. The picture indeed will bear the closest scrutiny, and we commend it as an ambitious effort worthy of encouragement.

snippet: North America, Steamship,Lost; List of Persons Lost; North America, U. S. Transport; Loss, and 200 soldiers
lead_paragraph: On Thursday last we announced the loss, at sea, of the United States steam transport North America, which disaster was coupled with the loss of nearly 200 lives, chiefly of invalid soldiers from the United states General Hospital, in this city. The North America was a new ship, and believed to be much more staunch and seaworthy than the avenge of transports. She probably encountered a severe gale, and sprang aleak from the strain to which it subjected her. We have received from headquarters a complete list of the names of her passengers, which we give below:

abstract: The grand annual "Tiger" Ball came off last evening, at the Academy of Music, and was one of the best and most brilliant ever given by the time-honored and well-known "Light Guard." The Academy was very beautifully dressed -- flags and streamers of varied colored bunting were draped about the tiers and boxes. Muskets, knapsacks, swords and caps were grouped between the boxes and about the stage. Hundreds of canary birds, in neat and fanciful cages, were distributed among the flowers and flags, and their sweet wa[???] everywhere greeted the merry dancers. The stage was covered with an immense canopy in the form of a tent, the walls of which were ornamented with shields and various warlike designs, and in front a brilliant gas fixture bearing the name of the company and the date of the organization. Two excellent bands, one promenade and one quadrille, under the direction of HAR[???] H. DODWORTH, discoursed the choicest music. The floor was covered and the boxes filled with the prettiest and best dressed ladies and the most gallant and attentive gentlemen one might wish to see gathered together. Enjoyment was everywhere visible, and between the merry voices of the ladies, the singing of the birds, the delightful music of the bands, the magnificent dresses, the sparkling diamonds and the bright eyes of their fair owners, the Academy seemed to show a glimpse of fairy land, rather than a scene from real life.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. in addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader: and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Question in Grant's Hands; Prisoners; To Control Exchange of
snippet: Question in Grant's Hands; Prisoners; To Control Exchange of
lead_paragraph: The country will be rejoiced to learn that the entire subject of an exchange of prisoners has been placed in the hands of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, and that already there is reason to believe a full exchange will soon be effected. Heretofore this matter has been controlled, we believe, by three functionaries of the Government -- the Secretary of War, Gen. HITCHCOCK and Lieut.-Col. MULFORD, with occasional help from Gen. BUTLER. Neither of them had plenary power to act in the matter, and, as a consequence, it has long failed to meet with the definite and just settlement which it should have received at once. There have been questions in dispute between the two belligerents, which it has been found impossible to settle on a satisfactory basis. The consequences have been, and arc, at this day, fearful to thousands and tens of thousands of brave soldiers of the Union who fell into the hands of the enemy.

abstract: Rebels Last Ditch; Last Ditch; Richmond
snippet: Rebels Last Ditch; Last Ditch; Richmond
lead_paragraph: When the leaders of the rebellion plunged the country into war, the military problem was one of extraordinary difficulty for our Government. The area of rebeldom was so vast, that the occupation of the whole South, even if almost unopposed, would have required armies of enormous strength. A mere accidental collection of States, as yet lacking all moral and political unity, there was no one point in the South which could in any way be considered the key of the position, the possession of which would in any very material point lessen its prestige. It was then more important to attack the Armies of the South wherever found than to capture any one city or port. The progress of the war for nearly four years has very much changed this state of affairs. That which commenced as a mere agglomeration of slave States, banded together for purposes of defence, has ended by becoming a centralized despotism in which the question of destroying even the form of constitutionalism is now mooted; and with any man of less powerful character and prestige than JEFFERSON DAVIS at its head, the military dictatorship of LEE would have been consummated long before this. Charleston, as the birth-place of rebellion, and one of its greatest strongholds, as well as from the failure for years of the combined operations of our land and sea forces against it, has attached to it a prestige which would make its capture a very heavy blow to the South; but except in name it would, militarily, a fleet the aspect of affairs but little. Wilmington as the chief port for blockade-running; New-Orleans as giving possession of the mouths of the Mississippi Vicksburgh as controlling its navigation; Atlanta as a great centre of railroad communication -- all these were important strategical positions, and their loss has done much to destroy the material resources and injure the moral power of the rebellion.

abstract: WALLACK's THEATER. -- Considering that Mr. FALCONER took sixteen days to write the comedy of "Men of the Day," it is really remarkable that he did not in that protracted period hit upon a single idea or expression that was in one degree removed from mediocrity. A balder piece has never been put upon the stage. The plot is old and threadbare, the situation -- well, there are no situations, the dialogue is profuse and circumlocutory, and written with an underbred air of defiance of the rules of society. It is possible perhaps to distinguish a few characters, and even these are conventional. We look in vain for anything higher than the "you're another" school of dialogue, and the stage mechanic's knowledge of what works well with the public.

abstract: The mortality report for the week ending yesterday, shows a total of 468 deaths during that period. Of the deceased, 132 were men, 64 women, 143 boys and 128 girls. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Consumption, 89; convulsions, 37; inflammation of the lungs, 51; small-pox, 26; marasmus, 24; typhus and typhoid fever, 21; ...
lead_paragraph: The mortality report for the week ending yesterday, shows a total of 468 deaths during that period. Of the deceased, 132 were men, 64 women, 143 boys and 128 girls. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Consumption, 89; convulsions, 37; inflammation of the lungs, 51; small-pox, 26; marasmus, 24; typhus and typhoid fever, 21; croup, 13; diphtheria, 17; scarlet fever, 15, and dropsy 14. As compared with last week there is a decrease in the number of deaths of 42; and as compared with the corresponding week of last year of 58. Of the deceased 224 were children under five years of age. It will be seen that the number of cases of small-pox has greatly decreased, only 26 deaths being reported this week against 41 in the previous week. There appears therefore no cause for alarm on the subject. The Mayor, yesterday. Issued his annual proclamation recommending all who have not been vaccinated, within the past five years, to apply to the dispensary physicians at once. The location of the different dispensaries will be found in the proclamation published below.

abstract: Order Organizing New Regiments; Old Regiments and New Regiments
snippet: Order Organizing New Regiments; Old Regiments and New Regiments
lead_paragraph: An order promulgated by the AdjutantGeneral of the State, announces the intention of Gov. FENTON to organize the troops prospectively to be raised by draft or volunteering before the 15th proximo, into five new regiments and fifty new companies. In common with every soldier in the field, from the Commanding General of all the armies down to the most "unthinking bayonet" in the ranks, we cannot help expressing regret that His Excellency should have come to this determination. Past experience has taught that entirely new regiments are comparatively useless for the first few months -- the time varying in length, according to circumstances -- after entering upon the active work of a campaign.

abstract: City Inspector's Annual Report
snippet: City Inspector's Annual Report
lead_paragraph: The annual report of the City Inspector, for the past year, was presented to the Common Council at its meeting yesterday. The statistics of mortality show more favorably than could have been anticipated, considering that they must have been largely increased by the deaths of the sick and wounded soldierswho were cared for in our hospitals. The City Inspector says, on this point: "In my last annualreport I stated that the deaths in this city for the past year were 25,196. During the year 1864, with an increased population of 80,000, they amount to 28,645, which is a nominal increase of 449 over the preceding year; and yet, when the increased population of the city is considered, there is no increase, but a diminution in the percentage of deaths, which is the more to be remarked when we consider the fact that such vast numbers of our brave soldiers, rendered ill and dying from wounds and exposure, return to their families in New-York to be cared for, die and are buried here, and form part of our general record of the mortality or our city."

abstract: Secretary STANTON yesterday sent in a communication to the Senate stating that the several resolutions calling for information in his possession, had been handed to him on his return to the city, and that information would be sent in as speedily as possible. The credentials of Mr. HOWARD, Senator elect from Michigan, were presented by Mr. CHANDLER. Resolutions from the Ohio Legislature and the Missouri Constitutional Convention, were presented, asking for the passage of the Constitutional amendment. An act was introduced and referred to the Military Committee, to increase the compensation of certain officers in the field. Mr. SHERMAN reported that the Committee of Conference on the Deficiency Bill had been unable to agree, and moved that the Senate further insist upon its amendments and appointed another committee. The motion was agreed to. A resolution declaring the sense of Congress upon the subject of negotiation, was printed and laid on the table for the present. The Chair presented a communication from the Secretary of War, in reference to naval credits. The bill defining the rank and pay of paymasters in the navy was passed. The resolution advising retaliation for cruel treatment of our officers and soldiers, was taken up, and after some debate, postponed for consideration to-day.
lead_paragraph: Secretary STANTON yesterday sent in a communication to the Senate stating that the several resolutions calling for information in his possession, had been handed to him on his return to the city, and that information would be sent in as speedily as possible. Resolutions from the Ohio Legislature and the Missouri Constitutional Convention, were presented, asking for the passage of the Constitutional amendment. An act was introduced and referred to the Military Committee, to increase the compensation of certain officers in the field. Mr. SHERMAN reported that the Committee of Conference on the Deficiency Bill had been unable to agree, and moved that the Senate further insist upon its amendments and appointed another committee. The motion was agreed to. A resolution declaring the sense of Congress upon the subject of negotiation, was printed and laid on the table for the present. The Chair presented a communication from the Secretary of War, in reference to naval credits. The bill defining the rank and pay of paymasters in the navy was passed. The resolution advising retaliation for cruel treatment of our officers and soldiers, was taken up, and after some debate, postponed for consideration to-day.

abstract: Whereabouts of
snippet: Whereabouts of
lead_paragraph: Since the capture of this veteran regiment last September at the battle of Poplar Grove Church, below Petersburgh, the friends of the officers and men had lost all trace of them -- no letters being received, and much anxiety beginning to be felt about them. But within the current week an exchanged Union Chaplain, Rev. Mr. EMERSON, returned from confinement at Danville, Va., brings word of the Fifty-first officers at the latter place. Maj. WRIGHT, Capt. G.W. WHITMAN, Lieuts. POOLEY and ATKINSON, and some eight or ten more officers, are there, or, rather, were, toward the last of November. They were kept in a large tobacco warehouse, and were doing as well as men could do under such circumstances. Mr. EMERSON, after leaving Danville to be paroled, was detained over a month in Richmond. He is now at Annapolis. He brought a number of those significant slips of paper, of all textures, colors and degrees of legibility, known so well to persons familiar with the Southern prisons and with the returned Union prisoners -- deaths, memoranda, messages, &c. Among these slips is one written by Capt. WHITMAN, of the Fifty-first, dated at Danville. Nov. 23, and simply addressed to his mother in Brooklyn, with the indorsement. "Well and nearly."

abstract: The grand annual "Tiger" Ball came off last evening, at the Academy of Music, and was one of the best and most brilliant ever given by the time-honoredand well-known "Light Guard." The Academy was very beautifully dressed -- flags and streamers of varied colored bunting were draped about the tiers and boxes. Muskets, knapsacks, swords and cans were grouped between the boxes and about the stage. Hundreds of canary birds, in neat and fanciful cages, were distributed among the flowers and flags, and their sweet warblings everywhere greeted the merry dancers. The stage was covered with an immense canopy in the form of a tent, the wails of which were ornamented with shields and various warlike designs, and in front a brilliant gas fixture bearing the name of the company and the date of us organization. Two excellent bands, one promenade and one quadrille, under the direction of HARVEY B. DODWORTH, discoursed the choicest music. The floor was covered and the boxes filled with the prettiest and best dressed ladies and the most gallant and attentive gentlemen one might wich to see gathered together. Enjoyment was everywhere visible, and between the merry voices of the ladies, the singing of the birds, the delightful music of the bands, the magnificent dresses, the sparkling diamonds and the bright eyes of their fair owners, the Academy seemed to show a glimpse of fairy land, rather than a scene from real life.

abstract: Should be Protected
snippet: Should be Protected
lead_paragraph: Some further facts in regard to Indian outrages on the Overland Mail route to California are given in our Washington news this morning. Now that Secretary STANTON has returned from the South, entirely relieved of all care in regard to Fort Fisher and future military movements directly or indirectly affected by its capture, we do not doubt that he will give immediate attention to the existing necessity for more energetic measures to restrain the Indian tribes of the Plains, and to protect the great highway between the Atlantic and Pacific States. It is not creditable to the Government that a few hundred savages should be able to absolutely hold two or three hundred miles of the road in question, and absolutely interdict the flow of travel and United States mails.
