abstract: The enlistments by the County Volunteering Committee average only ten men a day. At the other recruiting stations in the city, not less than three hundred men are daily enlisted, most of whom are "run" into adjoining counties, or out of the State. This species of swindling is being carried on by a class of unscrupulous bounty-brokers, who not only rob the county of men, but rob the men after they get them out of the county. So intent has this matter become, that with military officials it has ceased to excite surprise. The recent issue of an order from the War Department, prohibiting the payment of bounties to soldiers (except the hand-money, $25,) until they are in the field, will probably effectually stop much swindling. In future, the sum of money a soldier is entitled to will be placed to his credit for the use of himself or family. In the City Hall Park, and on the Battery grounds, there are not more than three or four recruiting stations that place their men to the credit of the city. The rascality practiced by the swarm of bounty-swindlers who infest our public thoroughfares, and not unfrequently force men from the State, is becoming an intolerable nuisance. It has grown to be the case that an honest man having a substitute to enlist cannot approach either of the county recruiting stations with safety. This is particularly the case in Brooklyn, where a man if he be not a licensed broker must pay a hundred dollars to one of these individuals for the privilege of sending a substitute. There is a law which imposes a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars on any person found guilty of inducing men to leave the State and the hone is that it may be put in force. Most of the men enlisted by Supervisor BLUNT are intelligent and know their rights. There never have been any complaints concerning the men enlisted by the Volunteer Committee, and it is very rare that cases of desertion occur when men have been legitimately enlisted. As an evidence of the class of men supplied to the Government by bounty brokers, the circumstance of the arrival of ninety-three men at this port last week, by the steamship Great Western. may be mentioned. The men were emigrants who left England for the purpose of enlisting in the army. Of the number examined, but forty-two were accepted. Of the fifty-one rejected, it has been ascertained that thirty-six were "put through" by bounty brokers.

abstract: --This company, yesterday, commenced running their small cars between their depot in Chambers-street and that in Thirtieth-street. The arrangement has the effect to slightly lessen the time heretofore occupied by the large cars in going over the same ground. The company, however, put the tax of five cents per head upon every one, whether the holder of a ticket or not. This causes much dissatisfaction among passengers, particularly among commuters, with whom it is equivalent to adding thirty dollars per year to the price of their commutation, and this, too, by a road whose commutation rates are already in excess of those of any other prominent road leading from the city. It has been supposed that this new arrangement was for the benefit of the passengers, but it proves to be solely a new source of revenue for the company, as passengers can take the Eighth. Ninth and Tenth avenue cars, as usual, and with about the game degree of convenience.

abstract: Gen. GRANT telegraphed to Secretary STANTON on Monday, announcing the return of one of his aids from Fort Fisher, with dispatches from Gen. TERRY. He reports, that on the 16th the enemy blew up Forts Caswell and Campbell, and abandoned them and the works on Smith's Island, and those at Smithville and Reeves' Point. These places were occupied by the navy. The whole number of guns captured amounts to 162. A large number of small arms also fall into our hands, beside quantities of ordnance and commissary stores. Our casualties prove smaller than at first reported. They foot up thus: Twelve officers and one hundred and seven men killed; forty-five officers and four hundred and ninety men wounded.

abstract: This well-known and praiseworthy charity has for the last thirteen or fourteen years, as is generally understood, furnished medical and surgical aid and medicines gratuitously to the sick poor of the Eighteenth and Twentieth Wards.
lead_paragraph: This well-known and praiseworthy charity has for the last thirteen or fourteen years, as is generally understood, furnished medical and surgical aid and medicines gratuitously to the sick poor of the Eighteenth and Twentieth Wards. It has pursued its work so quietly and efficiently that the impression has gained ground that it was supported by the State or city, whereas, with the exception of one thousand dollars annually appropriated to it by the Legislature, it is entirely dependent upon private contributions. The heavy drafts made upon its treasury during the last few months have so reduced its funds, that unless they are speedily replenished the dispensary will be compelled to greatly restrict its operations; and that, too, just at a time when it should have every possible facility for extended them. This fact only needs to be stated to secure liberal contributions, which may be sent to either of the managers, or to JOSEPH W. PATTERSON, Esq., the Treasurer, at No. 85 Leonard-street.

abstract: What Is It; Naturalization--What is it
snippet: What Is It; Naturalization--What is it
lead_paragraph: It is a point for the historian to note that the British Government is fighting to-day the battle it fought with the Maryland colonists one hundred and ninety-eight years ago. In 1666, Maryland decided that she had the right to extend political privileges to well-behaved settlers within her borders whatever might be their origin. Virginia, South Carolina aad New-York followed in the same pathway of progress, and the minor States of the ante-revolutionary period emulated the example of their elder sisters by naturalization acts of more or less liberality.

abstract: Storm's Mammoth Oxen; Presentation to
snippet: Storm's Mammoth Oxen; Presentation to
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAINS OF BEEFSTKAKS. -- Our stock-fancying friends up the river challenge the world to meet them at the agricultural fairs with the products of the soil and of the farmhouse. They farm on the grandest scale, and their labor shows the most gratifying results. They come hither from Rockland with the hugest and purest diamonds of ice; from Westchester and Orange with milk which would make our mouths water if we could but get it before it undergoes the traditional baptism in Croton; and from Dutchess and Putnam with colossal beeves and farm-yard stock that might well astonish even a VAN AMBURGH. Two of these enormous bovine animals were recently brought from Putnam, and are now on exhibition at Mr. J.W. STORM's stables, in Fourth-avenue, between Twenty-seventh and Twenty-egthth streets. One of these animals -- Columbus by name -- turns the scale at eight thousand pounds, and his fellow, Americus, is of about the same weight. Their Tourine Highnesses are described by the exexhibitor as of eleven feet girth, five feet eleven in bright, and nine feet eleven in length from the button of the horns to the root of the caudal adjunct They are visibly larger than the mammoth oxen Constitution, Union and George Washington, which were exhibited here two or three years ago by Messrs. LALOR, BRYAN LAWRENCE, and others, and on the scales Columbus or Americus will see any other ox that the country has produced, and go him two thousand pounds better. These animals are seven years old, and were raised by Messrs. W. & J.W. STORM, of Lagrange, Dutchess County. They are known us grade Durhams.

abstract: The steamship Atalanta, Capt. JOHN PENNINGTON, from Mobile Bay, 16th inst., arrived yesterday afternoon, having on board 1,000 bales of cotton on account of the rebel Government, the proceeds of which are to be expended in purchasing blankets, clothing, &c., for the rebel prisoners now held by our Government. The cotton is in charge of Capt. FRANK G. NOYES, of Maj.-Gen. GRANGER's staff, and was delivered to him on the 12th by the rebel authorities at Mobile, outside of their obstructions, from their steamer Waverly.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Atalanta, Capt. JOHN PENNINGTON, from Mobile Bay, 16th inst., arrived yesterday afternoon, having on board 1,000 bales of cotton on account of the rebel Government, the proceeds of which are to be expended in purchasing blankets, clothing, &c., for the rebel prisoners now held by our Government. The cotton is in charge of Capt. FRANK G. NOYES, of Maj.-Gen. GRANGER's staff, and was delivered to him on the 12th by the rebel authorities at Mobile, outside of their obstructions, from their steamer Waverly.

abstract: Medical College for Women; Officers of
snippet: Medical College for Women; Officers of
lead_paragraph: The report of the trustees of the above institution was presented to the Senate yesterday, in compliance with a requisition of the Regents of the University; Mrs. C.S. Lozier, M.D., is Professor of Diseases of Women and Children; Jno. Ellis, M.D., Professor of the Principles and Practice of Medicine; J.M. Ward, M.D., Professor of Obstetrics and Medical Jurisprudence; Jas. Hyatt, Professor of Chemistry and Toxicology; Carrol Dunham, M.D., Professor of Theropeutics and Materia Madica; J.R. Andrews, M.D., Professor of Principles and Practice of Surgery; Mrs. Sarah M. Ellis, M.D., Professor of Anatomy. The Chair of Physiology and Hygiene being vacant, the course of lectures has been given by Profs. Ward, Andrews and Lozier. The whole number of students attending the regular course is 34. The amount received for tuition has been $1,299, and with voluntary contributions of $1,155, have covered all the expenses of the College.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SHERMAN reported back the bill to appropriate money for the Post-office Department. The House bill to provide for Acting Assistant Treasurers or depositories of the United States in certain cases, was taken up and passed. Mr. SUMNER reported a series of resolutions as a substitute for the resolution before the Senate on the ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SHERMAN reported back the bill to appropriate money for the Post-office Department. The House bill to provide for Acting Assistant Treasurers or depositories of the United States in certain cases, was taken up and passed. Mr. SUMNER reported a series of resolutions as a substitute for the resolution before the Senate on the the subject of retaliation, setting forth that it would be impracticable, immoral and degrading for the Government to imitate the practice of the rebels in the treatment of rebel prisoners, and reiterating the determination of the people to put down the rebellion. Mr. SUMNER supported the views expressed in these resolutions in a long and able speech. The subject will be taken up again to-day. Mr. WILSON introduced a new and very stringent conscription bill, which was referred to the Military Committee.

abstract: Mr. FRANCIS ROBINSON, the assistant cotton agent in this city, has received intelligence of four cotton-loaded vessels being on the way to this port from Savannah. Three of the vessels are schooners, and the other is the steamer Commodore. On arrival here, the cotton will be carefully assorted, and stored until the return of Collector DRAPER from Savannah. The first sales will probably take place early next month. Several other vessels are loading cotton at Savannah, and their arrival may be looked for before the end of the month.

abstract: as Rebel Generalissimo; Military Operations Approved by Lee
snippet: as Rebel Generalissimo; Military Operations Approved by Lee
lead_paragraph: In calculating the effect upon the fortunes of the Confederacy of the substitution of Gen. LEE for JEFFERSON DAVIS, as Commander-inChief of the rebel armies, it must not be forgotten that there is every reason to believe that the change is rather in appearance than in reality. There is no good reason for doubting the statement which has of late been constantly made by DAVIS' organ at Richmond, that he has never given directions with regard to any great military movement without having previously consulted LEE. There has never been any indication of the existence of any feeling of coolness or jealousy, or want of confidence between them. LEE has been retained since 1862 in command of the best and most important army of the Confederacy; the safety of its head and heart has since that time been in his keeping, and there can be no question that he has, during the whole of that period, received DAVIS' hearty support. Without it, it would have been impossible for him to have played his part so well as he has done.

abstract: Wilson's Bill; Conscription Bill
snippet: Wilson's Bill; Conscription Bill
lead_paragraph: conscription bill, which owes its parentage to Mr. WILSON, is before the Senate. Its most remarkable feature is, that it makes principals responsible for the desertion of their substitutes. This is an ingenious proposition, to say the least of it. We had supposed that the interest of the principal in his substitute ceased the moment the latter was accepted by the military agent of the Government. It has been generally presumed, at least, that a substitute, in the very nature of things, could not belong, at one and the same time, to the Government, and to the man who procured him for the Government, in lieu of personal service. Mr. WILSON proposes to change all this by a legislative provision, which is to make the substitute duplicate himself, so that while he surrenders his physical services to the Government, his body may be mortgaged to the citizen who invests in him. The principal, on common commercial grounds, can hardly be expected to resign all control over the person of a substitute, and yet stand responsible at the same time for said substitute's being found ready to answer the muster call every day in the year for the whole term of service. Giving the military authorities absolute control of him is simply imposing upon the military authorities the same responsibility they charge themselves with now -- that of seeing that men who are accepted for the service shall not desert. We hardly see how Senator WILSON's device is to work.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was reported to increase the rates of pilotage in New-York. Among the bills introduced was one to repeal so much of the Registry Law as applies to towns ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was reported to increase the rates of pilotage in New-York. Among the bills introduced was one to repeal so much of the Registry Law as applies to towns and villages; to provide an armory for the Eighth Regiment, N.Y.S.G.; to remove the restrictions as to fare on the Hudson River Railroad. The Senate then proceeded to ballot for a Regent to the University, and WM. H. GOODWIN received 17, and ISAAC BUTTS 7 votes. The State Bounty Bill was then taken up, and debated until the hour of adjournment.

abstract: The
snippet: The
lead_paragraph: mittee, to which was referred the Bankrupt Bill desire to kill it, well and good. Let it be done in an open way. It can serve no good purpose for that Committee to trifle on this exceedingly grave question, by proposing amendments which not five sane men in the House, and not one sane man, except the deadly opponents of a bankrupt law, outside of the House, would ever consent to. Of such a character we pronounce the Senate Committee's amendment to make the bill entirely prospective in its operation. Such a provision not only deprives the measure, so cordially passed by the House, of its prime value, but it is an insult to public intelligence.

abstract: THE METROPOLITAN FIRE DEPARTMENT. -- A meeting of the Brooklyn Fire Commissioners, Boards of Trustees, of Appeal and or Representatives was held on Monday evening, at No. 9 Court-street, for the purpose of giving an expression of opinion in relation to the Metropolitan Fire Department bill now before the Legislature. After organizing, the act was read, when Mayor WOOD, in alluding to the Western Fire Department, and speaking in high terms of its efficiency, said that he was satisfied with the working of the system in the city as now conducted, and honed there would be no change. The department of Brooklyn needed no change, whatever the necessities for changing the system in New-York might be. Several others expressed their views on the subject, when the following gentlemen were appointed a committee to proceed to Albany and attend to the interests of the Fire Department: Hon. A.M. Wood, Mayor; J.P. Rorke, President Fire Department; Felix Campbell, Board of Trustees; Joseph Ketchum, Jr., President Board of Commissioners; John Navler, Chairman Board of Appeals; William Burrell, Treasurer Fire Department; John Cunningham, Chief Engineer. After appointing the committee the meeting adjourned.

abstract: Through some process of remarkable figuring, unknown to any other modern mathematician, Provost-Marshal-General FRY announces that he has added 14,000 more men to the quota of New-York, making the total quota of the State over 60,000. In the same breath we have the report of the Supervisors' Bounty Volunteer Committee, that Gen. FRY has increased the quota of this city, which had been reduced by credits to 4,000. to nearly 20,000. How the sharp figurer makes all this out, we don't know but we do know that the people are greatly disgusted and discouraged at these vacillating reckonings, and would be greatly obliged to Gen. FRY if he would finally ascertain the quota of each district in this State, explain how he does it, and then stick to it. Our authorities could then go ahead and recruit, and know just what they were about. But as it is now, they arc as much at sea about it as Gen. FRY appears to be.

abstract: We have endeavored to obtain some particulars in regard to the fight, but matters are in so confused a slate that no two reports agree, and unless we can get the truth, we prefer publishing nothing. All reports concur, however, in stating that Gen. WHITING and Col. LAMB fought gallantly, leading the troops to repel each assault, and never gave up, but were overpowered or shot down. Others also fought bravely and well, and are deserving of all praise. Forts Holmes and Caswell were evacuated by our troops on Monday, as we expected, the capture of Fisher rendering the holding of these points useless to us. A tremendous explosion was hazard and felt in town about 1 1/2 o'clock Tuesday morning, supposed to have been produced by the blowing up of magazines at the above forts.

abstract: Thomas' and Terry's Campaigns; the, in the South
snippet: Thomas' and Terry's Campaigns; the, in the South
lead_paragraph: The strong confidence which has lately sprung up in the public mind, not only of the ultimate success of the Union cause, but of the final and glorious triumph of our arms within a reasonable time, continues to be justified. This confidence is not based upon any one victory or its results, nor is it based alone and exclusively upon field victories. Nothing, indeed, could be more inspiriting and grand than the three campaigns of the last three months, under SHERMAN, THOMAS and TERRY; and nothing could he more hopeful of important and decisive military results than the new campaign of SHERMAN, which has already begun, and the other great movements which are on the eve of execution under the eye of the Lieutenant-General. The chief value of THOMAS' victory was in reducing the rebel military power in the Southwest to such a feeble condition that he not only leaves it powerless for offence in the future anywhere, but that. on the other hand, he can either sweep southward through Alabama and Mississippi, and, by seizing upon the remaining strategic positions and railroads, reduce the war in the Southwest to the guerrilla stage which will probably for a brief time precede its final close; or, on the other hand, he can furnish from his army large reinforcements to the main armies operating on the Atlantic seaboard. It would not be surprising, indeed, considering the present aspect of affairs, if the veteran army of Gen. THOMAS, instead of spending its entire energies this Winter in a campaign to Mobile, were to furnish heavy detachments of troops to be concentrated with the two great armies (GRANT's and SHERMAN's) which may now be said to be conjointly operating against Richmond. This view is confirmed by the published news of this morning, which sets forth that, in addition to the troops brought East from Tennessee by Gen. MEAGHER, the Twenty-third Corps, under Gen. SCHOFIELD, with this gallant commander, have already arrived in Virginia. This splendid body of troops has a history unsurpassed by that of any corps in the West for deeds of valor; and if the Lieutenant-General intends that, with their Western compatriots under SHERMAN, they shall now take a part in the closing scenes of this great war, on fields a thousand miles distant from those upon which they have heretofore fought, we may he sure that they will sustain the reputation they have always borne. It is certain that there is no danger whatever in taking a large body of THOMAS' troops from the West; for HOOD's army is so badly "played out," that we we have no doubt two-thirds of THOMAS' present force could whip and disperse it, and then pass on to Mobile. Whether SCHOFIELD's corps reinforces the army on the James, or the army on the Savannah, it will in either case reinforce the armies operating against Richmond.

abstract: Departure for Europe
snippet: Departure for Europe
lead_paragraph: Gen. GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN and wife sailed yesterday, on the Cunard steamer China, for Europe, where they intend remaining six months. After stopping a few days in London and Paris, they will go direct to Rome, where they will spend most of their time during their absence.

abstract: Counterfeiters' Cases
snippet: Counterfeiters' Cases
lead_paragraph: No. 138 Forsyth-street, presented at the Eric Railway Company's office a spurious five-dollar note on the Merchants' and Mechanics' Bank, of Troy, and then, having been informed of its character, tender-a five-dollar note, which had been altered from a one, on the National Bank, of Paterson, N.J. Mr. CHARLES B. SATTERLEE, the ticket-master, thereupon summoned Policeman TULLY, of the Third Precinct, and SMITH was taken to the Tombs, where the officersfound on his person sixty-seven dollars in genuine bank-notes, and spurious notes on the Union Bank, of Sullivan County, N.Y., Southport Bank, of Connecticut, Williamsburgh City Bank, and Faneull Hall Bank, or Boston. In default of $1,000 bail, the prisoner was committed by Justice HOGAN.

abstract: We violate no confidence in stating, as we do, upon adequate authority, that the House of Representatives has not devoted thirty minutes of all its secret sessions, since the commencement of the present term, to the consideration of peace propositions. This statement will relieve the House and reassure the country, and is, therefore, due to both. We are, of course, not to be understood in the above as saying that no propositions have been presented, for the contrary has been disclosed in the debates in the House. We are satisfied, however, from what we have learned of the spirit of that body. that there is no danger whatever of the passage of any irregular measures, however honestly proposed. Both Houses have just adopted a resolution which speaks to the country in the language of unfaltering heroism and determined purpose, and that resolution may be taken as a key to its legislation on all subjects.

abstract: On Tuesday morning, Jan. 24, about 2 o'clock, the rebel iron-clad fleet from Richmond, five in number, aided by the high state of the water in the James, passed the obstructions in the river, and made a furious attack on the depots, encampments and forts at City Point. The cannonading lasted several hours, and resulted in the complete repulse of the rebel fleet by the forts, the best rebel vessel, the Virginia, being sunk, two others damaged and run aground, and the remainder driven back. But little damage was done on our side.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, Jan. 24, about 2 o'clock, the rebel iron-clad fleet from Richmond, five in number, aided by the high state of the water in the James, passed the obstructions in the river, and made a furious attack on the depots, encampments and forts at City Point. The cannonading lasted several hours, and resulted in the complete repulse of the rebel fleet by the forts, the best rebel vessel, the Virginia, being sunk, two others damaged and run aground, and the remainder driven back. But little damage was done on our side.

abstract: Navigation Laws; Repeal Favored
snippet: Navigation Laws; Repeal Favored
lead_paragraph: that France has taken another step in the direction of free trade. The commission appointed by the Emperor, in 1861, to inquire into the expediency of repealing the navigation laws, have just made an affirmative report. And there appears to be good authority for the statement that during the coming session a bill will be introduced into the Legislative Corps, providing for the repeal of the duties upon all articles which enter into the construction of ships. The bill, it is said, will also provide that, within six months of the passing of the law all foreign vessels will be admitted duty free.

abstract: Greenwich-street, No 521, Incendiary--$5,000
snippet: Greenwich-street, No 521, Incendiary--$5,000
lead_paragraph: CITY NOTES. -- Miss MARIA BRAINERD, the talented soprano of St. Bartholomen's Church, announces a grand concert this evening at Dodworth Hall. A capital programme is offered, under the direction of Dr. CLARE W. BEAMES, Miss BRAINERD will be assisted by such distinguished artists as Mr. ALFRED H. PEASE, piano; Mr. THEODORE THOMAS, violin, and Signor REMI, basso....There will be launched from the ship-yard of Messrs. PINE & DAVIS, this morning, at 8 o'clock, a beautiful yacht, constructed for the China trade, and called Yang. She is 600 tons, constructed under LLOYD's inspection, and represented a very superior vessel. The same firm will, on Saturday, at 10 o'clock, launch a very fine ship of 1,400 tons, intended for the California and Pacific trade....The fee at the Central Park and on the various private ponds was in excellent condition yesterday, and immense numbers of skaters availed themselves of the fact....Rev. ALEXANDER R. THOMPSON has been commissioned as a Chaplain by Gov. ANDREW, of Massachusetts, and assigned to duty at the New-England Rooms, in this city, in place of the late Rev. Dr. BETHUNE.

abstract: Cabinet; Virginia Delegation advise resignation of
snippet: Cabinet; Virginia Delegation advise resignation of
lead_paragraph: We understand that the entire Virginia delegation in Congress, with the exception of one member, united a few days ago in the recommendation that the members of the Cabinet, with the exception of Mr. THENHOLM, resign their positions. The resignation of Mr. SEDDON, which took place on Friday, may or may not be connected with this recommendation. It is thought the existing Cabinet has pretty nearly exhausted its intellectual resources without achieving any very brilliantly illuminated individual fame, and that a new set, with fresh ideas and wide-awake characteristics, is especially desirable at the present time. Late yesterday evening an alarming rumor attained circulation, to the effect that Gen. Bragg had been appointed Secretary of War. Notwithstanding the absurdity of the rumor, and the well-known fact that the Senate would not confirm such nomination. Yet the rumor circulated widely, and produced universal gloom. Without any knowledge about the appointment, we feel justified in stamping this rumor as utterly without foundation.

abstract: In the year 1853, JOHN A. LOGAN, now a General in the Union army, was a member of the House of Representatives in the Legislature of Illinois, and introduced into that body a bill prohibiting "the immigration of free persons of color to the State of Illinois, or the setting free of slaves within the limits thereof." Two years later (1855) this bill was passed, with supplementary enactments, since known as "The Black Laws" of the State.

abstract: Grant and Lee on the Capture of
snippet: Grant and Lee on the Capture of
lead_paragraph: The London Times of the 6th inst., has an interesting letter from its Richmond correspondent, under date of December 5. It contains some account of a conversation that had just occurred, in which the interlocutors were Lieut.-Gen. GRANT and a "foreign gentleman in intimate relations with the Confederate Government," who had just come to Richmond from the North. This foreign confederate, it seems, described Gen. GRANT as a gentleman of eminent courtesy, tranquil and dignified in manner, free from bluster, and studiously conciliating in language." Gen. GRANT, we are told, commenced the conversation by praising the abilities of DAVIS and LEE, and then proceeded to give his views of the prospect of capturing Richmond. The correspondent writes that.

abstract: Butler vs. Brooks; vs Brooks; Butler vs.Brooks
snippet: Butler vs. Brooks; vs Brooks; Butler vs.Brooks
lead_paragraph: We have not the slightest doubt that Gen. BUTLER'S "gold robbery" is by this time a painful subject enough for Mr. JAMES BROOKS, and we are satisfied that a month hence he will consider the mere mention of it in his presence highly offensive. It is not often that a matter so small and insignificant in itsell furnishes occasion for the display of such enormous power of self-stultification as Mr. BROOKS exercised in the debate of Monday and Tuesday. We need hardly say that the most besotted advocate of parliamentary privilege in the worst days of parliamentary tyranny, never pretended that the "freedom of debate " included the privilege of charging anybody that a member took a dislike to with criminal offences, without exposure to correction or criticism.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. TRUMBULL presented the petition of army chaplains, asking that they may be allowed the same pay that is allowed to line-officers of the same rank, The House Bankrupt Bill was reported with amendments and ordered to be printed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. TRUMBULL presented the petition of army chaplains, asking that they may be allowed the same pay that is allowed to line-officers of the same rank, The House Bankrupt Bill was reported with amendments and ordered to be printed. The memorial of Ex-Surgeon-General HAMMOND was reported back, and the Committee discharged from the further consideration of the subject. A resolution was adopted instructing the Finance Committee to inquire into the expediency of relieving the tonnage of the country from the income tax find reducing the duty on chains and anchors. The resolution of the Military Committee, advisingretaliation upon the rebels, was discussed at some length by Messrs. CLARK, HENDERSON, SAULSBURY, WADE and FOSTER. Mr. WADE moved an amendment, making the resolution mandatory instead of advisory, and compelling the President and officers of the army to retaliate in kind; but no action was taken in the matter. The Senate voted to adhere to its amendment of the Deficiency Bill, and the bill consequently fails on account of disagreement between the two Houses.

abstract: The annual message of Gov. FENTON, of this state, has been wrought out in the most marvelously minute and beautiful style of chiography by the accomplished artist in this kind of work, Mr. DAVID DAVIDSON, of No. 204 East Broadway. The message of Gov. FENTON occupied nearly six columns of the fine print of the TIMES, and yet the whole of it has been written by the pen on twenty-two lines of ordinary Bristol board. Though the characters are so extremely minute, the text is perfectly clear and legible, and can easily be read by the naked eye. Mr. DAVIDSON has only the original copy, but it ought to be photographed for the benefit of those who would like to have a copy of such an ingenious production. The artist was engaged upon it twenty-three days and nights, and has made the most remarkable success in this style of thing that we have ever seen. Each character is a work of art, and the aggregate is a complete artistic work.

abstract: THE KILLING OF POLICEMAN CURRAN CONVICTION OF THE PRISONER OF MURDER IN THE FIRST DEGREE. The trial of THEODORE YATES, indicated for the murder of Policeman CHARLES CURRAN, was concluded in the Kings Country Court of Oyer and Terminer last evening, and resulted in a verdict of murder in the first degree.
lead_paragraph: THE KILLING OF POLICEMAN CURRAN -- CONVICTION OF THE PRISONER OF MURDER IN THE FIRST DEGREE. -- The trial of THEODORE YATES, indicated for the murder of Policeman CHARLES CURRAN, was concluded in the Kings Country Court of Oyer and Terminer last evening, and resulted in a verdict of murder in the first degree. As shown by the evidence, the prisoner attended a political meeting at the corner of Prospect-street and Hudson-avenue, on the evening of the 1st of October last. While there he got into a dispute with some men in regard to the presidential candidates, and offered to bet that LINCOLN would be elected. Some blows were struck, and YATES drew a pistol and fired, the ball grazing the head of a gentleman named MCJENNA, but inflicting no serious injury. The prisoner then ran to make his escape, keeping the pistol still in his hand, and followed by a large crowd of excite! people. On reaching the corner of Water and Adams streets. YATES was seized by Officer CURRAN. Being unable to free himself from the officer's grasp, he threatened to shoot if he did not let go, and almost at the same instant fired, the ball entering Mr. CURRAN's skull. The prisoner, still pursued by the crowd, who cried out "Stop the murderer," ran to the corner of York and Pearl streets, where, entering a public house, he went up stairs, and secreted himself under a bed in one of the upper rooms, his hiding-place was soon discovered and he was taken into custody. He still retained possession of the revolver, and it was found that three barrels had been discharged and two were still loaded. CURRAN was conveyed to the City Hospital, where he died a few days thereafter. Several witnesses were examined for the defence, and counsel attempted to show that the prisoner was unaware of CURRAN's official character, or he would not have fired, -- but supposed him to be one of the crowd who were pursuing him with so much ferocity; that believing himself in danger of his life he defended himself as best he could. It was held that, under the circumstances, the act was not premeditated, but came under that class of cases in which a jury could consistently decide upon a verdict of justifiable homicide.

abstract: The flag-of-truce steamer which arrived below on Friday brought among her passengers FRANCIS P. BLAIR, Sr., an route for Richmond again.
lead_paragraph: The flag-of-truce steamer which arrived below on Friday brought among her passengers FRANCIS P. BLAIR, Sr., an route for Richmond again. Whether Mr. BLAIR forgot something when he left the other day, or is desirous of leaving something before he goes for good, has not transpired; but it is evident that the "end of BLAIR," as announced by a Northern paper, is not yet. This return of a gentleman in the confidence of LINCOLN will, of course, reawaken peace rumors. It will bear a significant look to many, who cannot appreciate how Mr. BLAIR's private papers, lost six months ago, should suddenly be worth so much trouble as Mr. BLAIR is now taking, ostensibly to reclaim them. If the mission of the indefatigable gentleman is in reality peace, it is the general desire that he will succeed in his efforts. The LINCOLN usurpation has for a long time been fully in possession of our terms and nothing would be more desirable than their acceptance.

abstract: It will be seen, by reference to the Congressional column, that the Senate has made public its action, to which we earnestly alluded some days ago, with reference to the creation of the office of Commander-in-chief, and the reinstatement of Gen. JOHNSTON.
lead_paragraph: It will be seen, by reference to the Congressional column, that the Senate has made public its action, to which we earnestly alluded some days ago, with reference to the creation of the office of Commander-in-chief, and the reinstatement of Gen. JOHNSTON. The first matter is accomplished by bill, as an independent measure of Congress, leaving to the Executive only what it may constitutionally claim, its appointing power in the premises.

abstract: Olend, Iowa; Desperate Gang of Robbers Broken Up
snippet: Olend, Iowa; Desperate Gang of Robbers Broken Up
lead_paragraph: The Oquawka (Ill.) Spectator gives a very interesting account of what it terms the "Olena Tragedy." From the narrative, it appears that a Mr. DAVIDS, who had been to the western part of Iowa to buy a farm, on his return fell in with a couple of men, who persuaded him to let them ride with him some distance. After they had kept him company a day or two, they took advantage of a lonely part of the road to discover themselves as highwaymen by demanding his money, presenting a loaded [???]ver to compel compliance with their demands. [???]. DAVIDS had no alternative but to yield to their [???]ts, and surrendered all the funds he had with him -- $24 in all. To extricate himself from the difficulty, and to recover his money, if possible, he feigned to be a member of the gang of thieves to which these wretches belonged, and succeeded in convincing them of the fact so well that they returned him most of his money, and consented to assist him in undertaking to rob several wealthy citizens of Olena, near Burlington, Iowa. Upon reaching that place, Mr. DAVIDS promptly informed these gentlemen of the facts, and plans were immediately perfected to kill or capture the robbers, who had meanwhile brought into their project a desperate fellow also living at Olena, who Mr. DAVIDS had named as a member of the gang. The house of Mr. J.J. BROOKS had been selected as the first one to be attempted, and a number of the neighbors armed themselves, and prepared to give the robbers a warm reception, Mr. DAVIDS agreeing to pilot them on the occasion. After one failure to meet an appointment, the gang, numbering three beside Mr. DAVIDS, went to the house of Mr. BROOKS, about 8 o'clock in the evening and asked admittance, alleging some trivial excuse. The door once opened, they forced their way in and demanded an immeate surrender of the valuables in the house. Mr. BROOKS retreated toward the foot of the stairs, and at a prearranged signal the neighbors, who had been stationed in adjoining rooms and out of sight of the robbers, fired. The leader of the gang, a fellow six feet two inches in height, succeeded in firing one or two shots from his revolver before he fell, having been struck by a ball which killed him instantly. Another of the gang received a wound of which he died a day or two afterward, and the third was injured, but it is thought will recover. The affair created the most intense excitement in Burlington and vicinity, and vigilance committees were promptly organized to guard against any such attempts in the future, although there is every reason to believe that the treatment which these scoundrels received will be a pretty effectual protection.
headline: {'main': 'The Olena (Iowa) Tragedy.; A DESPERATE GANG OF ROBBERS BROKEN UP.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Olena (Iowa) Tragedy.; A DESPERATE GANG OF ROBBERS BROKEN UP.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On the 10th inst., a resolution of Mr. LAIMBEER's was adopted by the Senate, appointing a committee to make a general investigation of certain departments of the City and County Government, as follows: Tax Commissioner's, City Inspector's, Street Commissioner's, Croton Aqueduct, Surrogate's and Board of Supervisors; and to report the results of such investigation to the Senate, with such recommendations as in the judgment of the committee may best promote the interests of citizens and tax-payers. Yesterday morning, Mr. A.B. HULL, Sergeant-at-Arms of the Senate, served a notice on Mayor GUNTHER to appear before the committee at noon to-day, in Room No. 6, in the building No. 41 Chambers-street, and to bring with him a copy of his communication to the Common Council suspending City Inspector BOOLE from office, and also a copy of the reasons assigned for such suspension.

lead_paragraph: THEODORE YATES, convicted of the murder of Policeman CHARLES CURRAN, was brought up before the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning for sentence. abstract: The French in Mexico; Cession and Dr. Gwin; Kirby,Offering his Army to Maximilian
snippet: The French in Mexico; Cession and Dr. Gwin; Kirby,Offering his Army to Maximilian
lead_paragraph: San Francisco another and more explicit statement of the reported "cession" by MAXIMILIAN of several of the Northern States of Mexico to the French Emperor, and the appointment of Dr. GAVIN as Governor-General, or Vice-Secretary, under the authority of NAPOLEON. There are several inconsistencies in this statement apart from the absurdity of the report about Dr. GWIN. The conveyance of security by MAXIMILIAN to reimburse France for the expenses of the Mexican war is no new thing, as that was one of the conditions on which MAXIMILIAN got his sceptre. The statement, therefore, that several of these States have been conveyed to the French Emperor by trust deed, is not unlikely. But there is a vast difference between simply that and an absolute "cession" of the States, placing them under the control of NAPOLEON, who would therefore provide a military force for their protection, and the appointment of a Governor of some kind would not be out of place. If the States are absolutely "ceded" by MAXIMILIAN to his master, then they simply become a French Province; but if only "held in trust," then they can only become such when MAXIMILIAN defaults on the payment of the war debt.

abstract: City Point Attack a Blessing in Disguise
snippet: City Point Attack a Blessing in Disguise
lead_paragraph: light of the late attempt on the part of the rebel iron-clad fleet to push past the obstructionsin the James River, at Trent's Reach, for the purpose of smashing up our base of operations at City Point, and dealing death and destruction generally, it is very clear that the failure of the Dutch Gap enterprise was a "blessing in disguise" to us; certainly as great a blessing and more immediate in its benefits than the closing of the port of Wilmingtonhas been to the rebels. Had the Gap been open the mailed monsters Virginia, Fredericksburgh and Lynchburgh would have steamed through and run a muck without let or hindrance. There was no navy to bar the way, for it does not appear in the accounts that a shot was fired except from the land batteries -- Fort Brady above Dutch Gap and Fort Parsons at Bermuda Hundred, commanding the Howlett House fortifications. A special interposition of Providence was that temporary failure of Dutch Gap.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was passed relative to the pay of clerks and others employed in the several New-York City Departments. The State Bounty Bill was ordered to a third reading. A bill was reported for raising the money by direct tax, in case the Loan Bill does not receive the approval of the people, and another, in case both these should fail, authorizing towns and counties to pay bounties. Notice was given of a bill to create a new ward in New-York. A bill was introduced enabling husband and wife to be witnesses for or against each other. The bill o pay the members of the New-York Common Council $2,500 per year was taken up. An amendment was moved abolishing the Board of Councilmen.

abstract: Prospects Ahead; and Wilmington Cotton Prospects ahead
snippet: Prospects Ahead; and Wilmington Cotton Prospects ahead
lead_paragraph: The rapid dissolution of the Confederacy as a military power, forces into the foreground the great question of the return of the cotton trade to something like what may be called its normal condition. In spite of all the flying reports and predictions that have been uttered to the contrary, the people of the South have not made a general bonfire of their cotton accumulations. They destroyed small quantities, or there is at least sufficient evidence that the Confederate soldiery destroyed small quantities in the parishes adjoining New-Orleans, after the capture of that city. They did the same at Baton Rouge, at Natchez, at Vicksburgh, at and around Jackson, and at several points along the Red River. But there is not a scintilla of evidence to show that the mandates of the Richmond military authorities in regard to the destruction of cotton were obeyed, except where there were military agents present in sufficient numbers, at particular points, to overawe and to defy the opinion of the civilian population whose property interests were concerned. In Savannah, where, as it has turned out, the conscripts and agents of DAVIS were not sufficiently strong to carry out the behests of the Richmond oligarchy, the cotton was spared. Even the rebel journals admit that the accumulations there and in the neighborhood, were nearly five times greater in amount than SHERMAN and FOSTER, in their first reports, estimated them to be. Not a bale of this was given to the flames, in spite of the oft-repeated and loud-mouthed protestations of rebels North and South, and Anglo-rebel sympathisers abroad. The vast cotton stock at Savannah was saved because the non-militant population refused to sacrifice it.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- There was a great demand yesterday for boxes, reserved scats, &c., for the ensuing season of Italian opera, which bids fair to be one of the best patronized of Mr. MARETZEK's entire campaign. We hear also that it is to be the last until next Fall, but this can hardly relate to the first twenty-four performances. The box-office will be open for season tickets until Saturday. On Monday the sale of evening vouchers will commence.

abstract: An official dispatch from Admiral PORTER, dated "Off Smithville, N.C., Jan. 20," gives the details of the blowing up of Fort Caswell by the enemy on the 16th, and the subsequent evacuation of all the other works in that vicinity, including Bald-Head Fort, Forts Campbell and Shaw, and the foot at Smithville, all of the very strongest character, and mounting eight, nine and ten-inch guns, and one Armstrong 150-pounder. The total number of guns captured in these works was 83, which, added to the number captured at Fort Fisher, makes 155 cannon as the trophies of four days' operations. Two blockade-runners, the Charlotte and Slag, had been captured by running into the river past Fort Fisher, only to discover our fleet inside. Another was captured by the fleet outside.

abstract: -- Mr. ABRAM SMITH, book-keeper for Mr. FRANCIS B. BALDWIN, of Nos. 70 and 72 Bowery, appeared before Justice SHANDLEY and complained that JOSEPH LEVY, of No. 62 Essex-street, had stolen from Mr. BALDWIN's clothing warehouse a piece of goods of the value of $72. It appears that LEVY, while in Mr. BALDWIN's employ, proposed that Mr. SMITH should give him spurious checks, and that the two should share equally to the proceeds. Mr. SMITH seemingly acquiesced, but instead of becoming LEVY's confederate made known the proposition, and was instructed by Mr. BALDWIN to utter the checks. LEVY was apprehended by Officer WOOD, of the Tenth Precinct, and committed by Justice SHANDLEY, in default of $1,000 ball...... THOMAS BOYLE, a laborer at the Hudson River Railroad Company's Twelfth-street depot, was apprehended by Officer ROCKWELL, of the Ninth Precinct, and committed by Justice DODGE, upon complaint of Mr. WILLETT G. VANDEMARK, freight agent, alleging that the prisoner had stolen a freight from the railroad company's office. ...... SARAH CAMPBELL, for stealing a silk dress from NELLIE ASHTON, of No. 66 Cherry-street, and ANN MURPHY, for stealing $57 and a shawl from CATHARINE RENAIN, of No. 162 1/2 Broadway, were committed, yesterday, by Justice HOGAN.

abstract: The city was somewhat excited yesterday on the subject of the draft, and justly so, as far as the action of the Provost-Marshal-General is concerned. The incomprehensible arithmetic of Gen. FRY is based upon a system entirely new to the learned, and offers to mathematicians a problem worthy of profound study. As yet it is pons asinorum, over which only its author has passed. When the new draft was ordered Gen. FRY, by some equally intricate calculations, announced that the quota of the County of New-York was fixed at 4,400. This was divided by him among the sub-districts in the proper ratio and efforts were made to fill this quota before the expiration of the day of grace. It was officials communicated to the Provost-Marshals of the Eighth and Ninth Districts, that the quota of their Districts had been filled under all calls, and that no men would be required from them under the present order Elated by the triumphant result of their labors, the Assistant Provost-Marshal of the Eighth District trotted out a small field-piece and fired a salute in Madison-square, to let the world know that the Eighth District was out of the draft. Now, we refer to this merely as an instance to show how much injustice the vacillation of Gen. FRY will work. The quota now demanded from the Eighth District, is 3,348, and, lulled into security by the first order, no exertions have been made to fill it; while forty working days have passed, and but twenty days remain in which to get the men. The denunciations of Gen. FRY throughout the city, yesterday, were not confined to any party -- they were universal. Such a policy, unstable, shifting, and passing all understanding, breeds more opposition to the conscription act than a mere enforcement of its provisions, carried out in a just and equitable manner, would ever cause. Men knowing what is before them, can prepare to meet the contingencies of a draft. They can set their homes in order, and make up their minds to go themselves or send a substitute to represent them; but with such a senseless shifting of chances, none but the exempts can form any settled plans.

abstract: -- Coroner GOVER completed an inquest over the body of WILLIAM H. JOHNSON, who died on Wednesday morning from fractures of the skull, received in a Chatham-street den on Wednesday evening of last week, at the hands, the Jury say, of one "Shem." JOHNSON was 28 years of age. "Shem" and one PATRICK HEFFRON, against whom the Jury have found a verdict, are at large, and the females, whom the police arrested as witnesses, have been released on $500 ball each. One COHEN, who is alleged to have been one of the gang that made the murderous assault upon JOHNSON, is held in the Tombs..... HENRY YELVERTON, who on Wednesday evening shot and instantly killed JOHNSON K. POLLOCK in KATE BURKE's apartments, in Lispenard-street, is yet at large, and to the end that Capt. PETTY's officers have opportunity to apprehend him. Coroner WILDEY has postponed the inquest to Saturday morning. The girl BURKE, meantime, in held by Capt. PETTY at the Fifth Precinct Police Station. Young POLLOCK's body has been taken to No. 382 Washington street, where his mother resides.... An inquest was held by Coroner GAMBLE, on Governor's Island, upon the body of JOHN CONNEGAN, a soldier, who is supposed to have been killed in a drunken fight on the island on Saturday afternoon last. CONNEGAN was 30 years of age.

abstract: Last night the enemy made an unsuccessful attempt to run past our batteries. They took advantage of the storm and darkness to send down a fleet of eight vessels-of-war and three torpedo-boats. This flotilla consisted of the Virginia, Fredericksburgh and Richmond, iron-clads, mounting four guns each; the wooden vessels Drury, Nansemond and Hampton, of two guns each; the Bedford, one gun; the steamer Torpedo, and three torpedo-boats.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the credentials of Mr. SAULSBURY, Senator elect from Delaware for six years from the 4th of March next, were presented. A bill for the construction of a bridge over the Ohio at Louisville was reported and laid over. A petition from Mr. WEBB, asking for increased compensation for building the iron-clad Dunderberg, was referred to the Naval Committee. The House bill was passed authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to issue Treasury notes in lieu of any bonds authorized by the Act of June 30, 1864. The House bill to make appropriation for the Military Academy was passed, as was also the House bill making appropriation for the support of the Post-office Department for the next fiscal year. Communications were laid before the Senate from the Secretary of War, in relation to the loyal owners of enlisted slaves, and in relation to the thirty and hundred day volunteers from Delaware. The resolution advising retaliation upon the rebels, for cruelty to our prisoners in their hands, was again taken up and discussed.

abstract: Insubordination; Evils of Porter's Report; Threats to Foreign Powers
snippet: Insubordination; Evils of Porter's Report; Threats to Foreign Powers
lead_paragraph: It has always been charged on Americans, that one great fault in their character, was insubordination, or an indisposition to obey. This war has done a great deal to cure this. Military law and military success alike demand the most absolute obedience of the inferior to the superior. There must be no hesitancy and no equivocation. Subordination is the main condition in martial affairs, of celerity, order, and victory. Our whole people and our leaders have learned a new and most useful lesson -- to obey; and certainly no better foundation for true liberty can be found than the self-control gained in a voluntary and intelligent obedience. Many of the troubles we have had among ourselves during the war, and some of our dangers, have come from the want of this excellent virtue in some of our officers.

abstract: The Peace Delusion; Delusion; The; Blair's Mission
snippet: The Peace Delusion; Delusion; The; Blair's Mission
lead_paragraph: Mr. BLAIR has returned to Washington, but the confident predictions so widely indulged upon his second departure for Richmond, that he would bring back Peace Commissioners with him, do not seem to have been realized. So far as we are at present informed, he comes alone; nor can we learn that he brings anything, written or verbal, calculated to encourage the belief that JEFF. DAVIS is yet disposed to acknowledge defeat, sue for mercy, and tender his submission.

abstract: Meade, H W M, Photographer
snippet: Meade, H W M, Photographer
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning Mr. HENRY W.M. MEADE, late of the firm of Messrs. MEADE BROTHERS, of No. 233 Broadway, was found dead in his bed at the Tammany Hotel. On the table in his room were four empty phials, with the apothecaries' labels and the written word "poison" thereon, and five letters to his friends, which we give below, as tending to throw light upon the case which we have in hand. These phials are small, the largest probably not having contained more than an ounce of poison, or about the quantity which a druggist might unsuspectingly supply to any applicant whose movements were not manifestly those of a maniac. From the statements of Mr. JOHN E. BROWN, clerk at Tammany Hotel, it appears that Mr. MEADE, who had frequently tarried over night at that house, applied for a room and registered himself as "H.W. SHANAGER, of New-York;" that he retired, but before locking his door ordered a hot brandy sling, and this was sent up. He then exhibited no evidence of aberration, and no person in the house gave him another thought until late yesterday morning, when he was found as above stated. A messenger was at once dispatched to the Coroner's office, and Coroner GAMBLE and Drs. PARADISE, WELTJE and SHAW promptly responded, and the two latter at once made a post-mortem examination, which revealed nearly three ounces of laudanum in the stomach. This, the empty phials, and the deceased's letters, rendered it a clear case of suicide, and the jury so declared it to be. The following are the deceased's last letters, and these we present without comment:

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Hibernian at Portland, yesterday, we have intelligence from Europe to the 13th inst. English papers advance nothing new on American affairs. abstract: The return of Mr. BLAIR from his second mission to Richmond was announced yesterday morning, and the result of his mission became known in this city yesterday afternoon. That result is fully set forth in our special Washington dispatches, and is, in brief, "failure" complete and entire. The only conditions on which DAVIS will negotiate for peace is on the basis of two independent nations, and an armistice.
lead_paragraph: The return of Mr. BLAIR from his second mission to Richmond was announced yesterday morning, and the result of his mission became known in this city yesterday afternoon. That result is fully set forth in our special Washington dispatches, and is, in brief, "failure" -- complete and entire. The only conditions on which DAVIS will negotiate for peace is on the basis of two independent nations, and an armistice.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was introduced to amend the State militia law. Among the  bills passed was one legalizing the acts relative to the bounty bonds of Brooklyn. A resolution was introduced providing that a Select Commit  tee be appointed to ascertain, by correspondence with the authorities of Buffalo and all other municipalities in the State, on what terms grounds and buildings for a new capitol can be obtained.

abstract: Daniel G. Bradley and another, vs. Bethuel C. Wheeler stet. -- The plaintiffs in this action made an agreement with the defendants for the sale of hay then on the barge of the plaintiffs', and were delivering it on board the schooner of the defendants' when the hay caught fire and was burned. The plaintiffs now claim the contract price if the hay, (which was not disputed.) on the ground that the sale was complete, and the hay belonged to the defendants and was at their risk. The question being whether anything remained to be done by the seller (the plaintiff) to complete the sale, evidence was given to show that the barge was under their control, but that it was understood that the plaintiffs might retail the hay before delivering it, and the defendants should receive the balance, and that there was an inspector to examine the quality of the bay, and talliers employed by the seller to ascertain the quantity. On all these points contradictory evidence was given. The Judge charged the jury that it anything remained to be done by the seller to ascertain the identity, quantity or quality of the hay, the sale was not complete, and they must find for the defendants; otherwise for the plaintiffs.
lead_paragraph: Daniel G. Bradley and another, vs. Bethuel C. Wheeler stet. -- The plaintiffs in this action made an agreement with the defendants for the sale of hay then on the barge of the plaintiffs', and were delivering it on board the schooner of the defendants' when the hay caught fire and was burned. The question being whether anything remained to be done by the seller (the plaintiff) to complete the sale, evidence was given to show that the barge was under their control, but that it was understood that the plaintiffs might retail the hay before delivering it, and the defendants should receive the balance, and that there was an inspector to examine the quality of the bay, and talliers employed by the seller to ascertain the quantity. lead_paragraph: Whatever exaggerations there may be in the reports published yesterday of the cession by MAXIMILLIAN of Northern Mexico to the Emperor NAPOLEON, of the main fact we have no doubt. It is simply carrying out the original programme. That NAPOLEON entered on his Mexican campaign merely for glory, or in the interest of civilization merely, no one ever believed. He may make war "for an idea" as he did in Italy; but in all other cases, as in that, he is careful to receive some substantial advantage to himself by way of reward. After liberating Italy, he took Savoy and Nice as his compensation. Having saved Mexico from anarchy, he is quite certain to appropriate to himself a large share of the property rescued from wreck. We have not the slightest doubt that when the Mexican throne was offered to MAXIMILIAN, it was with the distinct understanding that these Northern Provinces of Mexico were to be ceded to France in return.

abstract: Oil Region, Canada; Oil Region; The
snippet: Oil Region, Canada; Oil Region; The
lead_paragraph: If the oil region of Pennsylvania is worthy of the title of Petrolia, then is the corresponding section of Canada West entitled to the designation of Oleagena. During the past three or four years, millions' of gallons of oil of various qualities have been taken from its ground, either through the medium of flowing wells, or by the ordinary pumping process. So enormous was the yield at one period, and of so little mercantile value, the uses of the oil not being known, that Black Creek was covered to the depth of from two to three feet with the crude article, flowing from flowing wells.

abstract: The New-York State Sheep-Breeders' and Wool-Growers' Association will hold its annual meeting in the City Hall in the City of Syracuse, on Wednesday, Feb. 22, at 12 o'clock M. The sheep breeders and wool growers of the State are invited to attend. The Executive Board of the Association will meet the preceding evening to transact important business, and the members are requested to report themselves at the Syracuse House at 7 o'clock P.M. HENRY S. RANDALL, President.

abstract: The campaign which has already been opened by Gen. SHERMAN, and in which the armies operating before Petersburgh and Wilmington, will soon take part, will be the winding-up campaign of the rebellion. It is no secret that great bodies of troops have been coming from the West to take part in it; and whether they reinforce for the moment the army of MEADE, or of TERRY, or of SHERMAN, it is all the same.
lead_paragraph: The campaign which has already been opened by Gen. SHERMAN, and in which the armies operating before Petersburgh and Wilmington, will soon take part, will be the winding-up campaign of the rebellion. It is no secret that great bodies of troops have been coming from the West to take part in it; and whether they reinforce for the moment the army of MEADE, or of TERRY, or of SHERMAN, it is all the same. The campaign is a unit; its combinations are made under the supreme direction of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT; and the enemy to be fought and defeated and destroyed is the army of Gen. LEE near Richmond. GRANT's combinations have always been of a very great kind, both in the West and in the East; and we believe that his final campaign will be the grandest of the war. The Richmond papers of Tuesday last show that the rebels at Richmond are in terror least a movement on the James accompany the other movements under way. LEE, we are told by the Richmond Dispatch, expected an attack on the north side of the James on Sunday last; and it was thought that for that day only the mud saved him. Attacks were also expected elsewhere on the lines, which the rebels fear are only temporarily postponed.
headline: {'main': 'The Winding-up Campaign.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Winding-up Campaign.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The British steamship Charlotte, of London, from Fort Fisher, captured by Admiral PORTER's fleet under the wall of the fort, arrived at the navy-yard yesterday afternoon, in charge of E.W. WHITE, Acting Master. She is an ironside wheel vessel, quite new, of about 800 tons burthen; is 250 feet long, and has a general cargo, consisting of arms, ammunition, medicines, clothing, &c.; was on her second trip from Nassau to Wilmington. Her Captain and passengers are on board.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the credentials of Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, as Senator elect for six years from March next, were presented. Petitions for increase of salary were presented from employes in the departments at Washington. A resolution was offered, and objected to, to inquire into the charge against Gen. JEFF. C. DAVIS, of inhuman conduct toward the negroes who had joined his army in Georgia. A joint resolution was laid on the table, declaring the State of Arkansas to be no longer in insurrection against the United States. A bill was introduced, and referred to the Judiciary Committee, bill to amend the act to restrict the jurisdiction of the Court of Claims and provide for the payment of Quartermaster's stores and subsistence furnished to the Army of the United States. The deficiency bill from the House was then taken up, and alter being amended by striking out the section giving extra compensation to the employes of the capitol, it was passed. The Senate then renewed the consideration of the question of retaliation. Messrs. JOHNSON and SAULSBURY spoke against and Messrs. HOWE, WADE, MORRILL, DOOLITTLE and HOWARD in favor of the resolution.

abstract: -- The February number  of this beautiful monthly teems with the richest and most artistic plates. Among the embellishments is a magnificent engraving entitled "Sappho," with a poetical explanation from the pen of Miss Landon. A splendid piece of music graces its pages called "Anxious Thoughts," with an embellishment. Two fashion plates accompany the book, and it contains complete and thorough instructions as to how to cut and make all articles of dress. This is one of the most attractive and reliable monthlies published in America. -- Delaware State Journal.

abstract: Herr Von BISMARK, in a dispatch replying to an address to the King of Prussia from the King of Schleswig-Holstein, says: "The King has received the address with pleasure, and recognizes therein expressions denoting a right perception of the real state of affairs. The Duchies had a perfect right to claim complete protection against foreign enemies, as well as respect for their internal rights. The King's efforts are directed toward the welfare of the Duchies and toward securing them a position in consonance with their rights. The address strengthens the King's conviction in the confiding cooperation of the country, and His Majesty expects the success of his efforts with so much the more confidence, since he and his illustrious ally meet with cordial and hearty cooperation on the part of the Duchies."
lead_paragraph: Herr Von BISMARK, in a dispatch replying to an address to the King of Prussia from the King of Schleswig-Holstein, says: "The King has received the address with pleasure, and recognizes therein expressions denoting a right perception of the real state of affairs. abstract: The, of 1864
snippet: The, of 1864
lead_paragraph: of the necrological record of the bygone year, which we publish in other columns to-day, will show how rich a harvest death has been reaping. Of those who were or had been in active public life -- some of them high in rank -- among ourselves, a year ago, we miss to-day such names as TANEY, DAYTON, JOSIAH QUINCY, DALLAS, LOVEJOY, GIDDINGS. From among the clergy we find absent Archbishop HUGHES, GORDON and MYRON WINSLOW, EDWARD HITCHCOCK, THOMAS STARR KING, Dr. POTTS, and scores of others scarcely less known through the different sections of the Church. From the catholic world of science, of art and of letters, the ingathering has seldom been so heavy in a single year. We call up, for instance, such names as HAWTHORNE, SILLIMAN, MORRIS, PARK BENJAMIN, WILLIAM HUNT, DAVID ROBERTS, JOHN LEECH, CATHARINE SINCLAIR, WALTER SAVAGE LANDOR, ALARIC A. WATTS, Miss PROCTOR, SPEKE, (the traveler,) N.W. SENIOR; besides in dramatic and lyric art WALLACK, ROBSON and Mrs. WOOD. From the military and naval lists we find absent such glorious names as SEDGWICK, WADSWORTH, MCPHERSON and W.D. PORTER -- how many others, alas! -- scarcely even second to these in the nobility of their record! Of titled and leading representative men in Great Britain and continental Europe, the necrological record is more than of average length. In the list we find the Dukes of NEWCASTLE, ATHOLE and CLEVELAND, the Earls of CARLISLE and ABERDEEN, the Marquis of BRISTOL, Sir WILLIAM ATHERTON, Mr. W.S. O'BRIEN, the Duke of MALAKOFF, M. MOCQUARD, the Chevalier HULSEMANN and the Count GEORGI. A score or more Princes and Princesses might be added to bring up the long funeral train, not including the late reigning sovereigns of Bavaria and Wurtemburg.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Arago, at this port yesterday, from Port Royal Jan. 25, we are in receipt of later intelligence from Gen. SHERMAN'S army and Savannah. No fighting had occurred, although Gen. SHERMAN'S forces were far from being idle. The last of Gen. SHERMAN'S army, under Gen. GEARY, left Savannah on the 20th, Gen. GROVER, with a strong body of reinforcements, had arrived and assumed command of the city.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Arago, at this port yesterday, from Port Royal Jan. 25, we are in receipt of later intelligence from Gen. SHERMAN'S army and Savannah. No fighting had occurred, although Gen. SHERMAN'S forces were far from being idle. The last of Gen. SHERMAN'S army, under Gen. GEARY, left Savannah on the 20th, Gen. GROVER, with a strong body of reinforcements, had arrived and assumed command of the city. Rebel dispatches to the Richmond papers of the 26th and 27th, assert that a heavy body of SHERMAN's troops is moving up the Savannah river, for the purpose of attacking Augusta. Gen. D.H. HILL is in command of the place, and he has ordered that if the exigency requires it, all the public stores, arsenals and powder works must be destroyed. The rebels are evidently in much alarm. We are indebted to Purser ELY, of the Arago, for the prompt delivery of our files and dispatches.

abstract: of Glasgow, on Pulpit and Press; Church and Press in Scotland
snippet: of Glasgow, on Pulpit and Press; Church and Press in Scotland
lead_paragraph: There is a society in Scotland of a quasi religious, quasi ecclesiastical character, styled the "Working Men's Sabbath Protective Association," the main object of which is to get a parliamentary enactment passed to prevent the running of railway trains, the dispatch or distribution of mails, or work of any kind, but what is of the strictest necessity, on the Sabbath-day. The association has recently had its energies aroused to the fullest activity by the proposal of the North British Railway Company to open up a new and more extensive system of Sunday traffic than it has heretofore engaged in. Most of the Free Church Presbyteries of the south and southwest of Scotland have taken decided action in the same way as the Sabbath Protective Association, employing all their power and influence, which, in that particular section of country, is very great, indeed, to compel the Government and the public companies into what is called the "Sabbatarian" view of Sunday obligations and duties. The Free Presbytery of Glasgow, which is composed of many of the ablest clergymen of that branch of the Presbyterian Church, is in the fore front in this battle. And an eminent Professor of the same Church, Mr. GIBSON, speaking for the Presbytery, has thrown down the gauntlet to the secular press of the, whole United Kingdom in a challenge which is almost as formidable as a papal bull. The challenge is put forth on the ground that Prof. GIBSON regards the secular press as all but atheistical or infidel in its sympathies and teachings, especially in all that bears upon the observance of the Fourth Commandment.
headline: {'main': 'The Church and the Press in Scotland.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Church and the Press in Scotland.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: JOHN M. MASON Esq., Attorney and Counselor, of No. 75 Trinity Buildings, and Mr. THOMAS CUTHELL, of No. 37 Park-row, merchant, were insulted, assaulted, and violently thrust from the new cars which the Hudson River Railroad Company have substituted for the old long cars that formerly took passengers down to Chambers-street. It is reported that a serious fight occurred in one or two of these cars yesterday morning, between certain uncivil and ruffianly conductors and a large number of commuters who, having hitherto ridden to Chambers-street without extra charge, insisted upon their indisputable right to ride in the new cars at least until the expiration of the time to which their commutation tickets are dated. THOMAS J. LAIRD and JAMES P. FINNER, conductors, were taken before Justice DODGE, and by him required to find $500 bail, Messrs. MASON and CUTHELL, being complainants. FINNER was fined $10, and committed in default of bail.
lead_paragraph: JOHN M. It is reported that a serious fight occurred in one or two of these cars yesterday morning, between certain uncivil and ruffianly conductors and a large number of commuters who, having hitherto ridden to Chambers-street without extra charge, insisted upon their indisputable right to ride in the new cars at least until the expiration of the time to which their commutation tickets are dated. THOMAS J. LAIRD and JAMES P. FINNER, conductors, were taken before Justice DODGE, and by him required to find $500 bail, Messrs. MASON and CUTHELL, being complainants. abstract: -- The trial before a court-martial of one of the hotel burners, whose true name has at length been disclosed, and is ROBERT COBB KENNEDY, Captain in the First Louisiana Infantry, has been commenced, but the proceedings are secret. On Thursday night last a knife was discovered under the bed in his cell at police headquarters, and it is thought that with this instrument he intended to make his escape by assassinating his keeper. He little knew the strength of his prison walls or how closely they were guarded.

abstract: Compliment to by Sanannah People

lead_paragraph: We are informed that the pens of ballast placed in the north channel, or a portion of them, have been removed, so as to render the main ship channel navigable for vessels of light draught. There are many other obstructions yet to be removed, but under the management of Capt. BENNETT, of the Board of Underwriters, and his indefatigable corps, we hope at an early day, to be able to report the removal of these impediments to our river navigation.

abstract: The California journals are discussing the subject of the Emperor NAPOLEON'S colonization scheme in Northern Mexico, and generally take the view that it will relieve the State of Southern malcontents and rebel sympathizers, many of whom are already preparing to leave under the invitation of Dr. GWIN, and that eventually American settlers will revolutionize the country it the Monroe Doctrine is not sooner asserted by the United States Government.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, it was voted to publish the correspondence of JAMES MADISON. Mr. SPRAGUE introduced a bill to increase the pay of members of Congress from &3,000 to $5,000 per annum. A resolution calling on the Secretary of War for information as to the number of troops furnished by each State was adopted. A spicy discussion sprang up on a resolution offered by Mr. DAVIS, to appoint a select committee of five on the "Corruptions of the Government." Pending which, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The most severe loss occasioned by the fire of yesterday morning, in Camp-street, arises from the destruction of the notarial records of HUGH MADDEN, Esq., Notary Public. These comprise the records of the following notaries public: WM. Y. LEWIS, S.H. LEWIS, E.L. LEWIS, and PARIS CHILDRESS, from 1825 to 1857; also the records of D.I. RICARDO, I.P. GILLY, and S.W. WATERS, from 1846 to 1853. The records of WM. Y. LEWIS covered some most important acts connected with commerce and real estate. He was an average adjuster for twenty years.

abstract: And Russia in the East
snippet: And Russia in the East
lead_paragraph: Since the death of the Macedonian ALEXANDER, the office of "Great King" has been in abeyance -- the sceptre of Asia has been wielded by no single hand. But two great Powers are now in the arena contending for the empire of the Orient, and endeavoring by arms and intrigue to extend their dominion over that vast and populous continent. These rivals are Russia and England -- the one advancing from the North, the other from the South. The one pressing onward from the "icy regions" of Siberia, and the other from the "burning plains of Ind."
