abstract: Varona, Aug; De Lunatico Inquiry
snippet: Varona, Aug; De Lunatico Inquiry
lead_paragraph: In the matter of an application to have AUGUSTIN VARONA declared of unsound mind, a commission was issued to HENRY H. MORANGE, RICHARD C. BEAMISH, and Dr. F.A. PUTNAM to inquire into the above matter. A jury having been impanneled, evidence was given by PEDRO PIETO, who testified to an acquaintance with the alleged in [???] and to various acts tending to show that he [???] unsound mind. JOSEPH VARONA, the cousin, at whose instance the proceeding was taken, testified to his relationship to the alleged lunatic; that he had known him from childhood; that he became insane about twenty years ago; that the alleged lunatic was 48 years of age when incarcerated in the Bloomingdale Asylum; was a native of Principe, in the Island of Cuba. The witness the gave a detailed account of Mr. VARONA's family relations, and stated that he had three brothers and two sisters; that from the time of his insanity he had imagined that one of his brothers-in-law intended assassinating him; that there was no insanity in the family though his mother was at times peculiarly eccentric; about 1852 he was imprisoned as a lunatic, and that his mother secured his release on ball, and had kept him confined in her house till her death, (about three years ago;) that since the death of his mother his brother Frederick had had charge of him, but that on the complaint of the neighbors, the Governor had directed that the lunatic be imprisoned, or that he be sent from the country; that he was accordingly sent to the care of the witness, for the purpose of placing him in an asylum; but that when he arrived here he seemed so much improved that the witness did not confine him, but left him at large; that last Summer he went traveling with another young friend, and on returning went to a Mrs. Hart's boarding-house in Bleecker-street, near Sullivan; that from Mrs. Hart witness received a letter informing him (witness) that he must remove his cousin, he being insane; that he called upon Mrs. Hart, accompanied by Dr. Loomis, and found him utterly insane; he talked about planetary combinations against him, and the friendship of England and the unity of France toward him; that he was going to Washington to get $20,000 from the President, (for which he had no claim;) that he was incoherent in speech, and worse than he had ever before seen him; that he had him removed to the Bloomingdale Asylum, where he had now been eight days; that he had squandered the patrimony he received from his father twenty years ago, and that he now had a life-interest derived from his mother's estate, amounting to about $800 a year in gold; that the only property of the lunatic now in this country was about $500, the remainder of $1,500 received by him in November last, which he had left in the hands of a lady at his boarding-house, and which was now in the Manhattan Savings Bank.

snippet: Wheelock, Brig-Gen.; Lee, Robert P; Lost on the Melville; Jackson, Dr Robert M S.
lead_paragraph: Referring to the late Brevet Brig.-Gen. WHEELOCK, who died at Washington a few days ago, the Albany Evening Journal says: "At the outbreak of the war, he was engaged in a large and prosperous business. This he abandoned after the fall of Sumter, and immediately devoted himself to raising men for the army, pledging himself to provide for their families. In a conversation with the writer of this, in the Summer of 1861, he said: "I am worth, I think, in the neighborhood of $10,000. Half of this I have already given of pledged; and if my country wants the other half, it can have it and myself in the bargain." Becoming impatient with the slow progress of the war, be soon after commenced raising a regiment on his own hook, fed and housed several hundred men at his personal expense for many months, and after a series of embarrassments and disappointments that would have disheartened almost any other man, completed its organization and marched it to the field. Entirely without military experience, and with but a very limited general education, he become one of the best volunteer officers in the service, and so signally distinguished himself that he was breveted Brigadier-General for bravery and good soldiership. He had seen much service, was engaged in many of the bloodiest battles in Virginia, was taken prisoner, if we mistake not, at the second battle of Bull Run, and tasted for many months the sweets of prison life at Richmond, but was subsequently exchanged, when he rejoined his old regiment and did more gallant service in behalf of the old flag. He had the true heroic mettle, and would, had he lived, still further made his mark as a soldier.

abstract: The Special Committee on Volunteering held session yesterday, but transacted no business in consequence of the absence of the Mayor and Comptroller. At present the committee have no funds on hand, and consequently are unable to offer increased bounties or larger sums as hand-money. There does not, however, appear to be any idea among the members of the committee that the quota can be raised even by doubling the bounties. Public opinion is freely expressed as to the action taken by Provost-Marshal-General FRY in regard to this city, which is characterized as unjust. Had an earlier notification been given of the increase of the quota, this city, it is believed, could have raised the requisite number of men, but it is now felt by all to be impossible. There seems to be a general idea, or at least a hope, that the Provost-Marshal will reconsider his decision, and place us where we were before.

abstract: The Cuba, with dates to the 15th. arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, from Liverpool. Her news is two days later, but unimportant. the Prime Ministers of Sweden and the Netherlands had written exceedingly neutral replies to the manifesto sent them by the rebel commissioners. ALFRED TENNY, SON, Poet Laureate, had been created a Baronet. Lady BROUHAM is dead. The Italian Government has cautioned the clergy against publishing the Pope's encyclical without first receiving an authorization. The steamer Lelia, a blockade-runner, from Liverpool for Wilmington via Bermuda, was totally lost January 15, off the bar of the Mersey. The loss of life is from 18 to 40.

abstract: Parliament of; Debate on United States Relations
snippet: Parliament of; Debate on United States Relations
lead_paragraph: In the Legislative Assembly, Jan. 23, the Address in answer to the Speech being under discussion, Col. Haultain echoed the statements in the Speech with inference to the outrages which had been committed on the territory of the United States by persons seeking in our hospitality immunity from their evil deeds. He spoke not as a lawyer but as a soldier, and declared that these acts were not war. He congratulated the country on the prompt steps which had been taken to put an end to these acts, and was glad the House was asked to give larger powers to prevent these sets for the future, and to punish those who might perpetrate them. No thoughtful man could contemplate a war between Great Britain and America, without shuddering at the idea. Nevertheless, we ought to prepare for defence. Four years ago, the military position was all in our favor. Then we were an integral part of the greatest military and naval nation in the world, while the Americans had but small numbers of soldiers, a few, though admirably appointed ships. Now, the American armies mustered by hundreds and thousands, and their ships were numberless. What, then, was to be done? Fortify the weak portals, in order to retard the enemy and give time to train the defenders of the country. We must also gradually train the population of this country. We were not, like the mother country, defended by sea; so that her partially trained forces can never be hastily called into action. Our levies would be brought suddenly into collision with the invaders, who, if they meant attack, would certainly not give us time to prepare for it. We must, therefore, have a number of trained men; we must also have more military schools to fit those who are to take command of the armies which would have to be called out. So, again, we should forward the instruction of the volunteers, and last, though net least, he mentioned that we shall require, as military adviser of the Government, one who, from military experience, is competent to give counsel for military affairs: who should be willing to think that he had much to learn of the people and the country, and by going among the people, would give them confidence in his management.

abstract: The; Sanitary Condition and Small Pox
snippet: The; Sanitary Condition and Small Pox
lead_paragraph: The condition of the city in the matter of small-pox, requires immediate and vigorous attention by the authorities. More than forty deaths by this disease were reported for a recent week, and, allowing twelve cases for each death, we should have some five hundred cases for a single week. This, we are convinced, is a low estimate -- the number is much nearer one thousand. There is not a school in which children of the laboring classes attend, where a number of cases are not reported; the tenement-houses are full of it, as any dispensary visitor will inform one; the Small-pox Hospital is crowded to overflowing. We hear of the disease on every hand; and yet, as is well known, the relatives of the persons diseased will seldom report them as cases of small-pox, on account of the odium it excites in the tenement-houses, and the fear of their removal to the public hospitals. All the poorer parts of the city we believe now to be more or less infected with this pest. And it appears we are spreading it to the country and the army.
headline: {'main': 'The Small-Pox Precautions.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Small-Pox Precautions.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gratifying Results of
snippet: Gratifying Results of
lead_paragraph: It was hardly likely that we Americans should learn either theoretically or practically that taxation is a science, so long as the fiscal requirements of the national Government were met by a trifle of some sixty or seventy million dollars annually. We are just beginning to learn, at the close of the fourth year of the war, that there is science, and a great deal of science in the business of taxing a large community -- if we do it on a moderately large scale, and do it with a fair consideration for the various industrial interests of the nation. Already great progress has been made by those who have had the business in hand; but, it is no reflection on their honesty or earnestness of purpose to say that it has been a progress looking more toward immediate results -- that is, actual money returns -- than toward a nice and equitable distribution and adjustment of the public burdens. However, actual, returns in money are precisely what are wanted at this particular juncture, and in this view we think the Commissioner of Internal Revenue may fairly and honestly be congratulated on his financial exhibit, covering the whole transactions of his branch of the service for the fiscal year ending in June, 1864.

abstract: Mr. BANCROFT contributes to the Ledger of this week an extended and most admirable sketch of EDWARD EVERETT. The two were associates in early life and the warm personal friendship which then grew up between them was never interrupted. Mr. BANCROFT's delineation of Mr. EVERETT's character, mental and moral, is exceedingly happy, and the biographical part of his sketch embraces many interesting incidents not mentioned elsewhere.

abstract: Paper from Corn Husks
snippet: Paper from Corn Husks
lead_paragraph: Two more captured blockade-runners, the Charlotte and Stag, arrived at this port lest week, from Admiral PORTER's fleet, after an unusually cold and rough passage from Fort Fisher. The Stag was captured by the United States steamer Maratanza, Lieut Commander G.W. YOUNG, and at the time of her capture was commanded by Lieut. Commander R.H. GAYLE, Confederate States Navy. She is a Confederate vessel, and was undoubtedly intended to be fitted out for a privateer after reaching Wilmington. She was sent north in charge of the following officers: Acting Master E.S. GOODWIN. Prize Master; Acting Ensign J.W. CROWELL, Executive Officer; Second-Assistant Engineer R.L. WEBB, acting Chief Engineer.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, it was voted to publish the correspondence of JAMES MADISON. Mr. SPRAGUE introduced a bill to increase the pay of members of Congress from $3,000 to $5,000 per annum. A resolution calling on the Secretary of War for information as to the number of troops furnished by each State was adopted. A spicy discussion sprang up on a resolution offered by Mr. DAVIS to appoint a select committee of five on the Corruptions of the Government." Pending which, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Precedents and American Practices
snippet: Precedents and American Practices
lead_paragraph: Some of the forms which national antagonism take are as singular as they are inexplicable. Everybody has observed the regularity with which, whenever our army or navy, or any officer of the Government, commits any act which is on general or even on purely legal grounds open to objection, somebody starts up to justify it by "British precedents." As there is hardly any species of violence or injustice of which Great Britain has not at one period or other been guilty, of course there is an abundance of these precedents always at hand. What is most remarkable about this process of purification is, that they are used with an air of triumph, not against England only, but against every nation that may happen to have cause of complaint against us. A great many people seemed inclined to believe, for instance, that England's having permitted the Essex to be cut out of a neutral port, was a complete answer to the remonstrances called forth from Brazil by the cutting out of the Florida.
headline: {'main': 'English Precedents and American Practice.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'English Precedents and American Practice.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There are two bills before the State Legislature touching the interests of our city, which we trust will not be allowed to fail. One is the Health Bill, the other is the bill establishing a Paid Fire Department. Both are of the utmost importance to the good order, prosperity and safety of our city. Both are vigorously opposed by parties personally interested in perpetuating existing abuses, and by nobody else. Their enactment will be welcomed, by the great body of our people, with enthusiasm, and will inspire the hope that our city is not yet wholly given over to pestilence and profligacy.
lead_paragraph: There are two bills before the State Legislature touching the interests of our city, which we trust will not be allowed to fail. Their enactment will be welcomed, by the great body of our people, with enthusiasm, and will inspire the hope that our city is not yet wholly given over to pestilence and profligacy.

abstract: Canada; good will and U S Diplomacy
snippet: Canada; good will and U S Diplomacy
lead_paragraph: There are few among us that expect to find the practical way of dealing with international questions adopted by the National Government perfectly understood abroad -- just at the moment. It takes time, generally, to make questions bearing on our foreign relations so apparent that the instant assent of a friendly neighbor can be reckoned on. But still, our way of doing things sometimes finds appreciation much sooner than we could almost have ventured to hope for. The people of the bordering Provinces, a ten months ago, supposed that they might keep up a profitable commerce at one and the same time with the United States and with the States in rebellion against the national authority. These hopeful people have just begun to find out that they cannot do this sort of thing with any profit. The journals which have come to us from Quebec during the past week are filled with parliamentary speeches from members in office, and from members out of office -- all couched in terms of good will. The frontier, according to these reports, is now protected by a volunteer force which is to cost the people one million of dollars a year. The laws which relate to the protection of so-called political refugees are to be amended by an enactment which will compel them to give security for their good behavior. The money stolen at St. Albans by the "Confederate" robbers is to be at once repaid. The Judge who connived with the felons is suspended from office. And, in short, the colonial people have begun thoroughly to understand that they cannot, at one and the same time, live in friendship with the President and people of the United States, while they lend themselves, their policemen and their Judges of the Petty Sessions to the small larceny business of JEFF. DAVIS. Let us here note, also, that the Chief Justice of Upper Canada, W.H. DRAPER, C.B., gave, on Friday, a common-sense decision, which is final in its character, and by which the pirate BURLEIGH will be at once surrendered, in accordance with the Extradition Treaty.

abstract: A meeting of the Board of Commissioners of the Fire Department, Western District, was held at No. 9 Court-street, on Saturday night, at which the project of reducing the working force the department one-third was discussed, and eventually resolved upon. The introduction of steam-engines, taken together with the increasing expenditures, has rendered this course advisable. There are at present 40 companies, of which 18 are engines, including 5 steamers, 17 hose-carts and 5 trucks. Another meeting is to be held this evening, when the resolution will be carried with full effect.

abstract: Gen. MEADE has issued an important order, intended to arouse a proper spirit of emulation among the enlisted men of the army. It provides by the recognition and reward of meritorious conduct by granting, under specified conditions, furloughs to such men as by attention to duty, proficiency in drill, conduct on the march and in battle, and care of arms, horses and equipments, have proved themselves to be the best soldiers in the bridgades to which they are attached.

abstract: The steamship America, which left Southampton on the 18th, and brings news three days later than that received by the Cuba, arrived here yesterday. The Glasgow, of the Inman line, from Liverpool on the 11th, via Queenstown on the 12th, also arrived here yesterday. The Glasgow brings a duplicate of the news summary forwarded by the Virginia, which left Liverpool early on the morning of the 11th, but which has not yet arrived. The steamship Borussia, from Southampton on the 11th, likewise arrived yesterday. The news by these vessels is anticipated. We publish a summary of the more important points in the Virginia report in other columns. The London Spectator has reason to believe that the Oueen will open Parliament in person. The London Times discourses at great length to the Confederate leaders, declaring how needless it is for them to expect European intervention by emancipating their slaves. Particulars are given of the loss of the splendid new blockade-running steamer, the Lelid, near Liverpool, on Saturday, the 14th inst; -- reference was made to this shipwreck in the report by the Cuba, published in yesterday's issue of the TIMES. The Pope's letter was causing serious ecclesiastical discussion in France. The Emperor NAPOLEON is to have his Life of Julius Caesar translated into English, and is to revise the proof-sheets himself.

abstract: The French steamship Washington, which was to have left Havre on the 11th inst., we are informed was detained on account of an imperfection having been discovered, a day or two before, in a piece of the machinery, which it was prudently decided to displace at once, rather than run any risk. The Lafayette, of the same line, will leave Havre on the 8th of February, and the Washington on the 8th of March.

abstract: The State Department Dispatches
snippet: The State Department Dispatches
lead_paragraph: We publish the full text of the dispatches issued from the State Department in regard to the seizure of the Florida. The substance of these dispatches was given to the public several weeks ago. But very many of our readers will be pleased to have laid before them, in a complete form the reasons which Mr. SEWARD assigns for disavowing the act of the United States naval and consular subordinates at Bahia, at the same time that he presents to the Brazilian Government the grave provocation offered to the United States in the hasty recognition of the pirates as belligerents by an important American State. The points in Mr. SEWARD's rejoinder to M. BARBOZA, will be found to be admirably taken, and illustrated with a force, pith and conciseness which have rarely been excelled in any modern State paper.

abstract: Mr. MAX MARETZEK's forthcoming season commences on Thursday next, with DONIZETTI's admirable opera of "Don Sebastian," which we learn, with no surprise, has been the principal attraction of the Boston campaign. On the following night "Fra Diavolo" will be given, and on Saturday, (at the matinee,) "Il Poliuto." Of Mr. MARETZEK's intentions, we hear that two of MEYERBEER's operas are to be revived, and VERDI's latest work, "La Forza del Destino," to be produced. The season will last until April, when the artistes are to repair to Chicago for the purpose of opening the new opera house there. Thus our musical season draws rapidly to an end. The sale of tickets for the week's performances commences at the Academy to-day; the demand for boxes has been unusually large.

lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen. BUTLER arrived at Lowell last Saturday. In the evening he addressed a large audience in that city, giving his version of his connection with the Army of the James, the operations of that Army around Richmond, and of the first Wilmington expedition. We are indebted to the courtesy of Mr. WILLIAM MARTIN, Manager of the People's Telegraphic Line, and to his obliging assistants, for the prompt transmission of our special report of Gen. BUTLER's speech.

abstract: In the Senante yesterday, an attempt was made by Mr. SAULSBURY to introduce a peace petition from Colorado JEWETT, but objection being made, the reading was suspended. A petition was presented, asking for the establishment of steam signals along the Atlantic coast. The House resolution reducing the duty on imported paper, with an amendment, striking out "three" and inserting "fifteen" per cent., was introduced and ordered to be printed.
lead_paragraph: The Senate then proceeded to the consideration of Mr. DAVIS' resolution for the appointment of a special committee on the corruptions of the Government in all its departments. Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, spoke against the resolution, and strongly censured the Navy Department for its course in regard to investigations into cases of alleged fraud. The clause of Mr. WILSON's new conscription act, which made the principal answerable for the conduct of his substitute, after the latter had been mustered in, was strickin out.

abstract: -- Twenty thousand dollars' worth of the three cent currency was issued, yesterday, at the Sub-Treasury. The new five and twenty-five cent notes will soon be ready....After the 1st prox. all receipts, whether for money or goods, must have a two cent stamp affixed....The New-York Post-office dispatches over twenty tons of mail matter per day, exclusive of that going to Europe and points on the coast....Seventeen thousand tickets, at $5 each, were sold for the Firemen's Ball, at the Academy of of Music, last evening.

abstract: The State Senate Committee yesterday morning continued its investigation of alleged abuses in the City Inspector's Department.
lead_paragraph: The first witness called was Daniel B. Badger, President of the New-York Sanitary Chemical Compost Manufacturing Company. The witness testified that in June last, in answer to an advertisement of the Street-cleaning Commission of the city, he made a proposal to clean all the streets and alleys of New-York for the sum of $300,000 a year. His offer was not accepted. He again offered to do the work on the 19th of January for the same sum.

abstract: Officer HORBELT, of the Fourth Precinct, apprehended JOHN MCLAUGHLIN, and he was committed by Justice DOWLING for robbing PATRICK HIGGINS of a watch and chain, valued at $500, and $40 in money, in a Water-street den, on Friday night last....Officer BUDDINGTON, of the Fifteenth, saw a girl carrying a large bundle, on Sunday night, and, after following her an hour or more, took her to the Station-house, where the bundle was examined and found to contain $200 worth of wearing apparel. This the prisoner confessed she had stolen from her mistress, Mrs. ELIZABETH FERRIS, of Great Jones-street. The girl was committee, by Justice LEDWITH, ....Lieut. AUGUSTUS W. LYON, of a Vermont regiment, was robbed in a Greene-street den, on Sunday night, by one ALLEN HUFF, a fellow who gained the Lieutenant's confidence by pretending to be a discharged soldier. HUFF was committed by Justice DOWLING.

abstract: The Quebec Evening Telegraph, of Jan. 27, in alluding to the action of the Canadian Government with reference to the St. Albans raiders, says: "The Judge of Sessions has at last received a communication from the Assistant Provincial Secretary, intimating to him that the Governor-General has deemed it expedient to cause a commission of inquiry to issue, with a view to investigate all the proceedings connected with the St. Albans offenders up to the time of their discharge by him; and conveying to him his (the Governor-General's) desire that he (Judge COURSAL) should, pending that investigation, abstain from acting as Judge of the Sessions of the Peace. He was also informed that the charge of the River Police had been made over to Col. ERMATINGER during that time."

He was also informed that the charge of the River Police had been made over to Col. ERMATINGER during that time."

abstract: The passport sys  THE PASSPORT SYSTEM, The passport sys  tem between the United States and Canadawas inaugurated and enforced by our Government immediately after the decision by Judge COURSOL, in December, releasing the rebel raiders. It was absolutely necessary that the people on the other side of the lines should understand that we were determined to protect our border by whatever measures might be found necessary  ...
lead_paragraph: whether by military force, by restrictions upon intercourse, by general legislation bearing upon their interests, or by any other means. Neither the unexpected adoption of the system, nor the abrogation of it which it is understood is about to take place, can be looked upon as hasty or indiscreet measures. If, in an individual case, marauders should break into one's ground from a neighboring estate, and if the neighbors, instead of being aroused to a sense of justice, should only jeer at the party assailed and afterward harbor those who had wronged him, it would not be surprising if he adopted very peremptory measures toward all who attempted again to approach his premises from that quarter, and subjected them to such surveillance as was necessary to prove their intentions, amicable or otherwise. But, if afterward he found that those who really possessed the authority on the other side of his lines utterly disapproved of the deeds of the assailants, and themselves adopted all necessary precautions against incursions from their grounds, punished the culprits or gave them up to the aggrieved party, and otherwise "brought forth fruits meet for repentance," then it would be perfectly proper to accept these actions in the spirit which had induced them, and show his appreciation thereof by promptly withdrawing the constabulary force which had been posted over against his neighbor's estate, and abolishing the surveillance which had been an imputation against his neighbor's honor. Both courses would be proper, and the promptitude of action in either case would not be a proof of haste or weakness, but at once of manly self-defence and a spirit of conciliation.

abstract: RAGES. The substitution of a national for a local currency will remedy more evils than one. The prime ends sought, of course, are first, uniformity of value, and next a reasonable security against counterfeits. The former of these objects, we have a fair assurance, will be secured; the latter will also be, in a measure, attained. At least, we shall not have one-tenth the number of spurious bills in circulation that we have now.
lead_paragraph: But there are incidental evils of a minor, but most aggravating kind, which will also disappear with the general introduction of a national currency. We desire to draw especial attention to one of these evils, and also to give one out of a hundred illustrations that might be given of the practical working of the thing. Day after day, complaints reach us of respectable persons -- honest and respectable house-keepers -- that have been subjected to insults for offering State money of a perfectly current character, at retail shops and market stalls in New-York. Many of these cases, but for the desire of the victims to avoid publicity, would have had an immediate and thorough exposure in these columns. One case, however, came under our notice on Saturday afternoon, which we feel authorized to bring before the public. A gentleman who does business down town asked another to meet him, for the sake of convenience, at a chop-house kept by one GUN, or GUNNING, near Exchange-place. The gentleman with whom the appointment was made was first at the place of rendezvous; and, having to wait for some time for his friend, he called for something, as the best excuse for being in the house at all. He tendered in payment for what he had a $5 bill, New-York State money. This was refused, and he was abruptly and rudely told, in the presence of a crowd of strangers, that he had offered counterfeit money. Perfectly satisfied that the bill was good, the gentleman was not inclined to lose his temper. He put the rejected bill back in his pocket, and tendered another, which was, first, likewise pronounced bad, but afterwards taken in payment. Just as this transaction was completed, the gentleman who had made the appointment came in. Nothing was said on either side about the money dispute, and the two sat down to lunch. When this was over, the last-arrived of the two gentlemen went to the desk to pay for the lunch. He had just come from his banker's, and, as luck would have it, he had only large bills about him. He tendered a New-York bill in payment, and without so much as looking at it, the person in charge tossed it back to his customer, and at the same time drew from the drawer the bill previously accepted from the gentleman who first entered the place, rudely and insolently demanding that his change should be given back to [???]. This man's insolence became perfectly outrageous. But both of the gentlemen, were determined to avoid a quarrel in such a place. The person in charge was civilly asked to send a waiter to one of the thousand adjoining broker's offices and see if the bills tendered were good or bad. This he at first declined to do; and made a parade of handing the money round among his comrades all of whom declared it bad. The determined attitude of the gentlemen, however, soon made the keeper of the place take another view of the matter. He sent or pretended to send out to test the genuineness of the money. The reported answer of the messenger was that "the brokers had refused it." But said the chop-house man, "I will take the bill," putting it again in the drawer. "You will do no such thing," said the gentleman who had tendered it. You have charged us with passing bad money, and insulted us, and we must now see if the bills are good." The money was then taken by one of the gentlemen to WHYTE, MORRIS & CO.'s, on Wall-street, and there promptly exchanged for greenbacks, the second gentleman meanwhile mortgaging his person at the counter, until the exchange of bills was effected. No words can convey an idea of the outrageous insolence to which these gentlemen -- either of them probably carrying enough money about them to buy out the entire eating-house -- were subjected. They could not condescend to raise a personal quarrel with the individual who had thus treated them, and made them for the time the jeers of his companions. They could have had no redress at law, for insolence, unfortunately, is not an indictable offence. And their only mode of redress is that which is now adopted -- exposure -- so that others may not unwittingly be made the victims of a similar outrage in the same quarter.

abstract: Tribune; Missions, Rebel Purpose and Spirit; Other Negotiations Alleged by; [Trib]; Hates the North and will Fight to the Last
snippet: Tribune; Missions, Rebel Purpose and Spirit; Other Negotiations Alleged by; [Trib]; Hates the North and will Fight to the Last
lead_paragraph: The correspondent of one of our cotemporaries, which has done all in its power to foster the peace delusion, declares that, though the Blair mission is a failure, Georgia and North Carolina are both coming back into the Union; that "there are rumors in high quarters, positive allegations," that "peace negotiations are progressing successfully in other directions, and that the first we shall hear of these terms will be in proclamations over the signatures of the Governors of Georgia and North Carolina." It appears, moreover, that Mr. STANTON's object in visiting Savannah was neither more nor less than to discuss with Gen. SHERMAN, "the terms he should propose, and which he should hold himself, on behalf of his Government, ready to accept."

abstract: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- The comic drama of "Charles the Second," well known in New-York, although not hitherto played at this house, was produced last evening, with complete success. The situations are lively, and the last act is exceedingly well worked up. The dialogue is by no means brilliant; fortunately, however, there is not much of it, and it is intrusted to first-class artists. Mr. GILBERT, as Captain Copp, took off the honors. He was well supported by Miss MARY GANNON, Miss IONE BURKE, Mrs. JENNINGS, Mr. FISHER, and Mr. FLOYD.

abstract: speech at Lowell
snippet: speech at Lowell
lead_paragraph: it professes unbounded devotion to the cause of the country; but its temper is thoroughly insubordinate, because it makes a personal issue with the General's superior officers, and appeals from them to the public, not only upon their action in regard to himself, but upon their own conduct in matters where, by the necessities of the case, they are supreme. Gen. BUTLER, it is true, assumes to be only defending himself, but he does it by assailing others. "If I did make mistakes," he says, in effect, "they were neither so gross nor so costly as those made by Lieut.-Gen. GRANT and other officers in command." And the responsibility for many of the acts for which he is blamed, actually rests, as he contends, upon other shoulders.

abstract: Railroad Sufferings; Sufferings and American Patience; North American Review on American Social Defects
snippet: Railroad Sufferings; Sufferings and American Patience; North American Review on American Social Defects
lead_paragraph: We have often thought of the influence of this cause, when considering one remarkable peculiarity of the American people -- their unequaled patience. Travelers have often observed it. We bear anything, and suffer anything, from our rulers, or those who are serving the public. Abuses which would set an Englishman's blood in a fever, and fill the columns of the London Times with indignant letters, and certainly lead to litigations, are endured here day after day, without a murmur. People come to look on the wrongs they suffer from the public -- especially on those inflicted by great corporations -- somewhat as they do on the sufferings caused by the weather -- as a thing inevitable, and not to be grumbled at or cured. This is especially a frontier peculiarity. Every one in a pioneer community must be good-natured; each must help the other; no one must grumble, and no one expects anything very complete, either in public or private arrangements. This habit of endurance, of "putting up" with abuses and defects, comes back to us where the excuse for it no longer exists. It is most of all exhibited with regard to our railroad management.

abstract: Ball
snippet: Ball
lead_paragraph: An immense tent covered the stage, at the rear of which stood the beautiful steamer of Engine Company No. 13, and the handsome little carriages of Hose Companies Nos. 7 and 29. In front of these a large gas fixture was placed, which blazoned forth in letters of light the word "Charity," below that a large eagle, below that again the words "New-York Fire Department Fund," and under all the coat-of-arms of the department. In front of the tent was hung the old firemen's banner. Between the boxes and about the columns pipes, trumpets and fire caps were grouped and lighted up by signal lamps belonging to the various fire companies. Flowers were distributed about the house in great profusion, in wreaths and bouquets, and were hung in graceful festoons around the tiers. Streamers of red, white and blue bunting were draped from the upper tier to the dome, from the centre of which was suspended a very large and well arranged basket of flowers. GRAFFULA's quadrille and promenade bands, of thirty-five pieces each, were stationed at either side of the house, and performed a choice selection of their favorite pieces.

abstract: The steamship Peruvian, from Liverpool Jan. 19, via Londonderry Jan. 21, arrived at Portland yesterday with two days later news from Europe. Messrs. SCHOFIELD, BRIGHT and BAXTER, members of Parliament, had addressed their constituents, and spoken favorably of the Union cause in their allusions to American affairs. Extensive orders for army clothing for the rebels have been executed in Liverpool. Lately twenty thousand uniforms were made for the rebel artillery. The gale prevalent when the Cuba sailed was most violent and destructive. No material damage had been done to American shipping. It is rumored that Russia and the Pope have quarreled over the Encyclical letter. Capt. CORBETT, who commanded the rebel pirate Sea King, alias Shenandoah, has been committed for trial on the charge of violating the Foreign Enlistment Act.

abstract: Count Johannes vs. S. R. Fisk, of Leader; Mandamus Denied; Smith >amp; Kerr vs Consolidated Stage Co; Rewinding up
snippet: Count Johannes vs. S. R. Fisk, of Leader; Mandamus Denied; Smith >amp; Kerr vs Consolidated Stage Co; Rewinding up
lead_paragraph: Hugh Smith and John Kerr vs. The New-York Consolidated Stage Company. -- Mr. Schell was, It may be remembered, the assignee of the Stage Company, and the above action was brought to set aside the assignment and wind up the affairs of the company. An order was granted, provisionally, in the action appointing Mr. Murphy Receiver of the Company, and enjoining Mr. Schell from interfering with the property or effects of the company. The case now comes up on motion to punish Mr. Schell as for a contempt of court, he having, under the advice of counsel, commenced suits on behalf of the company under advice of counsel. In connection with this a motion was made for leave to the receiver to sell some portions of the property of the company to meet the United States tax and other expenses. The court rendered a decision to-day in the first of these motions, adjudging Mr. Schell in contempt in commencing these suits, but giving him two days after notice to discontinue them, and intimating in such case no further punishment would be inflicted than costs of the motion.

lead_paragraph: If the enforcement of the draft in this city does not lead to riots and bloodshed, it will not be the fault of very many men in positions of influence. There seems to be a concerted effort to make the mass of our people believe that the Government is practicing a deliberate fraud upon the city; that it is demanding from it two or three times as many men as its just quota requires, and that it is doing this wantonly, intentionally, and for the sake of punishing our people for some fancied offence. Some of the less scrupulous of our newspapers have gravely asserted that this is done for the purpose of revenging the vote given by the city at the last Presidential election. The tendency of this strain of comment is in the highest degree mischievous. With the great mass of the people a draft is inevitably odious; but if they are taught to believe that it is fraudulent and unjust, as well as onerous and severe, they will naturally resent and resist it.

abstract: Parties arriving from different points in the interior of Georgia state that a great reaction is taking place in the minds of the people, who now openly confess that the attempt to establish a Southern Confederacy is a failure, and that it is useless for Georgia to extend any more aid to this end.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the Associated Press.
